para.tab:
Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)
took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, I seek your indulgence. I wish to inform the House that late yesterday I was in breach of standing orders in that I allowed a staff member to enter the precincts of the chamber. For that misdemeanour, I apologise to the House.

speech.speaker: Martin, Stephen, MP

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the member for Cunningham moving forthwith:
That this House:

(1)
calls on the members for Leichhardt, Capricornia, Dawson, Herbert and Hinkler to explain their opposition to the 500 per cent increase in the reef tax.

(2)
Endorses this opposition to the reef tax increase because:

(a)
the 500 per cent increase poses the greatest danger to the Queensland tourism industry since 1989;

(b)
the increase in the reef tax will effectively bring about the destruction of the marine reef tour operators on the Great Barrier Reef;

(c)
the 500 per cent tax increase damages the credibility of both Prime Minister John Howard and the Government because they are breaching an election commitment not to raise taxes;

(d)
the reef tax hike will cost tourism operators in Queensland millions of dollars and cause job losses;

(e)
the Howard Government is using the tax hike as a crutch to reduce or stop funding to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority;

(f)
without question, there will be job reductions, tourists will visit other destinations such as Indonesia, the Solomons, Guam and Hawaii and the impact of this decision on the business community where people in
private enterprise are working on very tight margins and on minimum staff needs to be considered; and

(3)
calls on the government to immediately abandon its plans to impose a 500 per cent increase in the reef tax.
Mr Acting Speaker, it is an absolute outrage that we cannot debate this in the House at this time.
That the member be not further heard.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Bevis, Arch, MP

talk.start.para: —I second the motion. It is interesting that the gang of five is now a gang of three. You can gag the debate in this parliament but you can't gag us in the public debate in North Queensland.

speech.para: That the honourable member be not further heard.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.para: Question put:

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para:
—Mr Acting Speaker, I seek your indulgence in regard to standing order 303. I call your attention to the antics of the member for Batman (Mr Ferguson) in yesterday afternoon's debate. I do not take this indulgence lightly. I ask you to review the tapes and the
Hansard
of yesterday afternoon. You were not in the chair, Mr Acting Speaker. This is the first available opportunity that I have had to bring this matter to your attention. Yesterday afternoon the member for Batman—I refer to standing order 303 under the heading `Disorder'—`persistently and wilfully obstructed the business of the House'. He also `persistently and wilfully disregarded the authority of the Chair'.
—I thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory. I will have a look at it.

—Mr Acting Speaker, when you are considering this matter you also might con
sider the fact that there seems to be a rather authoritarian strain developing in the government. What the government considered to be absolutely legitimate tactics when they were in opposition, the things that the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) was happy to do in opposition, he now decries as being terrible and disruptive.
—It is reflective of a vote of the House rather than the government, but I will certainly take into consideration what you have been saying.

—I am not reflecting on a vote of the House, Mr Acting Speaker. I am saying that if members of the government start to suggest to the Speaker that he should tighten up the standing orders in a draconian way that would prevent the opposition from properly being able to raise issues in this House—
—On a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker: this matter of indulgence is not debatable.
—I also raise a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker.
—This will be a great point of order. You don't even know the book.
—The honourable member for Mitchell will not assist me.

—I appreciate that you gave indulgence, but the standing orders are plain that any matter which goes to a reflection on the conduct of a member must be by substantive motion, and anything that imputes to the member for Batman improper conduct in relation to this House should be done in that manner. It is not a matter for indulgence and for you to report to the House; it is a matter to be done by substantive motion.

—I thank the honourable member, but the request was for me to read the
Hansard
and review the tapes.
—I move:

break.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Development of facilities for the Army Logistics Training Centre and the Bandiana Logistics Group at Bandiana and Bonegilla, Victoria.

The proposal will provide office accommodation, trade training and structural facilities, weapons storage and repair, and upgraded engineering services. The estimated outturn cost is $16.081 million. It is anticipated that construction will start in April 1997 and be completed by February 1999. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.sub1.title: Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs Committee

speech.speaker: Reith, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the House grants leave for the following submissions received by the Standing Committee on Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs to be adduced in evidence in proceedings before the Federal Court:

(1)
submission from Mr O. Harasymiw, dated 21 August 1996.

(2)
submission from Dr G. L. Kesteven, dated 26 August 1996.

Yesterday the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams) as Deputy Chair of the Standing Committee on Primary Industries, Resource and Rural and Regional Affairs made a statement on this matter on behalf of the committee. The position as I understand it is that the committee is currently conducting an inquiry into Commonwealth fisheries management. Two persons who have lodged submissions with the committee have asked that leave be given for their submissions to be used in evidence in proceedings before the Federal Court.

The committee has considered the request and, as the honourable member for Lyons informed the House yesterday, the committee has no objection to the granting of leave for the submissions to be adduced in evidence. I note this motion is quite consistent with the
practice of the House and that it in no way waives privilege. The provisions of article 9 of the Bill of Rights as applied by virtue of section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 apply. On that basis I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

proctext.para: That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 8 October 1996, at 2 p.m., unless the Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting.

talk.start.para: —It might be of interest to the House if the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) were to explain this motion a little more. He also might be willing to share with us his thoughts on the sittings of the House when President Clinton visits Australia. It is a matter that a number of members are interested in. Members want to know what they might be doing as regards their diaries and so on. Obviously the government will be looking at having some functions here in Canberra or replicating what the previous government did when President Bush visited Australia. Can the Leader of the House give us some idea on that as well as the other issue I raised?

—in reply—I do not have any information at this stage as to the possibilities of the Clinton visit or a date, but as soon as I do have that information I will obviously make it available to members. As to the sitting schedule for the balance of the year, there is no intention at this point to depart from the schedule already provided to members. There is one week near the end of the sitting period in which the Senate will be sitting. I suppose there is always a prospect for us to also sit in that week. But at this point I am not able to say anything other than that we expect to sit in accordance with the already published schedule.
—Mr Deputy Speaker—
—I am sorry to interrupt the member for Watson, but he has spoken to the motion. Does he wish to seek leave?
—Could I have leave, indulgence or something? The Leader of the House might be able to give us another little piece of information which would be of interest to all members.
—The honourable member for Watson does not have either leave or indulgence.
—I wish to adduce a further small piece of information from the Leader of the House regarding—
—I'm not inclined to give you leave for anything, Leo.
—I know you are not, but maybe you might be doing something for ordinary private members. Will we have a private members business day, seeing as we are giving up the Monday?
—The member for Watson is obliged to resume his seat. The debate is closed.
—In that case—
—The member for Watson does not have the call.
—In that case, can I have indulgence from you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to ask the Leader of the House whether we are going to have a private members day, seeing as we are giving up the Monday?
—The member for Watson did not even wait to discover whether he had indulgence or not.
—Sorry; I thought you were being decent. Are we going to have private members business?

interject.speaker: DEPUTY SPEAKER

talk.start.para: —There is no question before the House.

interject.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

proctext.para:
Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by
Mr Miles
:
That the bill be now read a second time.

upon which
Mr Latham
moved by way of amendment:

break.para: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1)
condemns the Government's mishandling of the Premiers' Conference;

(2)
notes with concern the impact this Bill will have on reduced State Government services and/or higher State taxes;

(3)
condemns the Government's breach of its promise, given before and after the election, that State general revenue assistance would not be cut; and

(4)
condemns the Government's cuts to public hospitals implicit in this Bill (around $450 million) and explicit in the 1996 Budget ($312 million)".

speech.speaker: Kerr, Duncan, MP

talk.start.para: —To date in this debate on the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill there has been a focus around the issues of health and of funding to the states. Today I want to take this matter further with respect to my own state of Tasmania and to draw out some of the consequences that will flow to that state from the decisions that have been made by the government and implemented through this legislation.

speech.para: To begin with, I suppose it is worth while referring to comments that were made by the Premier of my own state who believed that our community was improperly and unfairly dealt with by the federal government when it dealt with funding to the states. His comment was both powerful and condemnatory. He used language which would not normally be used in public discourse to describe what the Treasurer (Mr Costello) did to our state. He said:
Costello's only been there a dog's watch, but he has been making Willis and Dawkins look good.

When you think that has been the perpetual excuse, shall I say, of Liberal administrations in Tasmania—that their funding difficulties were caused by Commonwealth decisions under Labor governments—to find that expression used shows the magnitude of the concern that exists in my state.

It was not just the Tasmanian Premier who was concerned about the way in which the states were being treated. As a result of the Premiers Conference which decided the
measures which are now coming before this House today, Premier Brown from South Australia said:
Commonwealth‐state relations have never been as low as they are now.
Both those comments are accurate. It is true to say that no federal government has treated the states in the last 20 years of federalism as this federal government has.

This federal government has betrayed the whole philosophical basis upon which it asserted its legitimacy to govern: first, by betraying its expressed promises to the community at large on a whole range of issues and, secondly, by betraying the commitment that it gave to the states—a commitment that it put very high to restore some integrity into federalism. Rather than increasing funding to the states to enable them to proceed in a way which was anticipated by those governments, the government reduced their funding base both in direct and indirect payments and thereby reduced programs which are directly relevant to people who expect services from state governments.

I will take my own state of Tasmania because it is going to be particularly savaged. Tasmania is unique in Australia because it has the highest population of people who are welfare dependent. This is nothing to be satisfied with; it is simply the truth. Tasmania has the highest proportion of health care card holders, it has the highest proportion of those dependent on government, and it has structurally some of the highest unemployment in the country—and has had for decades. A failure to provide arrangements which go to the employment base of our state and which rip apart the public sector does enormous damage to the prospects of Tasmania.

I am increasingly despairing of any prospect for economic growth in my own state. Tasmania has a flat economy. It has structural problems of a dimension far greater than that which applies to the rest of the community. What did we find? We found that the impact of the regressive and unfair budget measures brought down by this government impact to a far greater degree on my own state of Tasmania than they do on other parts of Australia.

break.para: Direct cuts that flow from the budget now total over $48 million. When we are used to talking about billions of dollars, a sum of $48 million might be easily dismissed. But when you come from a state like Tasmania, where you know that the revenue base available to the state government is minuscule compared with the revenue bases that are available to state governments in Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia, you know it is not practicable to substitute, by increased state revenues, those funds that have been withdrawn from the Commonwealth.

Tasmania already has some of the highest state charges and taxes throughout the Commonwealth. It has those highest charges because revenue has to be raised from such a small base. There is no practical way of reducing those charges, nor indeed is there a practical way of increasing them because, if one were to increase them in order to substitute for some of the Commonwealth funding deficiencies, the existing disadvantages that our state faces in attracting investment become greater.

With mobile capital and mobile investment, a state which is dramatically out of the norm of all other Australian states would not be capable of attracting investment or retaining the small amount of investment that it already holds. So our state government is trapped in a position where it cannot raise its revenue to substitute for the expenditure reductions that are being imposed by the Commonwealth. Nor is there a private sector ready to take off in my state of Tasmania.

The programs that were behind the growth in some key sectors of the Tasmanian economy are being stripped away. One of the few bright lights that exist in Tasmania in terms of potential growth is the shipbuilding industry, building catamarans. There are only a few bright spots in Tasmania and that is one of the brightest. The budget measure that most savagely impacts on Tasmania in terms of private sector growth is that which relates to the bounty scheme, which is being withdrawn. We have the huge irony that this government is prepared to review its own budget decisions to make sure that companies such as BHP can import vessels from overseas shipbuilders,
subsidising them to do so, at the same time withdrawing bounties which enable boats to be built in this country and enable our manufacturers to compete on roughly equivalent terms with the subsidised shipbuilders of other nations.

When the Managing Director of Incat, Bob Clifford, has the temerity to draw attention to those consequences and to the deficiencies of the new training arrangements, his concerns are dismissed by the new government. Unless the new training arrangements are reviewed—he employs more than 100 people—he will miss out on opportunities to bring down the benefits that are alleged to flow from the new apprenticeship arrangements and he will not be able to access the Working Nation programs any more because they are being withdrawn.

I understand that there is some prospect that these matters may be looked at again. I know that when the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, went to Incat he promised that these matters would be reviewed. We are still waiting for that and we want that to happen, but the track record to date looks pretty poor.

We have a state which does not have the capacity to raise its own revenues, a state where private sector investment is, to say the best, sluggish, with a state Liberal government that has no investment or private sector growth strategy—certainly none that has had any discernible effect—and a state where the few areas of economic stimulation that have come in are being withdrawn. Where are they being withdrawn from? Not only from direct funding to the states but also through programs—for example, the better cities program, which has been used to develop new growth areas in Launceston.

The Inveresk rail project has drawn together state, Commonwealth and local governments and the University of Tasmania, but future funding will not occur. The better cities program was actually delivering benefits in a real sense to Tasmania in terms of jobs and helping to shape the possibility of some resurgence of growth in the economy that is now not available. So, too, the Working Nation program. For many parts of Australia,
the Working Nation program was important because it meant that people who had been out of the work force for a long time had some chance to get back in, and it gave them, notwithstanding the fact that the ordinary operations of the labour market would have otherwise left them outside, the opportunity for re‐employment.

But in Tasmania it meant much more than that. Because the Labor government saw it as important to address the resources of the Working Nation program to areas which had the greatest employment needs, Tasmania naturally benefited more per capita than any other state—because we had the greatest long‐term unemployment. So Working Nation was not only important in getting Tasmanians some work experience and some chance to gain labour market skills which they would not otherwise have had; it actually supported public sector investment which would not otherwise have occurred. Most particularly in that regard I refer to the Aquatic Centre, a large complex developed by the Hobart City Council where the actual cash value input of the Working Nation program was specifically structured and supported at levels which were arrived at in order to make sure that project could proceed and meant the difference between a major multi‐million dollar project going ahead or not going ahead.

In the same way, Working Nation programs were important to the state tourism industry because of the support they provided to the state government through the National Parks and Wildlife Service. So a whole amount of infrastructure that was important for walking tracks and wilderness protection came through the Working Nation programs. That will all go.

Our hospitals are going to be devastated. The way in which public sector funds for health have been dealt with—about $780 million effectively slashed from the budget—will mean that an already fragile and poorly performing health system will have to sack literally hundreds of staff. There are no other jobs for them to go to. The Tasmanian economy has no slack to be picked up. These people will simply be discarded. This is an extraordinary recipe to respond to concerns
about unemployment. Sacking people to create jobs is akin to fornification to virginity. It is an absurd, stupid and malign concept.

What other funds have been withdrawn? The amount of $16 million will be forgone in general revenue grants in order to allegedly help out with the federal budget deficit—a completely pointless, stupid, unnecessary move. This will be done in order, and only in order, to give some cover to this government that is really seeking to bring back malign policies that would not have otherwise had the endorsement of the population. It is extraordinary when the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), in his more honest moments, described the economy that he inherited as better than good, yet we then find this government in office in its first budget taking these measures—measures which are quite unnecessary.

We have the third best balance of payments, terms of trade deficit, in the OECD—outcomes that other governments would give their eye teeth for. What do we find? We find this government pretending that Australia has a crisis on its hands. As well as $16 million forgone in general grants, we have $29 million in cuts to tied grants to Tasmania and $3 million in Commonwealth sales tax to be stripped away—a total cut of $48 million.

You can do your own sums but at the very least $48 million on a recurrent basis means substantially more than 2,000 jobs lost to the Tasmanian economy directly. Then there are the indirect consequences. In a flat, low employment economy, with no growth and no opportunities, if 2,000 jobs go the multiplier effect applies. You would expect the consequence in Tasmania to be in the order of 6,000 to 8,000 jobs lost in addition to the high levels of existing unemployment directly as a consequence of those cuts.

Then add to those consequences what has happened to those who are in greatest need in the community. Remember I mentioned to begin with that Tasmania has the highest number of health care card holders. What do they face? They face much higher charges for their pharmaceuticals. They face the fact that they now have to wait immense periods of time for dental treatment.

In my own electorate of Denison the waiting period for general treatment, even with the Commonwealth program that had reduced the waiting period for public treatment for teeth, is now 18 months. In Mr Miles's electorate the waiting period is two years. The program has been stripped away. Those periods are going to blow out. The public health system will have reductions in its funding. People will not have access even to things as simple as treatment for their teeth.

People who are seeking to re‐enter the work force will not have access to the Working Nation programs. I hear the government saying that some of these programs were not particularly well targeted but in my own state a number of those programs, such as those run for Incat and Purity, had near 100 per cent success records. A number of the general service programs were producing results in the order of 50 per cent; some were lower. But the basics are that the long-term unemployed in Tasmania are not going to benefit by what the new government is proposing because there is not a strong labour market to take them up.

With the reduction of public expenditure, the knock‐on effects of that unemployment in my own state of Tasmania will soar. There is no doubt about that. This is not an arguable proposition. No‐one from the government will dispute it. No‐one from the state government will dispute it. Tasmania is hung out to dry. The state of Tasmania, more so than any other place, because of its economic disadvantages, its regional disadvantages, is being done over with no way of responding to those consequences.

Even the Tasmania package that the coalition brought forward has been a dud. Instead of the approximately $49 million that the Commonwealth projected in its subsidy for a Bass Strait crossing, the projection is for about half that funding. It does not add to the capacity across the Bass Strait so it will not really significantly impact on tourist operations. It might assist a little bit in winter tourism, but that is all.

The programs that were promised have not been delivered. Then we have the cuts to the freight equalisation scheme and cuts to the
wheat scheme, which will mean that the price of bread will go up. All this together means that there is rightfully a sense of absolute despair in Tasmania. We need regional policies that actually reach out and do something to make sure that we do not leave behind those parts of Australia which do face greater difficulties. This government is leaving them behind.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Hockey, Joe, MP

talk.start.para: —If there was any doubt about the philosophical and directional differences between a Labor government and a coalition government, then perhaps they are best borne out by the contribution of the Commonwealth to the states over a period of time. That contribution to the states basically takes two forms. The first form, of course, is general purpose grants and the second form is specific purpose payments.

speech.para: This bill provides for $16.3 billion in general purpose assistance to the states in 1996-97. Of that $16.3 billion, $15.346 billion is in the form of what is known as financial assistance grants. The rest of the money is made up of some adjustments. The most significant adjustment, of course, is the $615 million contribution from the states to the federal government's budgetary problems. Those problems, variously known as Beazley's black hole and Labor's legacy, are something that the states—I welcome the states' contribution here—must contribute to because they are beneficiaries of a strong and vibrant economy. They are the beneficiaries of responsible fiscal management at the Commonwealth level. That flows through to the states in the form of increased revenue for them through payroll tax, stamp duty and various other taxes, fees and fines, and the increased growth in the overall economy contributes to their own increase in their own purpose funding.

There is a variation that I would like to talk about today; that is, the role of specific purpose payments. This is where the most significant difference between the Labor Party and the coalition parties in government comes to the fore. In the 1996-97 budget, the Commonwealth is allocating $18,170 million in specific purpose payments to the states. Of
that sum, $11,135 million is in direct specific purpose payments to the states and $7,035 million travels through the states to specific purposes. Therefore, the total allocation to the states in 1996-97 is $33,516 million. Of that allocation, 46 per cent is in the form of general purpose assistance and 54 per cent is in the form of specific purpose payments. The overwhelming majority of the payments to the states is in the form of specific purpose payments. This is not necessarily unusual. It is a legacy we have been left with and it is a reflection of the centralism of the ALP when they have been in government.

Specific purpose payments started in 1923. They were used at that time for various purposes when the nation as a whole had a very basic private sector and the government had to take responsibility for developing new industries in our economy. Over the years there have been changes, of course. During the Menzies years it was important, in order to stimulate the development of higher education, that very specific purpose payments were made through the states to the universities.

However in 1972, when Gough Whitlam became Prime Minister, the SPP allocation to the states quadrupled in aggregate dollars. It went from 25.8 per cent of the total allocation to the states to 48.5 per cent. That is a very important point. All of a sudden, the Labor government comes in and they start winding up the specific purpose payments and tying the hands of the states and their ability to provide services to those most in need where the demand is.

Gough Whitlam was the great turning point in the relationship between the Commonwealth and the states in relation to specific purpose payments. It was not just the allocations to universities through his introduction of free education. It was the Whitlam government's commitment to extend the interference of the Commonwealth into the areas of preschools, child care, urban and regional development, hospitals and community health, and local government. The hands of the Commonwealth were extended into the areas that until that time were the direct responsibility of the states. Until that time, the public had a very clear understanding of the
difference in the roles and responsibilities of the Commonwealth government versus the state governments.

In 1975-76, as I said before, specific purpose payments represented 48.5 per cent of all the allocations to the states. In 1975-76, with the change of government, it took some time to change that relationship. The Fraser government was responsible about trying to free up the money that was allocated to the states. The Fraser government took the SPP ratio down from 48.5 per cent to 36 per cent in 1982-83. That included at the time an increase in the allocation to local government from $80 million to $425 million per annum.

There was a clear difference between the attitude of the Labor Party in government and that of the Liberal Party in government. In March 1983, as we all know, Bob Hawke came to power and again the relationship changed to the interfering Commonwealth government. Over the 13 years of Labor government, Bob Hawke, along with Paul Keating, who was an avowed centralist, took the ratio from 36 per cent to 53 per cent in 1995-96.

The relationship again changed between the Commonwealth and the states. It is interesting that during the debate on this bill we have had members of the Labor Party stand up and actually advocate the increased spending of the Commonwealth in areas that are the responsibility of the states. I recommend to the members of the Labor Party that they re-read section 51 of the constitution. I recommend to the members of the Labor Party that they look at the minutes of the initial meetings that set up the Commonwealth and the expected relationship as it has developed over time between the Commonwealth and the states. The more you tie the hands of the states in relation to specific purpose payments, the more you are affecting the delivery of services to the people most in need.

I do give credit where it is due. Credit is due to the attempts of Bob Hawke and Nick Greiner in 1990-91 to more clearly define the relationship between the Commonwealth and the states. In the Special Premiers Conference of July 1991 a number of goals were set and options were considered in relation to the
management of tied grants. Even by that stage Bob Hawke recognised that the level of specific purpose payments to the states had got out of control.

I would just like to repeat those options for the benefit of the House. They included, firstly, an assumption of responsibility for programs by the states with full absorption of tied grants into financial assistance grants; secondly, the broadbanding of grants by combining a number of specific payments; thirdly, lessening the conditions applying to the existing structure of payments; fourthly, the assumption by the Commonwealth of full financial and administrative responsibility for programs currently receiving tied grants; and, finally, where shared responsibility options are developed, alternative approaches such as better joint planning or consultation might prove to be a substitute for tied Commonwealth funding. There is a clear recognition out of those options by the Commonwealth under Bob Hawke that specific purpose payments were disadvantageous to the states and to the people who most needed the support.

In 1995-96, of the $33,703 million allocated in total assistance to the states, only $14,453 million was in financial assistance grants. The reason the recommendations of the Special Premiers Conference fell on the floor was that at the same time as Paul Keating knifed Bob Hawke he knifed the new developing relationship between the states and the Commonwealth. That was basically the end of any attempt to clearly define for the people of Australia the difference in roles and responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the states.

At times, however, governments had untied funding. Two of the most celebrated instances are, firstly, health in 1981-82 where the Commonwealth agreed that hospitals and community health funding should be untied and, secondly, in 1992 where Prime Minister Keating agreed that road funding should be untied. Even then, when the road funding was untied, it was still tagged as road funding. Therefore, there was a direct pressure on the states to say, `This has to go into roads,' instead of giving them the discretionary
power to perhaps put it into transport in some states.

There is no doubt that Queensland, Western Australia and a few of the other larger states deserve to have better road funding and deserve to have better roads. But in New South Wales there is a strong argument that instead of putting more and more money into roads, which the state government already does by its 3x3 road levy, the money should be going into better transport solutions, particularly in parts of western Sydney.

The argument is that under the opposition Commonwealth-State relations have unquestionably become more confused and more interfering. I am not saying that specific purpose payments are an ineffective way of improving a certain segment of the community. Specific purpose payments do have their role, and I accept that. But there are some legitimate areas, for example, where the Commonwealth purchases off the state various service deliveries. For example, in Aboriginal affairs it is easier for some of the state authorities to deliver services to various Aboriginal communities rather than the Commonwealth setting up a new service delivery system which duplicates some of the processes provided by the states.

Secondly, there are operational efficiencies if one state undertakes a project which benefits another. For example, if a highway is going to be built through New South Wales or there is an upgrade of the Pacific Highway, it is important that the benefit flows through to Queensland because they have a benefit in a better and safer main highway through to Sydney. That is an area where the Commonwealth has a legitimate responsibility to ensure that SPPs are used. The third area is to deliver national objectives. For example, SPPs were used to deliver the standardisation of railway gauges across Australia. In 1988, SPPs were used to deliver bicentennial celebrations right across the nation.

There are legitimate purposes for SPPs, but there are also downsides. The main area of downside is the duplication of services. Jeff Kennett said it very succinctly before the Premiers Conference in 1994. He said, `You have a Commonwealth department of health
that does not treat one patient and you have a Commonwealth department of education that does not teach one pupil.' That is a fair point. It is a generalisation, but it is a fair point because the Commonwealth has no responsibility for teaching children in schools. Therefore, why should the Commonwealth be funding schools, whether they be private schools or public schools?

One of this year's major SPPs, which I think was just over $1 billion, was in funding for private schools. I am not saying for a second that the private schools do not deserve or do not need that funding but, given, for example, that the New South Wales Department of Education funds $6 billion of the recurrent costs in school education, why is the Commonwealth duplicating that overall service?

The second area of concern relates to duplication and various groups playing off the Commonwealth and the states for funding. I do not think there is any doubt on both sides of this House that, when it comes to election time, people and various groups in our communities who have asked their state or local governments for funding and have received the big no turn to the Commonwealth government and ask them whether they can fund the local swimming pool, park or sporting facilities. At the end of the day, it all comes out of one pocket, and that is the taxpayers' pocket. Because it comes out of one pocket, we ought to ensure that only one hand is giving out the money. In certain circumstances, that hand should be the state; in certain circumstances, that hand should be the Commonwealth; and, in certain circumstances, that hand should be local government. But it is all taxpayers' money.

There is duplication. Various interest groups, no matter how poorly organised, always manage to play off one tier of government against another. A good example of this is in legal aid, where currently there is a dispute about whether the Commonwealth is decreasing funding for legal aid. The states also provide significant funding for legal aid. In 1996-97 the Commonwealth provided $150 million to legal aid around Australia.

break.para: The third downside of SPPs is that, because they are coming from the Commonwealth, money and support do not necessarily get to the people most in need. For example, during the severe drought in New South Wales and Queensland, the rural adjustment scheme simply tied farmers in red tape. The Commonwealth from Canberra was trying to decide at what point on the map people were in need of money and were not in need of money. There was a gross duplication of services. Agriculture departments in New South Wales and Queensland were constantly in battle to try to get the money there.

The most significant area where that downside occurs is in community services, particularly in disability services where $300 million is being allocated this year, and in home and community care where $305 million has been allocated by the Commonwealth. Those services are also provided by the states. In some cases, the states are delivering the services but the federal government is stepping in.

A fourth downside is that Canberra keeps telling the states how to spend their money. Having been involved at the state level, I can say that this is the most damaging aspect of specific purpose payments.

A classic example is where a certain program, perhaps in community services, has a 60 per cent success rate and the Commonwealth—or the state might argue—comes along for political purposes and says, `We will offer you 50c in the dollar if you go ahead with this terrific program.' The states have a 60 per cent success rate and it costs them only 50c in the dollar, so they say, `We are tight for money; we will go ahead with this program.' But they have an alternative program which has a 90 per cent success rate, and they have to pay 100c in the dollar, and they abandon that program.

So from Canberra we are telling the governments of Perth, Brisbane, Hobart, Melbourne and Sydney how to deliver the services that best suit the needs of their local communities. Importantly, this lowers the discretionary funding for the states.

The final, most important area is accountability. Haven't we seen some great flick
passes over the years between the Commonwealth and the states about exactly who is responsible for higher education or who is responsible for community services? Forty‐five per cent of all the funding to the states comes from the Commonwealth. This vertical fiscal imbalance between the Commonwealth and the states, this imbalance about a state's ability to raise its own funding and then spend its own money on its own services, is creating ongoing hardship to the people most in need—the community out there whom we represent.

Specific purpose payments need to be pared back. This government, I am sure, will pare them back because it is a tradition of the Liberal government that we give the states the opportunity to do what they can do best, and that is delivering services to those in need.

speech.speaker: Lee, Michael, MP

talk.start.para: —Following from the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey), you can certainly claim that this government is definitely paring back specific purpose payments, and in some ways that is in accordance with the recommendations in the report of the National Commission of Audit. It suggested that you get more efficient national and state financial administration for the country if you redirect all the money that is now provided in specific purpose payments for health and community services and subtract 10 per cent for the federal Treasury, providing only 90 per cent of the funding that is now available to the states. Of course, that would result in a reduction of the quality of service to patients and the broader community. That is obviously what this government has in mind.

speech.para:
The honourable member says that there are all sorts of problems caused by vertical fiscal imbalance. This government plans to have the federal government hand back responsibility for health, community services and aged care to the states, and is looking at in some way handing back to the states the responsibility for education and transport. Surely that is going to increase the vertical fiscal imbalance and make all those problems that you claim are caused by the imbalance even worse. For those reasons, I was not persuaded by the
honourable member for North Sydney, despite his eloquence in today's debate.

Today I want to spend a few minutes putting on the record the opposition's view on this government's decision to reduce federal funding for public hospitals. Almost every day there are stories in our newspapers, on radio and on television about the difficulties all of our public hospitals are having right across the country. In Victoria, in particular, virtually every day for the last fortnight the Melbourne
Age
has had a story that typifies and amplifies the crisis in public hospitals in that state. In my own state of New South Wales, despite the fact that New South Wales is the only state government that has been ramping up its expenditure on public hospitals, the public hospital system is also under pressure.

talk.start.para: —Ha, ha!

—For the information of the honourable member who is laughing on the government side of the chamber could I point out to him that New South Wales has actually increased its funding to public hospitals by $640 million over the last two years. Yes, the hospitals are still under pressure.

speech.para: We would hope that all members of this chamber would accept the first point—that is, our public hospitals are under pressure right across the country. I would have hoped that would be something everyone agreed with. The member for North Sydney may have even attended the odd rally or two at hospitals in or adjacent to his electorate.

talk.start.para: —Organised them.

—He might have organised one or two, as the member for Werriwa suggests. The question I put to the honourable member for North Sydney is: if he is so enthusiastic about attending and organising the rallies, why could he not have at least come into this chamber today in this debate and called on his own government and his own party to reverse the cutbacks they have made in public hospitals right across the country?
—Commonwealth money is not the solution.

—Commonwealth money is not the solution? The honourable member for
North Sydney is saying that he does not think the federal government should put any money into public hospitals across the country.

speech.para:
Mr Hockey interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —He is already trying to walk away from it.

—Order! The member for North Sydney will resume his seat. The debate has just degenerated into a conversation between the member for North Sydney, the member for Longman, the member for Werriwa and the member for Dobell.
—I am worried about Nepean hospital.

—The member for Werriwa knows better than what he is doing right now. The member for Dobell has an obligation to address his remarks more directly through the chair. Does the member for North Sydney still wish to take a point of order?

interject.speaker: HOCKEY

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.

interject.para:
Mr Cadman interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Members have rights. It is not a matter of your extending goodwill. Members have rights in this chamber, and you cannot tell me whether or not I can speak.
—Try me.
—Order! The member for North Sydney will resume his seat.
—That is a threat, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—The member for Dobell will resume his seat. The member for Mitchell knows better than to interject whilst out of his seat. The member for North Sydney was seeking my call.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The member for Dobell said that I said there was no allocated—
—Is this a point of order?
—It is a point of order. The member for Dobell has been misrepresenting what I have been saying. It is wrong to say—
—The member for North Sydney will resume his seat. That is not a point of order. If he claims to have been misrepresented, there are other forms of the House that he can pursue.

—Thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I will attempt to resist the temptation to reply to interjections. This government has cut back federal funding for public hospitals in two ways. First of all, we had the fiasco of the Premiers Conference where the Treasurer (Mr Costello) cut back federal funding for the states through the financial assistance grants by $1.5 billion over the next three years.

speech.para: Even if the state expenditures on health only cop a pro rata reduction in their funding, that $1.5 billion reduction in the financial assistance grants to the states will not only make worse that vertical fiscal imbalance but also mean that there will be a reduction in state spending on health, using the pro rata measurement, of $450 million. In addition, in the budget papers the government is saying that, because of cost shifting from the states to the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth is going to clearly take back a further $313 million from federal funding for state public hospitals over the next four years.

talk.start.para: —That is a total misrepresentation.

—The member for Longman interjects and says it is a total misrepresentation. I suggest the member for Longman read the budget papers. That $313 million is there for everyone to see, and even your own Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) referred to it in question time yesterday.

—Go back and read
Hansard
.

—Yes, go back and read
Hansard
. As a result of the Howard government's decisions, there are reductions to public hospital federal funding, and it is probably also in the electorate of the member for Longman. So $450 million has been lost to public hospitals as a result of the reductions in the financial assistance grants and the $313 million reduction is allegedly because of cost shifting.

break.para: Let us have a look at this argument of cost shifting. It is true that, as state governments have put pressure on local hospitals and on area health services, there has been cost shifting. In many cases, public hospitals have had to cost shift just to keep beds open in all states. Despite the fact that day after day in our newspapers, on radio and on television we are seeing the consequences of the pressures on public hospitals, you are saying there is too much money in our public hospitals. You are saying that you are going to use this excuse of cost shifting to further reduce federal funding for public hospitals by $313 million in this budget alone. That reduction will only make the problems worse. Whether or not there has been cost shifting, if you reduce the federal funding for public hospitals, that will only make the problems worse.

This reduction of a total of $800 million over the next four years is equivalent to the government's cutting back 1,000 beds across the country. It is equivalent to the government's stopping 66,000 operations across the country. It is no wonder that the waiting lists will get longer and the waiting times for casualty and emergency will be longer. Ultimately, people's lives are placed at risk if we cannot expect to get a reasonable standard of care and treatment in our public hospitals.

During the last four years of the Labor government in particular, under various health ministers the federal funding for state public hospitals actually increased. But, unfortunately, as the federal funding went up under Labor, I regret to say that state conservative governments were cutting back their funding for public hospitals. The worst offender was Victoria where we had federal Labor increase the funding by $200 million and Mr Kennett, the Premier of Victoria, cut back the state funding for public hospitals by even more—by $275 million.

That is the real reason that we have people like the Director of Emergency Services at St Vincents in Melbourne saying that people, after going to a casualty ward, are getting inhuman treatment by being forced to wait for more than three days before even getting admitted to a bed at St Vincents. This is the
direct result of Liberal state governments cutting back their state effort.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I will just quote you the figures as I know that you are very interested in these statistics. Mr Kennett, as I mentioned, reduced his funding by more than $260 million to $270 million. Even the Premier of South Australia, Dean Brown, cut back that state's funding for public hospitals by $66 million. In Western Australia, Richard Court reduced their government's funding for public hospitals by $160 million.

In contrast, in New South Wales, despite the fact—as I accept—they do not have a perfect system, they increased the funding by $600 million over the last two years. If every state government put in as much effort and funding, extra effort and extra funding as New South Wales has in the last two years, we should be seeing an improvement in the quality of public hospitals across the country.

Whatever effort the states make—we do not control state governments; we are here to decide what the Commonwealth government does—my concern today is that, while federal Labor was increasing federal funding for public hospitals, you have headed in the opposite direction. You are cutting back in this budget federal funding for state public hospitals by $800 million. That means that people will suffer and are at risk of dying because there will not be the beds, there will not be the qualified staff, there will not be the effort in public hospitals right across the country.

People opposite may say, `Well, it's due to the economic pressures, due to the fact that we want to get the budget into surplus; we cannot afford to do what people such as the Labor Party are saying.' Let us just test that argument.

The government in this budget is providing $1.7 billion in a new tax break for private health insurance. Despite the fact that it is a shambles—we have had the health funds increase their premiums so that almost all of the tax rebate has gone—the government says that they can afford $1.7 billion in this tax break for private health insurance.

You really have to ask whether providing a tax break for the industry was the right way to address the problem. Rather than giving $1.7 billion to private health insurance, perhaps the government should have considered whether it would have been better to give that $1.7 billion directly to public hospitals across the country. Perhaps that was the best way to address the most serious problems in our health system. I certainly believe that it is too late to try to stop the $1.7 billion tax break, because that would only penalise the patients and contributors.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I inform the deputy whip that, if the Government Whip had not provoked me and tried to stand over me, I would have finished a few minutes ago. But, having been provoked, I will finish my speech.

The point I make is that people should really be asking whether, in spending 13 years in opposition drafting their health policy, those opposite should have given some thought to whether the money would have been better spent by directly improving federal funding for public hospitals. Those opposite said that this tax break would make a fundamental difference. But, if it is just a tax break for the private health insurance industry, perhaps we should have directed that money directly at public hospitals.

Then there is the second argument, `Well, we have to get the budget into surplus.' This is an argument that has been pursued very severely by the Victorian state government. A week or two ago that government brought down its state budget and claimed that it had a terrific set of figures, that the budget is going back into surplus. Yet almost in the same week—as I am sure the people in the gallery will remember—there were stories on the front page of the Melbourne
Age
every day about people not being able to get access to casualty and emergency in the great public hospitals in that state.

para.break: I think the day is coming when people will ask: what is more important—the size of the surplus or the quality of our public hospitals? Is it a good reflection on the government of Victoria that they might have the best state surplus of any of the states of the Common wealth, but they will end up with the reputation of having the worst quality of care in public hospitals? My view is that it is time we looked at the level of federal and state funding for public hospitals right across the country.

break.para: I would like to finish by making the point that this whole debate about the level of federal funding for public hospitals will be something that we will continue to bring up in the public debate. We had the minister for health in question time yesterday alleging that New South Wales was the `worst offender'—and they were his words—in cost shifting for the Commonwealth. The member for North Sydney nods his head in agreement, not realising that what that means is that the minister for health has got New South Wales public hospitals in the target sights. The minister for health, in saying that he believes New South Wales is the worst offender, is giving a clear signal to every public hospital in New South Wales that federal funding will be reduced even further.

As this government thinks that New South Wales is the `worst offender', I would challenge it to go out to Nepean Hospital, Mount Druid Hospital or Westmead Hospital and tell the staff, the patients and the people who live in western Sydney that their public hospitals have too much money. What is really happening is that this government is seeking to penalise public hospitals in New South Wales because New South Wales has the hide to elect a Labor government. That is what they are doing.

Yesterday's statement by the minister for health that he will be targeting New South Wales, penalising New South Wales, is something that I think should send a very clear warning bell to patients and the staff at public hospitals right across New South Wales. For all these reasons, we have real concerns about what this government has done and we will be pursuing these issues for many days to come.

Mr MILES
(Braddon—Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (11.06 a.m.)—Listening to the debate, particularly from opposition members, one becomes very much aware of the fact that apparently
something happened on 2 March, and everything prior to that they have forgotten about—absolutely forgotten about. They now come in here and are still talking about ideas of pushing up the debt and the deficit in this country.
What really happened on 2 March was that the Australian people decided that the previous government with its incompetence had to be changed, as did the debt which had been run up by the previous government.

We will just go back to that $70 billion figure. I find it absolutely amazing for members of the opposition to come in here saying, `Well, there's this money which is being dragged out of the public health system,' when in actual fact the interest on the money that the previous government ran up in bills in the last four years was $7 billion. And that $7 billion is now not available to the Australian people to put into health, to put into education, to put into crime protection, and so on—$7 billion!—and those members of the opposition come in here whingeing.

That is the legacy that people like the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and other opposition members who are in here at the present time left this present government. But they are now in here saying, `We can forget about the history'—the absolute debacle that occurred in the last four or five years under Labor in this country. They can complain about that.

The one thing that is certain, though, is that this government understands that Australia has got a problem. The problem was not caused by us, but we will take the responsibility of doing something about it. That is exactly what it is about.

There has been a great defence about the public sector of the Australian community by a number of members from the opposition. The public sector does have an important role, but I note that the member for Werriwa, in a book entitled
Reviving Labor's agenda
, says:
. . . the public sector in Australia only survives by virtue of government authority and monopoly.
This is his quote.

talk.start.para: —No, that is out of context. Read the full thing.
—I quote it, page 25. I will just repeat it for everybody because they have been in here saying, `The public sector has got to grow. That is the way to keep Australia healthy.'
—You are reading half a sentence in a paragraph.
—Yet he says:

break.para: . . . the public sector in Australia only survives by virtue of government authority and monopoly.
In other words, he is against any competition. Are you for competition or are you against it?

talk.start.para: —Government authority—that's self-evident.
—Are you for competition?
—I am for you reading the full quote.

—Are you for competition or are you against it? What you are saying is that the public sector does not function very effectively. That is what you are really saying, aren't you? You are saying it only survives by government authority and because it is a monopoly.
—You're a good Christian—read the full quote.
—I just find it very interesting that we have got—
—Order! I might just interrupt this conversation. The parliamentary secretary might direct his remarks through the chair and the honourable member for Werriwa might stop interjecting.

—I find it very interesting that members of the opposition come in here and believe that nothing ever happened before 2 March this year because they want to forget about it. They do not want that talked about any more because of the absolute debacle that occurred.

break.para: It was their mismanagement of this economy that caused the problems. We recognise that there are problems and the Australian people recognise that there are problems. We did not cause the problems, but we will take responsibility for fixing the problems.

The opposition continues to peddle the line that you can run the Australian economy into
debt and into deficit and into more debt and more deficit. It has no interest in future generations of young Australians. It just piles up the debt and leaves it to the future generations to pay it off in future years. Of course, it does not want to hear these sorts of things, but that is the nature of the situation that this government has faced. We will do something about it. We are taking measures to address the Australian economy in a very positive way and this legislation is part of doing that.

I want to make a few comments about Tasmania because the member for Denison (Mr Kerr) raised some things about my own state in regard to the Tasmanian package. He said, in regard to passenger equalisation—a very good initiative by this government in regard to Tasmania—that we promised that we would provide $49 million and that has been reduced in this budget. Well, that is not true. The reality is that, depending on the number of passengers who go across Bass Strait, they will be funded under this equalisation scheme. It might even go above $49 million. Who knows? It depends on the amount of traffic going across the strait.

He also claimed that freight equalisation had been cut. The premise of that comment is: if there is no freight going across, you still have to pay freight equalisation. What a ludicrous suggestion by the member for Denison. The fact is: if freight is going across the strait and it is eligible for the equalisation, it will be paid.

Another comment he made was about the wheat equalisation scheme. He said that this is going to raise the price of bread. There have been estimates by a range of people saying how much per tonne it might cause the price of wheat going into my state to rise. On the upper end of the scale, they are saying $14 a tonne and on the lower end of the scale it is about $6 to $7 a tonne.

Even if it were the higher end of the scale, that would mean a 1.4c increase per kilogram. I am not sure whether that is really of great significance to the overwhelming majority of people. When you calculate it out and think about it, it is a very small change. The fluctuations in the price of wheat is $70 to $80 a
tonne, so any change in this area is going to be quite small.

He also claimed that the direct reduction in jobs in Tasmania would be around about 1,000 people with an indirect reduction of maybe 6,000 to 8,000. Tasmania has an economy that is quite strong. This government has taken measures which will certainly help underpin that economy.

One of the measures that is very important is the decision about forestry. Under the previous Labor government, forestry had no security and no stability right throughout Australia and Tasmania where it is a major part of the economy. This government has now moved to ensure that there is security and stability in that very important industry to our state.

Not only that, in regard to the passenger equalisation scheme, you will find that, with more people travelling across Bass Strait, that will be beneficial to the state. There are a lot of people in Tasmania, Victoria and other states who have found this measure, which was adopted by this government, to be very beneficial. I am sure that that will be beneficial to the Tasmanian economy.

There are a few general points which have been made, and I would like to comment on the fiscal contribution by the states. In regard to the fiscal contribution by the states, the opposition would like to say, `Well, this decision of the states having to agree to a certain amount of money is outrageous.' But in actual fact it was an agreement worked out between the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) of the Commonwealth and the state Premiers.

talk.start.para: —Including Bob Carr.
—Including a Labor state Premier. So these agreements go on regularly between the Commonwealth and the states. They agreed upon that.
—With a gun at their head.

—What are you saying? Are you saying that the Premier of New South Wales is weak? The member for Werriwa obviously is saying that the Premier has no power and very few bargaining skills. I guess what the member for Werriwa is actually
saying is that the Premier is a poor negotiator and that he is very weak. That is what the member for Werriwa is actually saying. So the fiscal contribution is not something which was rammed down their throats by the Commonwealth. It was actually something that was agreed to by the states.

break.para: In regard to the specific purpose payments at the Premiers Conference, they were told that there was going to be a three per cent maximum. In the 1996‐97 budget it was 2.5 per cent, and that is a nominal increase on 1995-96.

We oppose the amendment which was moved by the member for Werriwa. I would like to thank all members who have made a contribution to this debate. Quite a number of members contributed to the debate. It was a wide ranging debate. I would just like to note that the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) is in the chamber at this stage and that his last speech to the House was a valuable contribution, as were many speeches of other members from the government side. As I said, we oppose the amendment which has been proposed by the member for Werriwa. I commend the bill to the House.

para.tab:
That the words proposed to be omitted (
Mr Latham's
amendment) stand part of the question.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

break.para: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.

proctext.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

debate.title:
INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT (FAMILY TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996
Cognate bill:
FAMILY (TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996

proctext.para:
Debate resumed from 11 September, on motion by
Mr Costello
:
That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Evans, Gareth, MP

talk.start.para: —The Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill represents in a sense, I suppose, the jewel in the coalition's crown, the centrepiece of the election campaign, the famous family tax initiative. Unfortunately for Australian families, however, this initiative is being delivered as part of the most family unfriendly budget that has been seen in this parliament for at least 15 years. I say that because, as we on this side of the House know, and as the Australian community is becoming increasingly aware, this budget takes from families in a whole variety of ways a lot more than it gives to them through this initiative.

speech.para:
What the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is putting into one pocket with this measure, to
which so much attention was given during the election campaign, he and his Treasurer (Mr Costello) are busily engaged in taking out of the other pocket of just about every family in this country as a consequence of the combination of the changes to, in particular, child care, pharmaceutical benefit charges, higher education charges and the reduction in a number of ways of support for the elderly, which is an increasing responsibility of so many families in our country.

The family tax initiative puts into people's pockets $3.85 a week for each dependent child, with an extra $9.60 a week being available if the family has a child under five, with couples only being eligible for this additional payment, however, if the second partner earns no more than $4,500 a year. The family tax payments are means tested. Families only receive the basic payment if their taxable income is less than $70,000, plus $3,000 for each child after the first.

It is important to appreciate that the extra payment for children under five is only paid if the main breadwinner's income is less than $65,000 together with the $3,000 for each child after the first child. I make the point about those various constraints and limitations because I do not think it is widely understood that only a relatively limited number of families in this country will benefit from the second part of the initiative, that is, the availability of the extra $9.60 a week for a child under five where one of the partners is only earning a minimal income. Only 13 per cent at most of Australian families will benefit from that part of the proposal. In order to demonstrate that, I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
a table, small graph or chart making it clear how that calculation is derived.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —A small further point to make by way of introduction, I suppose, is that instead of providing a rebate for this amount the legislation takes the rather unusual step for those families who are paying tax of adjusting the income tax-free threshold by $1,000 for each dependent child under the first part of the concession and by $2,500 if the family has a child under five years old. This has the same effect as providing a rebate. For some reason the government has taken the unusual step of putting it up as a tax free threshold change. I presume that is to reduce the comparison with the much more generous family taxation rebates which applied under Labor, such as the spouse rebate, the sole parent rebate, the housekeeper rebate and the child component of the zone rebate, just for a start.

break.para: All that being said about the nature of the proposal now before us, I think it is also important to appreciate in understanding its significance that the form in which it comes before us very much represents a retreat by the government on the proposal as it was originally crafted and publicised. The Treasurer's second reading speech alludes to the fact that the coalition took a family tax package to the election. It certainly did, but it is not the package that is before this parliament.

The proposal that was announced during the election campaign was different from that before us in a very significant respect, one that made it a very fundamentally flawed proposal. The way in which it was unfair was the spousal income test that was contained in the proposal previously publicised. A family was to be excluded from any benefit at all in relation to the second part of the payment if the non-breadwinning spouse earned any income at all from part-time work.

You could have a process worker husband and a wife doing maybe no more than two hours on a Friday night in a supermarket checkout earning just a few hundred or a few thousand dollars in the course of the year, but that would be enough to exclude that family completely from the eligibility that it would otherwise have had for the payment. At the same time, if the income received by the non-
breadwinner was in the form of unearned income, income from investments and the like and not actual labour, then you could earn up to $20,700 by that means and still qualify for the additional payment. It was an outrageous proposal. It was exposed by Labor as a rort. It would have meant, for example, that families with around $300,000 in net investable assets would have been able to qualify for the concession even though much poorer families with the breadwinner just working a few hours a week part-time would have been excluded.

I am pleased to be able to say that, due to the pressure that has been applied by us on this issue, the government has relented and has introduced as the appropriate income test for the non-breadwinner spouse the level that is applicable for the parenting allowance. That is a much fairer test as it only allows $4,500 in income to be earned but, more importantly, because it makes no distinction at all between the type of income that is earned, it does not discriminate in the way that was the case previously against low income families where both parents have to work. It does not unfairly favour high wealth families where one partner is earning a substantial income from investments.

I make it clear that, had the proposal come before the parliament in the form in which it was publicised during the election campaign, we would certainly have sought to amend it to reflect what is now in fact contained in this particular bill. I do acknowledge the fact that the government has made the amendment. The fact that they have done so and incorporated it in the bill now before us means that the opposition can support the measure, and I indicate that we will do so.

The measure, however, is not going to get off scot-free in terms of criticism by us, the main point of that criticism being, as I intimated at the outset, that it is given on the one hand but in many ways taken away again by a variety of other measures that are contained in this particular budget.

The budget itself, it should be said at the outset, is one that has many flaws. This is not the occasion to spell them all out in detail. I just simply say again for the record that the
basic flaws are these: first of all, the whole strategy underlying the budget of a massive contractionary impact on the economy, focusing all the emphasis on deficit reduction and giving no priority at all to growth in employment—in fact, putting together a series of slashes and burns and cuts and draconian revenue measures which will take about half a per cent of growth out of the economy—is exactly the wrong strategy to be applying overall in the context of the economic problems of this country as they now exist.

The only real substantial economic problem Australia has at the moment is the problem of unemployment—utterly unacceptable at 8½ per cent, or more than that now, and not only a tremendous need for the economy to grow fast enough to be able to jog along at the existing unacceptable rate but also a desperate need to bring that rate down. The whole philosophy of the budget in not putting growth in employment first is fundamentally flawed. It is justified by reference to talk of a fiscal crisis in Australia, the need to engage in these hairshirt measures and the need to inflict this pain because of some greater good for the economy as a whole. All of this serves to make people feel virtuous, I suppose, when they are bearing pain, but it is utterly unnecessary pain.

There are many ways of making that point. I do so on this occasion quickly and simply by saying that the best way of understanding Australia's situation and understanding that we are not in crisis is to compare our situation so far as debt and deficit are concerned with that which prevails internationally. The truth of the matter is that we have the third lowest budget deficit in the industrialised world. We have the fourth lowest government debt of all those countries in the industrialised world. We amply satisfy the tests of good economic management that have been identified by the European Union as the criteria for joining that particular monetary union being proposed in that part of the world. By any standard the Australian economy is fundamentally in sound shape so far as those issues are concerned. There is no justification for the assault that is being launched upon the economy and, in particular, the lack of hope that
is involved for the jobless as a result of the whole budget strategy.

Beyond that there are many other things that can be said about this budget. The promise breaking that is involved in it and the deception of the Australian community is really quite breathtaking: something over 25 major deliberately given promises explicitly broken and scores of lesser ones. We have estimated over $17 billion worth of broken promises in this budget. For every dollar's worth of promises that have been kept in the budget there is $2.25 worth of promises that have been broken. The gloss on Honest John Howard, I think, has well and truly worn off as a result of this little excursion, and that is a point that we will be making many times in the future.

talk.start.para: —Jobless Johnny.

—Honest John has become Jobless Johnny, as I am appropriately reminded by the shadow minister for trade. The third basic flaw in this budget—and one that we will be pointing to on every occasion that we rise to speak about it—is the assault that it makes on the unemployed and the assault that it makes on pensioners and so many other categories of disadvantaged Australians. It is an assault which is made even more cruel, even more disgraceful, when one takes into account that it is all so desperately unnecessary. As the product of an ideological passion for small government, it is not a product of economic management necessity.

break.para:
We will be making the point—this bill is a very appropriate context in which to make it—that this budget involves a quite fundamental deception of middle Australia. It is not only wrong‐headed in its economic strategy, it is not only full of promise breaking and deception to Australians at large and it is not only full of unnecessary pain and assaults on the disadvantaged; it involves a very fundamental deception of middle Australia, mainstream Australia—the people for whom this budget was meant to be crafted, the audience to whom this budget was primarily directed. The nature of that deception of middle Australia becomes clear, I think, when you start looking systematically—layer by layer, item
by item, issue by issue—at all the other measures in this budget that hack away at the income of mainstream Australian families.

One element, of course, of the deception of middle Australia that is involved in this budget that has become a matter of absolute notoriety in the last two or three weeks is the treatment of the private health insurance incentives. We have already seen the reality becoming starkly clear when, whatever prima facie return there might have been for families in this particular measure, it is being immediately eroded by the behaviour of the health funds in increasing their fees and doing so in a way which has made the government look both clumsy and incompetent, and impotent as well, in a way which has opened up a dramatic gap between the Prime Minister and his own Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), which has shown a mutual lack of confidence between the two of them starkly exposed on the floor of this House, but in a way which, most importantly of all, has created a situation where any conceivable benefit for Australian families in these particular incentives, in these rebates, is totally eroded. Some families in New South Wales, for example, face increases of $306 a year in their private health fund contributions, and that will totally wipe out the $250 rebate for couples and erode by two‐thirds the $450 rebate for families with dependent children.

Apart from that deception, there are other deceptions throughout the whole budget structure. One of them, on which the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) will very appropriately spend some time, is the deception that is involved in not bringing to the attention of mainstream Australian families the way in which the operation of the tax system will erode a significant proportion of the benefits that are flowing to families through the phenomenon of fiscal drag. That is to say, as family incomes slowly rise—and they are rising more slowly than they used to because inflation is very much lower—people move into higher tax brackets, a greater amount of tax is drawn from them and they have less disposable income, obviously, as a result. When you do the arithmetic of how that phenomenon is likely to work itself out over
