the next three years, you can see a very dramatic erosion of a number of the purported benefits that are contained in this particular family tax initiative.

The biggest deception of all is the one that is involved in pretending to middle Australia, families with children, that they are going to be substantially better off as a result of this family tax package. When you take into account all the other measures that are impacting on families in this particular budget, the impossibility of sustaining that argument and the fraudulent character of that argument become starkly apparent. Let me spend just a few moments going through the main categories of impact on families that are contained in the other parts of the budget. For a start, take child care. Maximum child‐care assistance is going to be frozen for the next two years but fees, of course, will continue to increase and the value of that assistance will erode as a result. The child‐care assistance ceiling will be capped and the $30 income disregard for each dependent child will also be abolished, reducing thereby child‐care assistance payments.

Most families with children in formal care will certainly lose more from these changes in child‐care assistance than they gain from the family tax initiative. A family with two children in long day care for 50 hours a week, on an annual income of just under $30,000, will pay $19.60 extra per week. The same family earning $45,500 per year will pay $15.30 extra per week in child‐care fees. In addition to that basic problem with the child‐care increases, you have families with children in community based, long day care centres having to pay substantially higher fees following the abolition of the operating subsidy. EPAC has estimated that that operating subsidy is worth $21.40 per week for children under three. For children older than three, it is $14.35 per week. There is every reason to believe that fees in the community child‐care centres will rise by just that amount, dramatically and instantaneously eroding as a result any value that might be thought to flow from the family tax initiative.

Then, of course, you have the increases in the pharmaceutical benefit charges. The
Howard‐Costello government has increased the price of pharmaceuticals covered by the PBS system by up to 20 per cent. Most of the drugs that doctors prescribe are covered by the PBS. The situation now exists where the charge that many families will have to contemplate for particular drugs goes up an extra $2.60, to $20. You can be forced to pay out. As everyone knows, kids tend to get sick at the same time. Often the caring parent gets sick as well. If you had three kids, that can be $60 in one go for scripts. That is a real situation, a real world—not a fanciful, exaggerated one—and one that all families are now going to have to contemplate facing as a result of this. In addition, concession card holders are going to have to pay an extra 50c a script, and without any compensating increase in the pensions that we have always sought to make available in the past to compensate for any necessary increases in that area. And so it goes on.

So far as Medicare and health care generally are concerned, we now have a situation where bit by bit we will see the erosion and slow, grinding assault on Medicare that we saw from Mr Howard when he had a chance to get to work on Medibank back in the seventies and slaughtered that particular innocent as a result. We are seeing that now at work. One of the biggest benefits of Medicare, as everyone in the community appreciates, is that many doctors are prepared to bulk‐bill their patients. We now have a situation where this government has decided that the Medicare schedule, which in simple terms says how much money is paid by the government to the doctor, will not be indexed for inflation this year. It is the case—the signs from the medical profession are already very apparent—that a great many doctors will now decide, with increasing numbers in this category as the situation works itself out over the years ahead, that it is no longer worth bulk‐billing. If these doctors charge their patients the AMA recommended fee, patients who used to be bulk‐billed could right now have to pay up to $10 per consultation out of their own pockets.

Then, of course, for low income families and those in receipt at least of health care
cards or pension cards, you have the scrapping of the Commonwealth dental program, which is one of the nastiest, most disgraceful and cruelest of the measures in the entire budget package.

All Australians, including mainstream, middle Australians, will feel the effects of the very large funding cuts to public hospitals which are contained in this budget. We have a situation over the next four years where the government is planning to directly take well over $300 million out of public hospitals with reductions in the general assistance grants going to the states, making that total cut much more likely to be of the order of $800 million. What that means is more pressure on services, longer waiting lists and, again, financial pressure on a great many mainstream Australian families.

Home and community care is something that we increasingly associate with families who have to look after elderly parents or in‐laws. It is not just a problem for pensioners or people living alone. The home and community care program has been very significantly funded by the Commonwealth government to provide a range of services for frail elderly and, for that matter, frail young people living at home—home nursing, home maintenance, meals on wheels, respite care, day centre care and so on. Now we have a situation where there will be reduced funding for those services and increased user charges required to fill the gap amounting to some $6.30 per hour. As a result, a pensioner using three hours a week or so of HACC services—which seems to be the norm around the country—will have to pay up to $18.90 a week, nearly $1,000 a year, in increased user charges; again, part of the burden that in a great many instances is not just falling on specific disadvantaged groups but falling on the families of whom those groups or individuals are a part.

Turning to nursing homes, the subject of a lot of discussion in this parliament this week—and I can promise there will be a lot more in the weeks ahead—older Australians and their families in turn will be dramatically hit by the introduction of up-front entry fees of nursing homes. It is true, and it is frankly
acknowledged, that there will be some places, as there always have been in the past, in both nursing homes and hostels for those with no assets or minimal assets. But, as we all know, there is dramatically increasing pressure upon nursing home places as the proportion of the population which is aged ever increases and the number of people seeking access to those nursing home services continues to significantly increase.

There is a market out there. There is a shortage and markets generate a situation where people respond to it by making the appropriate charges. The truth of the matter is that it is the government's own calculation that the average nursing home entry fee that will be charged will be exactly the same order of magnitude as the entry fee now being charged to hostels with the amalgamation, the assimilation, of the two systems. That is to say that the average will be $26,000. In a great many cases it will be much more than that.

If a resident stays for more than six months, only part of this entry payment will be refunded when the resident leaves the nursing home. In the meantime, the interest on that particular capital sum thus invested will go to the nursing home. The government has conspicuously failed to give a guarantee—it cannot give a guarantee—that no nursing home residents or their spouses will have to sell their homes to pay the new up-front fees. The truth of the matter is that that is the way the market pressure will work. It will happen.

In addition to the new entry fees, nursing home patients will also have to pay a new means tested daily fee of up to $34. Pensioners with private incomes as low as $50 a week will now have to pay fees. All of these things amount to stress, financial stress, not just on the pensioners themselves, those seeking immediate access to the homes, but on the families who support them.

In very many instances, this is not a matter of individual budgeting arrangements; it is matter of family budgeting arrangements. It is utterly reasonable to regard these measures as trade-offs to be weighed in the balance when one is trying to make sense of just how much
it is worth to ordinary families to have this particular family tax initiative paid to them.

Yet another major impost or set of burdens or charges that are now being faced by mainstream Australian families is that of higher education costs—costs flowing from the changes in the eligibility rules for Austudy. But even more immediately worrying in their impact for a great many families are the changes to HECS funding. The fees will now have to be paid at much higher levels and at a much earlier stage of the graduate's earning career.

It is all very well to say, as the government constantly does, that this is not a problem for families, that it is only an issue for the individual student who is coming through the system and, by definition, he or she ought to be able to pay. But the truth of the matter is that families look at these issues as a whole. They do make decisions. Families want to support their kids going on to higher education.

Particularly as the fees are now getting so high—up to $30,000 for someone doing law, for example, without any guarantee that they will have any kind of a serious income earning capacity of that order of magnitude after they are finished their course—families do sit down together and make judgments together about what the family household, as a whole, can afford to pay by way of these fees, by way of the burdens that are involved. That is seen, already it is being seen, right around the community as a massive disincentive—a massive additional financial impost upon families.

Cuts to state government services are a more insidious way but a very intrusive way at the end of the day in which again this budget is going to impact on ordinary families. There has been a massive cut in Commonwealth funding to the states. More is yet to come. I have already spoken of that impact in the context of hospital funding, but there are many other ways in which the implications of this will bear upon, impact upon, ordinary families.

New South Wales has already had to introduce what it has called the Howard‐Costello tax, which will increase payroll tax,
land tax and stamp duties on motor vehicles. The Victorian government, which has the highest tax burden in the country, has had to delay reducing taxes because of the Commonwealth government's broken promises, budget induced, concerning state funding. As Mr Stockdale, the Victorian Treasurer, put it the other day:

These burdens flow through to State taxpayers and they'll have to fund these burdens, and Mr Costello is taxing them by stealth in flagrant breach of his election commitment, upon which he was elected with an overwhelming mandate by the people.

I still have not come to the end of the list. For example, labour market programs will be slashed and cut—the jobskill programs, the jobtrain programs and skillshare programs, all those programs that assist those who are unemployed to acquire the right sort of confidence, the right sort of skills, the right kind of training and the right kind of job readiness to get back into the work force.

This, again, is something that is not just an issue which affects some group of people out there somewhere remote and distant from mainstream Australia. The truth of the matter is that middle Australia is, unhappily, increasingly jobless Australia. It is families, adult members of families and kids growing up who are those in need of the sort of assistance here which has been so dramatically cut, and the income reduction associated with a cut in a number of these programs is yet another thing to weigh in the balance.

I have made the point—it will be made many times in the course of this budget debate—about the dishonesty, the mindlessness and the unfairness of this budget and the unnecessary nature of the pain that is being caused. An absolutely crucial element is this constant theme of deception—deception in the promise breaking at large and a very specific form of deception of middle Australia in this absolute unwillingness to make clear the reality of the competing burden. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1)
notes that only a limited proportion of family types receive the full benefits of the so‐called Family Tax Initiative;

(2)
expresses its concerns that other Budget measures leave the average Australian family substantially worse off;

(3)
notes with concern that the Government is only returning to PAYE taxpayers a small proportion of bracket creep/fiscal drag revenue collections via this Bill; and

(4)
expresses its concern that this and other Budget‐related measures have established very high Effective Marginal Tax Rates for non‐working parents returning to the workforce".

talk.start.para: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

speech.speaker: Brough, Mal, MP

talk.start.para: —The greatest deception that has been played on the Australian people has been played by those opposite. We have just heard 30 minutes of absolute claptrap by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans). The greatest deception played on the Australian people was that the Labor Party were not prepared to tell us the situation in the books of this nation. They hid it from us. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) was a prime player in that. At the end of the day, it is Australians that are paying the penalty for Labor's mismanagement over 13 years.

speech.para: Let us look on the bright side. New Year's Day 1997 will be a particularly happy day for thousands of Longman families because the Liberal‐National government tax cuts for low and middle income Australian families will be delivered. That is very much in contrast to New Year's Day 1996. That was going to be a happy day for Australian families and Australian workers as well. The l-a-w tax cuts which were going to be brought in were our Clayton's tax cuts: the tax cut you have when you do not really have a tax cut. You talk about it and tell everyone about it, but at the end of the day you don't deliver. That is pretty much what we have seen from 13 years of Labor: talk about things and get people's hopes up but, for goodness sake, don't deliver.

This commitment to Australian families is recognition of the important role parents play in building today's communities and future
generations. For too long it has been middle Australia which has borne the brunt of the previous Labor government's high taxing policies. Until now there has been no recognition of the extra financial burden working parents carry. There have been no incentives for families to choose to have one of the parents care for the family in the home.

The focus throughout the 1980s and the 1990s was very much on DINKs—double income, no kids. No section of the community is any more important than any other and there should never be any undue attention given to one section of the society, particularly when it is at the cost of another. This initiative is designed to redress this balance. The time is well overdue for the government and the nation to recognise not only the expense of raising children but also the long-term social impact of having a strong family unit in this nation. This tax cut will put more cash into the pockets of working Australian families.

The Labor Party failed Australia. In particular, they failed middle and low income families, the very people they purport to represent. The Labor government saw an ever increasing need for the welfare state, which only detracted from the contribution of working families. It does not really reconcile with their rhetoric.

To better understand the failure of this previous government and to better understand the way they have come to their decisions in the past, I thought I could reflect upon some of the comments of the opposition spokesman, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), on 21 August, just one day after the budget in this House, when referring to this measure and referring to Australian families. I will give three examples.

First, she referred to a two‐income family with two dependent children. She referred to this particular family as having one income of $32,000, the motor mechanic husband, and another income of $35,000, that of the wife as a sales assistant. That is typecasting if ever I have seen it. Perhaps the wife should have been the motor mechanic. That gave that family an income of $67,000.

She then moved in her comments to Penrith, a topic which is dear to many people's
hearts at this stage. In this particular case she had a teacher earning $39,000 and a mother earning $36,000, for a total income of $75,000. The third example she gave was of a single income earner on $68,000.

The Labor Party's spokesman on the family referred to middle income earners receiving $67,000, $75,000 and $68,000 respectively. The reality of the situation is that the average family income in Australia today isn't $60,000, $50,000 or $40,000; it is $34,654. That is the average income of Australian families. It is nothing like the $60,000 and $70,000 she referred to when she discussed average Australian families. She must mix in much different circles from the people she claims to represent.

If you look at figures on the families in my electorate from the 1991 census, you see that the average family income there was only $28,593—a far cry from the $60,000 and $70,000 that the opposition spokesman mentioned. The fact is that 42 per cent of all families in the Longman electorate actually earned, as a total family income, less than $30,000. Those earning under $20,000 represented 25 per cent of Australian families. Yet she stood up in here and cried poor when she referred to families earning $60,000 and $70,000. I suggest to the member for Jagajaga that she get out in the real world, talk to real people and see what they earn. They will just laugh at the cases she raised in this place.

Let us look at what Labor did over the last four years under the former Prime Minister. The last four years has seen revenue to the federal government increase by a total of $28.1 billion. How does the government get revenue? There is only one way—tax. They rip it out of the pockets of Australian families. That is what they have been doing for 13 years, but they honed that skill to a fine art over the last four years. Add to that additional borrowings of $74 billion and the selling off of a couple of Australian assets, Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, predominantly overseas, raising another $8.7 billion.

para.break: Over the last four years, they raised an additional $110.8 billion. You would think, out of that, they would give something back to Australian families—just something. Any thing at all would be appreciated, but they got not a red razoo. Not a cent went back to Australian families. The then government continued to pull money out by putting on additional sales tax and creating new sales taxes. In their last budget they put up fuel tax, which impacts on middle income families as much as on anyone, by 5c and 7c a litre. They put up the price of an average car by increasing sales tax on cars. That obviously put them out of the price range of most families.

speech.para: That is the legacy of the Labor government. It just puts a lie to the fact that they have ever been concerned about Australian families, and their rhetoric totally flies in the face of reality.
I would like to read a quote at this point. It reads:
It—
the family—

is the source of national continuance; it has supplied the human material indispensable for the production of the means of subsistence; it provides for the replacement of the old and the dead, and is the sole guarantee for the redemption, in the future, of those obligations which previous and past generations have found it desirable to incur in order to enjoy the fullest obtainable measure of security, comfort and civilisation.

That quote is one that we could all take to heart and think about when we deliberate in this place on any number and range of bills. It was delivered by a fine former ALP Prime Minister, John Curtin. I think those opposite would do well to put it up in their party room and have a read of it each morning so that they can refocus on the needs of the Australian family as opposed to what they have been doing. They no longer consider themselves responsible for the continuation of the national interest by looking after Australian families.

I think everybody in this place over the past election campaign would have had the comment made to them from Australian workers and families, particularly low and middle income earners, that they would be better off on the dole—`Why bother working? I would be better off if I threw the job in and I went on the unemployment benefit.' The fact is that
a family of five—husband and wife and three children—will receive approximately $1,000 from social security. I do not deride that—that is a very important safety net that is in place for Australian families that are unemployed—but the problem is that a metalworker who is on the current award wage is less than $100 a week gross better off than the unemployed person. That is before you take into account his work related expenses, his tools, his cost of getting to and from work and his clothing, not to mention his exorbitant union fees, which very often do not actually repay him anything in real kind.

The point I want to make is that this tax initiative—giving money back to Australian families—ensures that this government recognises the importance that these people play in contributing to Australia's improving productivity, and the role that they play as parents is important. We recognise it and we feel that it is important that they continue that role. We do not want to see Australians take the easy option that some people see of going on unemployment benefits. It does not set the right role model for Australians, it does not set a role model for their children and it obviously reduces productivity.

Let us have another look at what the Labor Party has done in its time here. Back in 1982-83—they came to power in 1983—the average Australian working family had a tax take of 14.1 per cent; 14.1 per cent of their money went into consolidated revenue. By the time they had left, through PAYE tax obviously, it had grown to 16 per cent. These are the people who can least afford to take that extra money out of their pocket and have it delivered to the government. They need it to survive. What we are trying to achieve here is in some measure to start to repay them and put some money back into their pockets through these tax initiatives.

As I mentioned earlier, these families also saw petrol prices rise through Mr Keating's hand in their pockets. The price of cars went up. He even tried to put up tax on building materials, which would have inevitably increased the price of the family home. Let us take that Australian dream totally out of the
possibility and the realm of them trying to achieve it.

What the Labor Party did in every instance was take from Australian families. They increased Medicare levies and they increased the threshold for pharmaceutical benefits, yet they come into this place screaming and yelling that we are being irresponsible. For once, Australian families have had something returned to them. I hope that it is only the first of a series of measures that this government, through fiscal management, will be able to put in place to respond to Australian families.

We come to the l-a-w tax cuts. A closer examination of those tax cuts really flies in the face of everything that Labor has ever spoken about. I will read the fundamental objectives of these tax scales as purported by Labor: first, to reduce the marginal tax rate facing the greater majority of the full‐time work force, including those on medium and average wages, from 38 per cent to 34 per cent; and, secondly, to reduce the marginal tax rate for those earning up to $50,000 per year, almost twice that of the family income of those in Longman, by 46 per cent to 40 per cent.

So what were the Labor Party going to give in their Clayton's tax cuts to the Australian family—the people in Longman who needed that money? If you earnt under $20,700 you could imagine that you would expect to receive something from a Labor government. The reality is that you did not receive a cent—zilch, zero, not one dollar! Not one dollar was to flow into the pockets of families or individuals earning under $20,700. In doing so, they immediately wrote off a great percentage of the families in my electorate and those throughout Australia. Who were they really representing? They certainly were not representing the people who work in my electorate.

I would also like to mention the accord, which was trumpeted back in 1983 when Prime Minister Hawke came to power. It was going to put some equity into the marketplace. It was going to allow these working Australians to benefit from an accord. If we look at a metalworker in that period from
1983 to 1995, their award has increased in that time by $119. If we compare it with a public servant on SES level 2, for argument's sake, who also benefited from the accord, you would imagine that his wage would have gone up by about the same amount. Labor likes to see things fairly. No. The reality is that the metalworker's wage increased by $119 and the public servant's went up by $513. That is a difference of $294 today in the hand of the metalworker opposed to this public servant.

That is not being equitable. That is not responding to average Australian families. That is why the rich got richer and the poor got poorer under Labor. Because we are bringing in a tax relief at the lowest level, impacting on all middle and low income families, we are responding to Australians' greatest needs.

In short, in 13 years Labor failed to deliver. It was as simple as that. We saw that on 2 March. But in reality that was played out just after the previous election. In the 1993 election Labor was as shocked as many Australians were when they were brought back to power, and the truth of the matter hit home. They had been deluded. The wool had been pulled over their eyes for the last time. The die had been cast. They no longer wanted to hear the rhetoric and the claptrap of `bringing home the bacon' and all the other fabulous comments and great figures that we heard from the previous Treasurer and Prime Minister.

The Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill, which does deliver money into Australian families' pockets, does two things. It delivers the cash which helps them on a day-to-day basis, and it also gives them an incentive from knowing that this government responds and respects the role that low and middle income families play in bringing up families and contributing to Australia's economic growth.

para.break: You would think that this was a new phenomenon and that the Labor Party would be pleased to hear it. But I wonder why it is that the member for Jagajaga, the opposition spokesman, has not chosen to even speak on this bill when it falls within her responsibil ity. You will not see her in here. It deals with families, I remind the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). Whenever she has the opportunity, she speaks long and loud in this parliament about families. Here is a tax matter which is going to go to the heart of helping Australian families, and she does not want to speak about it. She does not want to open her mouth. I can understand that; you would be pretty much appalled by the things that she is likely to say in trying to defend the pitiful amendments that she has moved to the second reading motion on this bill.

speech.para:
I would like to quote from a book called
A Fair Go for Families
, which was put out by the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission in, I think, 1989. It refers to the unfair taxation system which obviously was in place at the time. It says:

A simple method of moving towards a fairer taxation system for families would be to introduce additional tax thresholds in respect of dependents. This would recognise the additional minimum cost incurred by families with dependents.

What had the Labor government done about it in seven years? Not a damn thing—not one thing—because you do not really care about families, and you certainly do not care about low and middle income families.

I am proud to represent the electorate of Longman. We are not a wealthy electorate. In fact, the average income for Australian families in that electorate figures in the lower third of incomes of all electorates in Australia. We have hardworking families who just want to have a fair go. They want to be recognised for what they contribute to Australia. They want to be recognised for the fact that they contribute to the welfare of their families and that they set a standard and an example for their children to look up to.

In a very real way, this government has delivered on what it promised. It promised tax cuts to lower and middle income families and said that it would deliver them on 1 January 1997—and it will do so. That flies in the face of those opposite who promised tax cuts for 1 January 1996, never delivered on them and, instead, put in their place higher taxes. They have no mandate and have never had a mandate relating to assisting families. I look
to the future when this government can continue to support low and middle income families through responsible measures such as these and put money into the pockets of the most deserving in this nation.

speech.speaker: Latham, Mark, MP

talk.start.para:
—I recall the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) last year saying that the more politicians talk about the past, the more they demonstrate that they have no answers for the future. I think that anyone in the public gallery today, listening to this broadcast or subsequently reading the
Hansard
would appreciate that the member for Longman (Mr Brough) has no answers for the future, because he is obsessed with the past. I would have thought that a new member to this place, a new government representative, would have been talking about the government's strategy for families. In that regard, his argument has crumbled in his own hands.

speech.para: He is condemned by his own words because he said that the worst thing any government can do to families in Australia is to increase the take on PAYE tax collections. Yet that is what the government is doing in its 1996-97 budget. By his own words he has condemned the economic strategy of the Treasurer (Mr Costello). If he consults the revenue estimates in the budget, he will find that gross PAYE taxation revenue for 1996-97 is up by 8.3 per cent. It is up by a whopping $4.3 billion. Of that amount, the government can explain away 1.5 per cent in employment growth for the year average. It can explain away a forecast earnings growth of 4½ per cent. So six per cent of the 8.3 per cent comes in the form of nominal GDP growth.

What about the other 2.3 per cent? That is fiscal drag. It is bracket creep. This government is taking away a huge amount from working Australians, from gross PAYE, by kicking people into higher brackets without tax indexation. For all individuals, the amount gets even worse. The increase in taxation revenue for individuals for 1996-97 is $5½ billion. A lot of that is coming out of the electorate of Longman. The bracket creep within that category is a whopping $1.8 billion. Compare that to this very small amount for the family tax initiative, which is
part of the government's revenue measures. Page 119 of the budget papers says that the family tax initiative for 1996-97 is $147 million.

For the average family in the seats of Longman, Bonython, Werriwa, Warringah, and every other seat in the country, this means that for every dollar the government provides in its family tax initiative, it is taking away $8.30 in bracket creep through gross PAYE tax collections. As to tax on individuals, for every dollar the government provides in its family tax initiative it is taking away almost $13 extra in tax from individuals for 1996-97. So your families in Longman are going backwards under this government and this budget.

The member for Longman and his colleagues are condemned by their own words. This is a straight‐out tax swindle. For every $1 in this so-called family tax initiative, $13 is being swept away in bracket creep as people move into higher brackets in Longman and all the other electorates because this government will not introduce tax indexation.

This is a John Howard special—a tax promise, a fistful of dollars that he is handing over with one hand to rip back $13 with the other hand. He is giving $1 with one hand, but $13 is being ripped back out of the pockets of individual taxpayers in Australia with his other hand.

A lot of the members opposite are probably concerned about fiscal drag. I can imagine now the member for Braddon (Mr Miles) up in his room listening to this broadcast. He has heard me talk about fiscal drag in the budget. He probably thinks it is something that should be arrested. He is probably going to organise an anti-sodomy march down the main street of Burnie to do something about fiscal drag. He should do something about it. It does not take a march. It does not take the police arresting someone.

para.break: He should do something about it. He should be recommending at the Lyons Forum and standing up in other government forums saying, `This government should be fair dinkum and should be in the business of tax indexation.' It should not be here saying that it is introducing a so‐called family tax initia tive—$1 given in one hand and $13 taken back with the other. If you are serious about helping families in Australia, do not be in the business of a $5½ billion increase in taxation revenue, of a $2 billion net revenue increase in the budget over the next two years or of increasing tax as a proportion of GDP by 0.4 per cent.

speech.para: Again, the member for Longman was talking about the historical record, a period 10 to 15 years ago, when tax went up as a proportion of GDP. What is it for this budget? It is going up by nearly half a per cent of GDP, and it is happening in Longman and every other of the 147 federal electorates. You are condemned by your own words. I am sure the Treasurer is appalled to hear these things in the House of Representatives from a new government member. He is setting the criteria, setting the high jump bar, knowing full well the Treasurer has not even got off the landing mat. He is doing a sort of belly flop straight onto the landing mat because of the criteria set by his own colleague, the member for Longman.

These things need to be placed on the public record. They need to be understood by Australian families. The bottom line is, when they are filling out their tax returns some 12 months from now and they are looking at their rates, their brackets, and the very low level of return on this family tax initiative, they will know the impact. They will know the tax swindle. They will know fully the extent of the tax fraud. They will also understand that this government is more interested in hurting people than helping them.

This government is led by a Prime Minister more interested in telling Asian leaders what Australia is not instead of what Australia can be. This family tax initiative is more interested in what females in Australia should not be instead of what they can be. It is a bill conceived by the Lyons Forum, but it does not even have the virtues of consistency.

The member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) is sitting opposite. He was trumping around the House some 18 months ago the idea of a $6 billion flat, non means tested, so‐called homemakers allowance. He ran that through the Lyons Forum and it got knocked over. His
is not the worst case. For 20 years the member for Bennelong, the now Prime Minister, has been running around every public forum in Australia—Catholic welfare and family associations, anywhere they give him a microphone—talking about the virtues of income splitting. Whatever happened to income splitting? He has been committed to that idea for 20 years—a lifetime of political commitment to a concept—and he must have got knocked over in the Lyons Forum, such is their power.

They have come up with a poll driven, focus group tested increase in the tax threshold and its full benefits apply to only 13 per cent of Australian family types. For every $1 they provide in that initiative, they are ripping back $13 with the bracket creep. The Lyons Forum, for this measure and all the rhetoric from the other side, does not even have the virtue of consistency. I would have thought the member for Warringah, based on his past policy pronouncements, would be moving an amendment to introduce his $6 billion flat, non means tested, so-called homemakers allowance, but he is sitting there with a wry smile on his face. He knows that he got done over at the Lyons Forum.

No wonder the Prime Minister has gone overseas. He could not be here for the debate because after 20 years of personal commitment to income splitting, 20 years of staking his political reputation on that idea, he has been knocked over as well. So it is a sorry old day for the integrity and consistency of the coalition. It is a sorry old day, indeed, for Australian families because they have been misled by this lifelong commitment to income splitting to deliver a miserly $147 million family tax initiative in this budget, which rips back so much more in bracket creep and fiscal drag.

It is interesting that the Lyons Forum have developed these policies. I always find their name ironic. I think they take their name from Joe Lyons. He was perhaps Australia's most prolific Prime Minister ever. He had 12 children. He was prolific. He was a family man through and through.

I find it ironic that another Lyons served in this parliament, another Lyons who served in
the coalition government—that is, Enid Lyons. So much for the rhetoric that a woman's place is in the home. After the passing of her husband, Enid Lyons said that a woman's place was in the House—that is, the House of Representatives. She was the first female member in this House, and she did it as a widower. There was no white picket fence for Enid Lyons with the male working as the breadwinner for the family, the dependent children. There was no white picket fence for Enid Lyons. She had her working career as a widower with 12 dependent children.

So, for all the Lyons Forum rhetoric about their model family—the traditional nuclear family with a white picket fence in Australia—they have to appreciate the other side of the coin. That makes a very important point about family diversity. Since the time of Joe and Enid Lyons and John Curtin, Australian family types have diversified incredibly—the widowers, divorcees and single parents who are working, the double income families; the growth in no‐ and two‐income families in Australia has seen the great diversification of family type and earning capacity. That poses a very real challenge for both sides of politics.

I make no secret of the fact that a major challenge for left of centre parties is how to deal with the way in which the assumptions upon the postwar welfare state have fundamentally changed. The postwar welfare state was based on the idea of a traditional nuclear family—the male breadwinner bringing home a living wage to support the children and the family unit, with the wife staying at home to look after the children. That is no longer the typical family type in Australia in the 1990s.

We have had a phenomenal growth in zero and two‐income families. So the one‐income family, the type of family that gets maximum benefit out of this so-called family tax initiative, is no longer the majority, no longer the main stream. In fact, that type is the minor stream when one looks at the figures broken down in Australian demographics.

The Lyons Forum need to respond to that. These days they need to take greater inspiration from Enid Lyons than Joe Lyons. I think
that is a very important point to make—that people without partners should have a rightful place in the workplace. They should have a place in the house, and they should have a place in the work force. Of course, the fact that they have dependent children should not be a barrier to that. For all the rhetoric of the Lyons Forum, they need to take stock.

The member for Warringah is assuring me that they have taken inspiration from Enid Lyons. I welcome that. Why then have they supported and sponsored in this House a family tax initiative that increases the effective marginal tax rate for the non-working parent trying to rejoin the work force?

I will give the example of someone in my electorate who rang and said that six months ago she had a baby girl. Her husband was still at work, earning about $50,000 a year. If she were now to try to re-enter the work force, because of the provisions in this family tax package, she would face an effective marginal tax rate of 120 per cent. If she were to re‐enter the work force, she would lose the threshold benefit under part B of this legislation.

Mr Brough interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —You do the figures in Longman and you will get a surprise. Those families lose the means tested family payment; they lose their parenting allowance; they lose $10 on the child-care cash rebate under the provisions of this government; they lose the increase in the threshold under part B of the legislation now before the House; as a product of the budget, they face increased child-care costs with the spouse going back to work—a double income family; and of course there are the travelling costs. Their calculation—and they have produced it line by line, dollar by dollar, cent by cent—is that this young, educated career woman faces an effective marginal tax rate of 120 per cent to rejoin the work force. That is: if she goes back to work, she effectively loses one day's earnings off their current family income.

speech.para:
This bill and this government are placing a huge financial barrier and disincentive in the path of Australian women wanting to rejoin the work force after childbirth. I think that is a great shame. That is something Enid Lyons
would have been disgusted with—the idea that she would not have been allowed to join the House of Representatives because of the high, effective marginal tax rate. So, if the Lyons Forum stands for the values and opportunities that Enid Lyons enjoyed in life, they should bring down the effective marginal tax rate, and should not be in the business of social engineering.

The Lyons Forum and the government are about social engineering. They do not believe in choice; they do not believe in diversity. They believe in telling Australian women that they belong in the home. They are the social values that they want to engineer across all Australian family types. They believe in their own little world of one Wollstonecraft, one Kirribilli and one Vaucluse and that they are the sorts of family values we should have in Australia—that women belong in the home. They have placed a very high barrier in the path of women who try to rejoin the work force, because they lose benefits under this tax initiative and change to the tax threshold.

The Lyons Forum needs to take stock. I mention these things because so many people in my electorate these days are asking, `Well, what is the Lyons Forum? Who is it made up of? We are reading things about them and seeing things on the
7.30 Report
. Who is in charge of government policy? Who is running the government's family agenda? Is the Lyons Forum a secret society? Is it a right‐wing faction of the Liberal Party?' My constituents are asking me, `Is the Lyons Forum a group of religious zealots? Is it a group of fundamentalists with a Bible in the top drawer and a
Hustler
magazine and a box of tissues in their bottom drawer?'

My answer to my constituents who are posing those questions is that they are all of the above. They are narrow; they are social engineers; they are zealots; they are fundamentalists. They are saying to the women of Australia that they have one place, and one place only, in our society—and that is in the home. That is a great shame. For a party that was founded on the basis of liberalism, whatever happened to choice; whatever happened to diversity; whatever happened to
recognising that women in Australia need to make their own way in life?

The women of Australia need to have all possible career or family based opportunities made available to them—without hindrance, without disincentive and without barriers. If people choose to take their place in the home, raising children—and I think more men than ever are doing that these days, and certainly there are a number of women who still want to do that—I say, `Good luck to them.' They should be treated in the same manner with government tax scales and government policy as women and men who want to take a place in the work force. There should not be one rule, one set of laws, for Australians who want to fulfil the image of a white picket fence family, and another set of rules and laws for Australians who do not fit in with that stereotype of their free choice in a free and open society.

There is nothing mainstream about this legislation. The shadow Treasurer, the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), incorporated a graph showing that the full benefit of this family tax initiative was restricted to just 13 per cent of Australian families—because 50 per cent of our family types have no dependants; and, of the 50 per cent who do, three per cent earn too much under these provisions and 47 per cent are technically eligible. But single parents do not qualify for part A of the benefits in the bill; the two parents who are earning qualify only for part A and not B; and parents not earning do not pay tax at all, so they get no benefit out of the bill. Who does that leave? That leaves the `one parent earning, white picket fence family', the traditional nuclear family in Australia—13 per cent of the family types.

That is so different from the time of Curtin and Joe and Enid Lyons; that is not the mainstream Australian family. That is not the majority. That is a minor part of the incredible diversity of Australian family types. `Diversity' should be our buzz word in this parliament. Choice and support for families in need should be the basis of taxation and other policies. Mr Howard is well outside the `main stream' with this provision. He is swimming
in the `minor stream' of Australian family types.

Of course, that applies most acutely in the seat of Lindsay which is so topical because of the forthcoming by-election. Lindsay is the typical double income family type electorate in Australia. Fifty‐three per cent of the families in Lindsay are double income families, and they do not enjoy the full benefits of this provision. If in the future the female partner in those families were to give birth to a child and after a period of time tried to re-enter the work force, she and her family would have an active disincentive placed in their way. It is to the lasting shame of this government that it is in the business of social engineering—and, in the seat of Lindsay, social engineering in a fashion that runs down government support and opportunity for families in that particular part of western Sydney.

We have seen a huge amount of economic change in recent decades and it has produced massive changes to our society and the family unit. The basis of the postwar welfare state has changed fundamentally. The white picket fence in Australia is now looking moribund and tatty.

The growth of no- and two-income families is the major challenge in social and taxation policy. The Liberal Party is trying to deny all those changes. Its social engineering basically says that John Howard will stand like King Canute in front of the waves of female labour force participation.

The great increase and the great change in the Australian work force in the last 50 years has been the huge surge in the rate of female labour force participation. But John Howard and his Lyons Forum are trying to stand in the path of that wave. They will be swept away by it because economic change leads to profound social change, and Australian family types are a product of that.
I noticed with great interest that, when the Prime Minister was in Indonesia the other day, he said:
The Indonesian economy has changed and I am sure, in the process of time, the political institutions of this country will also go through change.

But what does he say in Australia? He says that economic change should be a reason for freezing social policy; economic change should be an alibi by which we try to freeze social structure and organisation. So there he is in Indonesia saying exactly the opposite thing—`They have had a revolution in their economy. They are having a big bundle of social and political changes, and that is inevitable.' Why doesn't he say that in Australia?

The Prime Minister should recognise that the opening of the Australian economy, the development of post‐Fordist work and the development of a post‐Fordist system of production has fundamentally changed the nature of our society and the family unit. Politicians should be in the business of anticipating those changes, not being social engineers or social commentators about them. They should be trying to promote choice and diversity.

Do not try to stand in the way of a wave of female labour force participation. The Liberal Party will be swept away by it. As Australian families understand these provisions—only 13 per cent get the full benefit and for so many women in Australia there is a disincentive—they will condemn the government for its actions.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

talk.start.para: —I have listened with great interest to the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). I have come to the conclusion that his obsession with the Lyons Forum must mean that he is either a member of it or very disappointed that he is not a member of it.

speech.para: I would also like to point out to the member for Werriwa that in this House the Liberal Party has four times the number of women that they have in the Labor Party—without a quota system. I do not think that goes well with your sarcastic comments about picket fences and forcing women to stay at home.

These family tax initiative bills acknowledge the central role that families have in supporting the foundation of Australian society. It is the centrepiece of the government's election commitment to Australian families. I, like my colleagues in the coalition, believe that a loving, supportive and stable
family environment is the best and most enduring system of social support. I strongly believe that families are central to the ongoing stability of Australian society. As a government, the coalition will focus the full range of government policies on strengthening families.

The family tax initiative will commence on 1 January 1997 and will benefit almost two million families with dependent children. Every year $1 billion will be directed into the pockets of these families. The people who will benefit most are Australia's lower and middle income families—a group forgotten by Labor.

The family tax initiative gives families a greater choice on how they spend their hard‐earned cash and how they juggle work and family responsibilities. The coalition recognises that each family is the best judge of its needs and the government programs reflect that approach.

As the Treasurer (Mr Costello) said in his second reading speech, the family tax initiative provides two forms of assistance. The first increases the tax free threshold by $1,000 for one parent in a family for each dependent child up to the age of 16 and each dependent secondary student up to 18 years. The assistance will be available to families which have a combined and taxable income of less than $70,000.

The increase in the threshold means that a family will save tax at a rate of about 20c in the dollar. Eligible families will, therefore, receive the equivalent of an increase of $200 per annum in their disposable income for each dependent child.

The second part delivers extra support for single income families, including lone parents with young children. The tax free threshold will increase by $2,500 for one parent in those families which have at least one child under five years of age. This is available to families where the sole income earner earns $65,000 or less a year. For example, a single income family earning less than $68,000 a year with two dependent children which takes out private health insurance will be $51.90 per fortnight better off.

break.para: Providing an economic and social environment in which families can achieve their full potential is crucial to maintaining a strong, cohesive and compassionate society. Financial assistance for those families with the greatest need is an investment in Australia's economic and social environment.

The pressures on today's family are enormous. Australian families must perform a delicate balancing act between their work and child‐raising responsibilities. This government is committed to pursuing policies which enable families to choose how they balance their work and child‐raising responsibilities. The government will ensure that families with young children are given greater freedom to choose whether one parent cares full‐time for their children at home or whether both parents are in the paid work force.

The coalition's family tax initiative is a great policy. But you do not have to take my word for it. Listen to the independent editorial reactions from some of Australia's leading political commentators after the family tax package was announced in this year's budget. Tom Burton, in the
Australian Financial Review
on 21 August, said:

John Howard's new government has kept faith with middle Australia and the market demands for major Budget repairs. Low and middle income groups are protected in a Budget which delivers tax cuts and health rebates to the mainstream political constituency which Mr Howard believes formed the core of his March election victory.

Michelle Grattan, in the
Australian Financial Review
of the same day, said:

Peter Costello's first Budget . . . reflects the Government's priorities with getting the economics right and focusing the politics towards the diligent middle class and those who strive to be part of it.

The
West Australian
editorial on 21 August said:

The Howard Government's first Budget makes a series of adjustments to the Commonwealth fiscal management—many of them essential and overdue. It clearly favours what Liberal Party founder Robert Menzies called the `Forgotten People'.

The
Daily Telegraph
editorial on 21 August said:

Plainly, the Government is solidly committed to repaying the faith shown by the broad band of voters who delivered them to office in March this
year—middle income Australian families—and for that it warrants no rebuke.
Importantly the Budget is also a convincing indication of the Government's sharp understanding of the scope of its economic task.
. . . Minor parties in the Senate take note. There is no question mark over the Government's authority, no shadow of doubt over the propriety of its budget strategy.

The
Age
editorial on 21 August said:

The Howard Government's first Budget is, as promised, a good Budget for middle Australia. It is a Budget that could hardly have been more carefully crafted to make most Australians feel comfortable in the style foreshadowed by Mr Howard in the lead up to the last election.

The
Advertiser
editorial said:
Rarely have Australians been presented with a happier anti‐climax.
. . . There were actual advantages for families with children and for some couples.

In the
Australian
, Alan Wood said:
The horror figures in this Budget . . . are the $69 billion of deficits accumulated over the past five years of the Labor Government—mostly during the Keating Prime Ministership.
. . . Instead of playing sleazy games in the Senate, Labor should apologise for its terrible failure as a financial manager and help Costello clean up the mess.

As Alan Wood reported, the coalition government should not stand back and ignore the problems of national debt and budget deficits faced by this country. Although we did not create these problems, we have accepted the responsibility to fix it. But, even with the budget black hole of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), we maintained our commitment to families.

The people and the families of Australia respect us for delivering a strong, fair and equitable budget. There is no doubt the coalition's first budget has been accepted by Australians. Unfortunately, the only political tactic of the Leader of the Opposition and his Labor Party has been to resort to the lowest common denominator and frighten Australians, particularly older Australians. The opposition is a desperate party playing desperate politics.

Labor's shrill scare campaign is riddled with inaccuracies and is a weak attempt to
divert attention from its responsibility for creating this budget mess. A prime example of Labor's campaign of misinformation is a newsletter from Queensland Senators Gibbs, Hogg and Reynolds, which was distributed by Mr Keating's candidate in Lilley at the last election.

An article on page 5 of the
Courier‐Mail
on Monday, 16 September said that nothing daunted Mr Keating's candidate in Lilley as he spent the early part of the morning pounding the pavements near his home, filling letterboxes. He was filling letterboxes with a newsletter that misinforms the electorate about the 1996 budget. Surprise, surprise! The newsletter directly targets the elderly, residents and families. However, it appears certain that the Labor Party have wasted thousands of dollars producing their inaccurate literature because, once again, they have failed to listen to the grassroots voters—the Australian families.

Indeed, I have been personally heartened by the community's response, particularly from the average family man and woman, to Labor's negative newsletter of deceit. Their litany of lies has not gone down well with the electorate. The feedback I am getting is that Senator Gibbs, Senator Hogg and Co. are very loose with the truth. The electors of Lilley are also very cynical about their newsletter, considering they have not been seen in the electorate.

Labor have no credibility when it comes to looking after families. People do not believe Labor any more. Labor are in for a long decade in the wilderness if they keep insulting the intelligence of the Australian families with a deceitful scare campaign. The days of the scare campaign are over. Australian families want positive policy targeting their needs. If the Labor Party do not learn this, they will end up like the shadow Treasurer, suffering from a terminal `relevance deprivation syndrome'. The coalition's Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 is a positive policy for Australia, and I commend it to the House.

speech.speaker: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

talk.start.para:
—I rise today to speak on the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative)
Bill 1996 to indicate that—far from having the benefits ascribed to it by the member for Lilley (Mrs Elizabeth Grace), who has just finished speaking—it actually has very detrimental effects on a great many families. Rather than generalising about that, I propose to read from a series of letters that I have, particularly on the question of increased child‐care costs.

speech.para: These tax measures are not about `mainstream Australia'—now a much abused phrase by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—nor about the battlers. It is actually, as one commentator put it, about the chosen few—a minority of Australian families. Some 13 per cent of the 4.8 million families actually benefit from this, and even many of those will have to meet additional costs as a result of cuts to the budget that paid for these tax breaks.

What I want to say—and I think it is very important that this be said clearly—is that this and other measures in the budget represent a very significant and direct and calculated attack on women and their families. It is an attack on women who choose to work part‐time or full‐time, women who are studying and women who want a break sometimes from their children, even if they are at home as the principal caregiver. This is a direct frontal attack on their interests, and they are beginning to realise that that is precisely what is happening.

It is not an accident. It is part of a philosophy that has formed part of the right wing of the Liberal Party for a very long time. There is the idea that women's choices should be restricted, that they should be at home providing care for their children, that they are the principal caregivers, that they cannot aspire to a career or an education. If they do, it is basically so they can make intelligent conversation with their partners, not so they have a role themselves.

It misunderstands the very significant social changes that have taken place in Australia, from a time when the majority of women did indeed stay home and look after their preschool age and older children. I might say, at that time most families were considerably larger than they are today. Most women in
Australia today have only one or two children at most, so their lives are not going to be totally determined by their role as mothers. They take that role very seriously. Every one of them, myself included, who has that responsibility takes it absolutely seriously.

None of us wants to be told by the government how we shall live our lives, and that is precisely what is happening in this budget. The Prime Minister and others within government are saying, `The choices that you make, the arrangements that you make, are not yours to make. We will actually penalise you financially if you have certain types of arrangements that are now commonplace in Australia.'

The majority of families in most electorates are two-income families—sometimes only from a part-time income. Many of them have young children of preschool age who require decent child care. One of the revolutions of the past 20 years has been the recognition that child care is as important to working families, to women in particular, as the tools of a trade are to a plumber or to a building assistant.

To take away child care, to make it too expensive for those families, is to prevent them earning a decent living. I would have thought that was what any government was about; to allow the family to support itself, to allow the family to make its own decisions without interference from government. Some people have suggested that this represents a form of social engineering. I endorse that view because it clearly is. Women are also getting the message. They are beginning to understand that this government is saying, `Stay home and look after your children. Give up your educational aspirations. Give up the need to keep your technical skills fresh by working part‐time while the children are young or we'll hit you for six economically.'

As the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) said in his speech, in some cases those who return to the work force find it extremely difficult because of the effective marginal tax rates in some cases of 120 per cent. If that is not forcing people into a certain course of action, I do not know what is. Women are getting the message, families are getting the message and they do not like what they are
hearing. I have been to a series of meetings concerning child care and the big increases that we have seen in the costs of child care are not just in the community based centres but across the board.

The claim that gets the biggest response—and this is not being made by politicians; it is being made by men and women standing up in these meetings—is from women saying, `If John Howard wants to send me back home to constrain my choices, he should think again. I will not be dictated too.' That gets an enormous round of applause and cheers. This is not coming from women who are privileged. Many of these women come from single income families, many of whom are struggling. I would like to read from a few of the letters that have been sent to me, copies of which have gone to Judi Moylan. These are people in my electorate. My electorate is very mixed. It includes low income families, some pretty well off professional and technical people, a lot of students and a fair number of single parents. This letter is from one of those single parents and reads:
Judi,
My husband works full time and I work part time—
a very typical arrangement for Australian families today—
just to keep up with everyday expenses. How on earth can I make ends meet if my child care fees come to more than my wage?

That is what is happening in these budgets. These tax breaks go to a very small number of families anyway, and for most of them they are immediately washed away by huge increases in child‐care costs, not to mention pharmaceuticals and health costs. The letter further reads:
Please stop us and more families from going below the poverty line.
So much for representing the battlers! Another letter which is very plaintive reads:
Dear Judi,

My partner and I study and work part time. We have one (shortly to be two) children in day care part time. Neither of us wishes (or can afford) to be at home full time. We are both better parents and a happier family—
and I underline this part—

break.para: with the arrangements that we have worked very hard to set up.
That is their choice. Why should they be prevented from exercising it? The letter further reads:
Why are you damaging the financial and emotional security of so many families like ours? There is NO benefit to our children, our community and our families in this—and we will fight you over it.

That is certainly a message that I want to give to the Prime Minister and the minister responsible for this area of child care. It is no good giving tax breaks to families when they are insultingly small compared with what you are taking away and when you put these big barriers in front of the exercising of their choice and you undermine the arrangements that they have already made for their family income, for their security and for their future.
Another example is from a young woman who is doing the right thing and studying. She is trying to ensure that she is able to help support her family. The letter reads:
I am a student with two children in long day care part time. Even so I am anticipating an increase of between $50‐$60 pw rise in fees next year.
That is what will happen to a lot of these people, with the combination of the removal of the operational subsidy and other changes. It further reads:
. . . for two children, 4 days per week because of the loss of the operational subsidy, plus further losses from benefits and child care assistance as our centre is open 57.5 hours per week.
Another hit, because you are allowed to keep them open only 50 hours. A lot of people have factored this in. They know what the equation looks like. The letter continues:
After the family tax package I am $70 pw worse off.
How does that help this struggling family? The letter states:
Next year was to be my honours year. It is a crucial year for me as I want to work in academia and go on to further post‐graduate studies.
That is a reasonable choice for a human being to make. Just because she is a woman does not mean she should not be able to make that choice. The letter further reads:

This is now impossible. I feel so frustrated and angry that with the flick of a pen you have taken
away all my hard work, all my aspirations, my hopes for the future and a better life for myself and my children. Please look at the human costs of your economic rationalist policies.

Many letters of that kind have been sent to Judi Moylan, and a lot of them have been sent to us as members representing these women in the community. I think one of them puts it very poignantly. It is a very simple little fax which states:
Dear Judi,
Wake up, before it's too late! Australia's children need that $½ billion back now. Now!

That is just a summary of the very great concern that many parents are expressing to me and to other members. They note that there has been a tax rebate offered to them. Many of them can take advantage of only part A of that, and at the same time they are getting the big increases in child‐care costs.

I want to go through some of the child‐care changes in detail because this is one of the great betrayals. During the election campaign the shadow minister at the time and the Prime Minister said that they would maintain the system and, what is more, improve it. They were critical of some elements of our child‐care policy. They indicated that they would maintain the system of child‐care assistance that existed. Have they done that? No. The child‐care assistance system has been radically changed in this budget, with cuts of more than $73 million in the first year. How can you stand up and say that is not a significant change? It is a clear breach of promise; a clear breach of commitment to these people. Again, quoting from the policy document:
A Coalition Government will maintain the non‐means tested Childcare Cash Rebate.

Again there is a clear breach of promise. I know it is fashionable to say that this affects only the wealthy, but a lot of the families—the two‐income families, the families of Lindsay who will be looking at this in the next few weeks—may well be two teachers, a nurse and a teacher, or a clerical assistant and a teacher; hardly people at the top end of town. The child‐care cash rebate is now subject to a means test. It is a breach of promise, if nothing else. The coalition promised:
The Liberal and National Parties will strengthen parents' right to choose the arrangements they want for the care of their children.

What a joke, because in removing the operational subsidies from community based care you are basically saying, `We don't care if these centres go to the wall.' Either they will have to put their fees up through the roof or they can be privatised and set free in the wider market.

Parents who are using community based centres have chosen them. Many of those parents, indeed, cannot find appropriate care in the private sector, either because they have young children below the age of two and there are not enough places for them in the private sector or because there are significant advantages in the community based sector for children who have special needs.

There is another point, one which I think the government has overlooked. Those centres are the longest standing in our community and they are run by parents for parents, not by individuals outside the system for profit. What the government is basically saying is, `We don't care if parents continue to have a role in child care, in its management and its design. As far as we are concerned, the private sector can do it all.' We do not say that anywhere else in the system—we have a balance, we have a mix. Yet here parents are actually being told that they cannot have choice any more. The policy document said:
The Liberal and National Parties will strengthen parents' right to choose those arrangements.

Yet the part B tax initiative penalises them, because if you are working you do not get all the tax break. Again that is a very clear disincentive to families, along with the child care cuts. The coalition went on to say:
A Liberal/National Party Government will continue to support the creation of additional places to meet the current un‐met demand . . .

What a joke. It has all been pulled out in this budget—no further expansion, none at all. It is as if we had already met the targets, not just for women who want to go into the work force but for those requiring education and a significant number of women who are at home with their pre school age children but who sensibly say that from time to time their
children need the social contact with other children and they need a break.

With small families it is absolutely critical that young children have opportunities to socialise and that parents, particularly mothers at home with children, have a break from their children. That is something that any decent psychologist would recognise, yet this government appears to be ignoring the advice of its own experts—I know they exist—from the Department of Health and Family Services. I am sure they would have told members of the government the likely impact of these changes.

What we are seeing is that not only has each and every one of those promises been broken but the government has actually taken half a billion dollars out of the system. How is it being made up? It comes out of the pockets of the families who are struggling to provide for their own security. They are being told, `Here is a little bit back. We'll take out half a billion dollars and we will give you back a small proportion of that.' Australians are not stupid. Women are not stupid. They can read that message.

Some of them will not read it until their particular child‐care centre has its fees go through the roof, until they realise that they are being denied the same level of child‐care cash rebate as they formerly had. Perhaps they will not realise it until they see the staffing levels at their centre being cut and the level of expertise diminished—with more 15-year-olds, who can be paid peanuts, rotating through the system and with no continuity of care for their children. That is when those who have not yet seen what is coming at them will wake up. But many of them already are aware of it, as I pointed out, because the measures to abolish the operating subsidies for community centres, the changes to the income disallowance for child‐care assistance and so on, represent a massive assault on the women of this community.

I have to say that I found it extremely irritating that the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Newman) was saying that she recognised that child care should be a work related expense,
but at the same time was making it impossible for women to continue working with comfort.

In the little budget document
More choice for women
, as if by saying the opposite of what is true you are going to convince people that it is so, the government actually delivers less choice but says, `Oh, this is more choice.' Again people are not stupid. They can read that. The more the government emphasises that this is about choice, the more people recognise that it is the government's choice, not families' choice. They do not want this package. The minister, talking about affordability, says:
Affordable child care for families who choose paid child care arrangements will be maintained.

Again, what a joke. Every analysis has shown that even if you are in a private centre the changes will certainly lead to increases in costs. Where do they hit hardest? Low and middle income families are hardest hit, they are the ones who bear the brunt of this—the people that you insultingly describe as the battlers, the people who do often do it hard.

You insult them by thinking that, just because you label them battlers, say you are supporting them and say you are giving them more choice, they will not figure out that you have not done any of those things, that you are not supporting them, that you are giving them less choice and that you are hitting them in the pocket while bringing in a piece of legislation like the bill today and having all these paeans of praise for something that is insultingly small compared with what is being taken away from them.

The minister goes on in her document to say that, in a tough fiscal environment, low and middle income families using child care have been protected from reductions to benefits. I suggest the minister have a look at the policy. I suggest the minister have a look at her own budget papers to see that that is simply not true.

In case members opposite are under any illusions about this, let me give them a couple of examples, and not unrealistic examples I am sure you will agree. If you look at a single income family with a wife at home with young preschool children, maybe doing a little bit of part‐time work on the weekend
so her husband or partner can take care of the children, yes, that family is better off as a result of this budget. That part of that 13 per cent cohort is better off by about $25 a week. But that is not taking account of changes to pharmaceutical and other costs that they are going to have to meet as a result of the budget. However, just looking at the balance between child care and this family tax initiative, that family is better off.

Let us have a look now at more realistic scenarios since we know the majority of families are working families, dual‐income families. Take a two‐income family with two children aged one and two and just for the moment let us suppose they are living in Penrith, since it is on everyone's minds. Say that the wife is a sales assistant on $22,000 a year and the husband a motor mechanic on $25,000. That is a combined family income of $47,000, not an unrealistic scenario in the homes of the battlers that you claim to represent. They are both earning below average weekly earnings, but an average is an average so inevitably some families fall below it.

Let us say they have children in community based child care for 50 hours a week. Again, that is not an unreasonable scenario; there are plenty like that in my electorate. Let us assume further that they have no private health insurance. Again, that represents the majority of Australians. Sixty-six per cent of Australians do not have private health insurance; they choose Medicare. What the government is giving is the family tax initiative part A for the two children—$7.70—and no part B because the spouse is earning. You remove the operational subsidy from child care of $21 a child per week. That is $42 a week additional cost to them, and restrictions on child-care assistance mean that there is another $13.80 a week cost.

What is the effect on that family? That family—the battlers if you want to call them that, people who are doing it hard—will under your generous arrangements be paying an additional $48 a week, even with the tax benefits that you claim to be giving them. You can go up the income scale and find the same arrangements. For example, take a two-income family with one dependent child aged
two years and both parents senior teachers. You might say they are relatively well off as they have incomes of about $35,000 each. The child is in a full-time private care centre for 50 hours and they have no private health insurance.
