That family—even that relatively privileged family—is nearly $10 a week worse off after you have had your way with them.

I must say they are not unique scenarios. In fact, with the combination of charges in this budget—and I have not mentioned them all—such as aged care, education, child care, pharmaceuticals, health care costs, with all of those additional costs, the families of Australia are entitled to say to this government what a bunch of cheats you are.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Bradford, John, MP

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to stand up in this debate and defend the government's decisions in respect of family care. In fact, the opposition has very little credibility at all on this or any other issue and the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), in particular, is really straining things to stand up here and talk with any credibility about family policy.

speech.para: The former government, the now opposition, did enormous damage to families over the 13 years that they were on this side of the House. For them to stand up here and criticise this legislation in any way at all just reeks of plain hypocrisy as far as I am concerned.

I am proud to be a member of a government now that has finally recognised the importance of families within our society. All we have heard today from the member for Fremantle is some of the sort of ideology that was rammed down our throats year after year for the whole 13 years that we put up with the former government. We understand the importance of child care but in the end what the former government did, through its great penchant for social engineering, was to create a situation where some parents had access to child care and others did not. The system that the former government introduced discriminated against stay‐at‐home mothers. Why? Because people like the member for Fremantle, who leads the feminist charge in this place, wanted to create a situation whereby
women were forced or coerced or conscripted into the work force. It is as simple as that.

Our policies in relation to child care are aimed at creating equality of choice for people about what is the best care for their child, not to create a situation where they are forced by virtue of the arrangements that were put in place by the former government to take child care on a take‐it‐or‐leave‐it basis. In other words, you take the sort of child care we have to offer you on our terms, the government's terms—that is, you get it if you go out to work or you stay home and take care of your own kids and do not get it. Or, even more ludicrously, you stay home and you actually can be in a situation where you can be paid to care for somebody else's children but not your children. That is the system that you are defending. That is the system that the member for Fremantle stands up here and attempts to defend. It is ridiculous. So the former government's policies discriminated against families. The former government's policies prevented families from making their own choices about what was best for them and what was best for the care of their own children.

I believe that on 2 March this year the Australian people took a very definite decision. They had had enough of that sort of social engineering, that sort of pandering to minority groups that the former government was famous for. They took a step in voting for a coalition government that I believe said very clearly that they want an end to all that sort of intrusion in their lives, and that is what this government will deliver to them. There is no greater example of that than the family tax initiative legislation that we are actually debating in this House today.

This legislation not only delivers a key election promise by John Howard to Australian families but also delivers a fairly substantial turnaround in public policy. This legislation is a watershed for Australian families. It is a divide. It draws a line in the sand between the anti‐family bias in the family policy of the previous government and the pro‐family stance of this Howard government. It really is as stark as that. It draws that line between anti‐family and pro‐family. We were
elected on that platform. One of the key parts of our election platform was the legislation that we are debating in this place today. This legislation makes as clear as anyone would want to have it the distinction between the coalition and the Labor Party.

Although the budget achieved a lot for Australia, nothing more clearly exemplifies the underlying philosophy of John Howard and his government than this particular legislation. The legislation is symbolic because it is indicative of the Howard government's commitment to Australian families. As one who has in this place proudly defended families at every opportunity, I say that the merit or the virtue of this legislation is not so much in the dollars, because we could go a lot further than this, and I might have been one who advocated or hoped that we could go further than the $1 billion that this package costs. What it does is point to a direction in which I believe Australian families want to go.

In that respect, it is the first step in a journey back to prosperity for Australian families. I do not mean prosperity in a material sense necessarily; I mean that Australian families can now, with a John Howard led government, have a sense of wellbeing, a feeling of confidence that they have not been and will not be forgotten by the Howard government. They will no longer have the sense of despair, of marginalisation and of being discriminated against that was so evident amongst Australian families under the former government.

As we emerge from those 13 years, it has become very clear that Australian families were forgotten—or, worse, that they were actually denigrated by the policy makers of the Australian Labor Party, particularly those like the member for Fremantle. Traditional families were denigrated. Families who wanted to make the choice to have a stay‐at‐home mum or a stay‐at‐home dad—a stay‐at‐home parent—were denigrated by people of their ilk.

For that reason, the majority of Australian families are certainly glad to see the end of the Labor government. Those people have emerged not unscathed but unbowed in their
determination to redress the wrongs of the past 13 years—and the coalition is there to support them—and to repair the damage done to our society's most fundamental and enduring institution, the family.

I am not going to spend time in this debate going to the technical details of this package. That has been spelt out very clearly. I think everyone understands what the actual intention is as far as this particular package is concerned. I am very proud to stand in this place today and support the legislation.

We are now entering the post‐feminist era. This is particularly good news for families. In her excellent 1995 John Bonython lecture at the Centre for Independent Studies, Professor Brigitte Berger, Professor of Sociology at Boston University, said that the 1960s and 1970s circumstances had:

. . . served a loosely formed coalition of Leftist and radical feminists to declare war on the family in its middle class form and ethos. The governments of virtually every Western nation came under siege to establish, maintain and of course finance supplementary and alternative structures to the family and to provide for a great variety of intervention mechanisms.

In my view, that aptly sums up exactly what we had from 13 years of Labor government in this country. In her lecture, Professor Berger develops a very persuasive argument for the close link between middle‐class family, economic prosperity and political liberalism. She says further:

The majority of governmental efforts to supplement and circumvent the functions of traditional family, with a few notable exceptions, have not achieved a lot. A mass of frightening statistics attest to the failure to stem the rising tide of delinquency, crime, drug use, teenage pregnancy and welfare dependency rampant in virtually every society of the West today.
She continues:

If one views the politics of the past decades through the prism of family one cannot help but conclude that in turning away from the strong normative order of the middle class family all these costly and public efforts combine to undermine the social fabric of Western society.
Further, reflecting the current situation, she says:

. . . a sizeable proportion of feminists, moved by the strength of their love for their children and one
would hope their husbands as well, have been lured back from the wilder shores of madness where many had moored for long.

talk.start.para: —Oh, claptrap!

—I imagine the member for Werriwa probably hates hearing this stuff. This is exactly what the member for Werriwa stands for in this place. I could be talking about him. He is squirming and I love it. Let me quote again from Professor Berger. She says:

speech.para: With the socialist vision—
which the member for Werriwa so strongly subscribes to—

discredited perhaps beyond repair, policy makers already disheartened by the remarkable powerlessness of their programs have shown a surprising willingness to give credit to the importance of the family in the organisation of individual and social life.

Luckily, the members opposite have come around. They have come around slowly. They have realised that the day is passed for their discredited anti‐family ideology, their social engineering. People are fed up with all that stuff. Latterly, they are slowly waking up to the fact that somehow the family is important.

Professor Berger was mainly speaking about the United States, but we are finally getting there in Australia. President Clinton declared recently that governments do not raise children—families do. They have come to that point in the United States. We are getting there too. This legislation brings us a fair way down that track, not only in substance but also in the symbolism that is involved in it.

There are still some in Australia who remain moored on the wilder shores that Professor Berger spoke of. Fortunately, or perhaps I could say hopefully, these policy makers have been sidelined, at least for the foreseeable future, but I have noticed there are a few still out there. Eva Cox is still writing for the
Australian
I see, and there is Beatrice Faust—the member for Werriwa would love these people. Eva Cox in last Friday's
Australian
was using that great language that we hear from the Labor Party so often, the language of the 1950s and 1960s. She describes people like me, and I suppose ironically maybe the member for
Werriwa, as fiscal fascists who imply that somehow the advocates for a fairer society are ripping off the system.

She must be one of the few remaining true socialists. She is a feminist socialist. What could be worse than that combination. She even has the audacity to suggest that I and those that believe as I do implicitly support the idea that families are important and traditional values are important. She also has the audacity to suggest that I support Pauline Hanson populism, as she puts it. I assure this House I do not. In fact, quite to the contrary, I found very little indeed to agree with in anything the member for Oxley said in her speech. I am on the record as taking that position and I am quite happy to be. It does not worry me that 95 per cent of Australians agree with some of the incredible remarks she made. The fact is that I do not agree. For Eva Cox to even imply that those who believe in some of the things I and many of us on this side, and even some on the other side, believe in would agree with Pauline Hanson is quite offensive.

The legislation we are dealing with is a recognition not only that families are important but also that it makes sense to support families—not just from a social policy perspective, although in this place I have often argued that it does that and it certainly does, but it just makes good economic sense as well, which ultimately appears to be Professor Berger's thesis too. The cost of family breakdown is incalculable. There have been attempts over the years to calculate what the actual cost is and you can add all sorts of things into it and the dollars add up and add up but in the end you can't even begin to put a price on the social costs that are associated with family breakdown.

The good news of this legislation is that the family is on its way back. Perhaps it was destined in many respects to survive the onslaught that it has experienced, that Professor Berger spoke of and that I have spoken of having occurred in Australia. She puts it in these terms:

While there can be little doubt that parents all over the world have remained loyal to time tested values, the same cannot be said of the media and
a generation of policy makers reared in the adversary culture of the past decades.
The member for Werriwa would certainly fit into that category as well.

However, to quote the former Labor leader, the caravan has moved on, and you will have to move with it. You might not like that but Australia has changed a bit—2 March was the watershed when that change really came to light. You have been left behind but you will catch up inevitably; you will have to catch up. This legislation is indicative of the direction this government is going to go in. What it is going to do is give families more responsibility, more choice, more ability to look after themselves. People plainly got tired of having their affairs run for them by the intrusive and interventionist and social engineering government that we had for so many years. People got tired of that and 2 March, as I say, was the point where they made their position very clear indeed. Because of that, the relevance deprivation syndrome must be very painful. It is obviously also catching. For a while you are just going to have to get to like it, because the Australian people made you largely irrelevant at the last election.

The legislation that we are dealing with today, the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill, is underpinned by a number of important principles. The most important one is that children need families—family breakdown hurts kids, divorce is bad for kids and kids thrive in a functional family environment. That is what underpins this legislation. That is what this legislation ultimately is about doing, in terms of giving money back to families with children—money that has been taken off them and redistributed to all sorts of great programs that the former government used to cook up. I do not think there would be much argument now, although there was for a couple of decades, that no alternative can work. There were plenty of alternatives thrust upon us but they have not worked. We have to realise, finally, that families work and they have to be supported, they have to be encouraged. This legislation, ultimately, is aimed at doing that.

The tax system, which has traditionally discriminated against families with children, had to be fixed. That is what we are doing
here. The legislation is a step in the direction of fixing that discrimination. The former government was very big on discrimination. Anti‐discrimination would have to be one of the foremost planks of its reason to be. Yet here it presided over legislation, it introduced legislation, it fostered legislation which discriminated against families with children.

This legislation is a step away from the past trendy ideology which made marriage and family actually disadvantageous. That is what we put up with for 13 years—legislation that actually disadvantaged people in getting married and having families. It is hard to believe but that is what we had to put up with for 13 years. This is a move away from the discredited tax and welfare systems of the past, which made it difficult for women to choose to stay home. There can now be no doubt that the absence of women from the home has had serious consequences for child rearing, despite the arguments that we might hear from the member for Fremantle. She would be arguing that putting kids into child care as soon as they are born is actually the best way to go. That is ludicrous. That is why she and so many that think that way are totally out of date.

This legislation also reverses the trend of treating support for families as welfare. The message in this also is vital: this legislation gives a clear signal that we are moving away from saying that caring for children and family benefits are welfare. They are not. Welfare for many families, as it has been for Australians who are not necessarily in a family situation, has become the problem, and it is not the answer.

talk.start.para: —What do you mean by welfare?

—The member for Werriwa knows what I mean by welfare. He is up to his neck in it. This legislation also reinforces the fundamental notion that families are partnerships. There is an interdependency within families, not a dependency. A family is an entity. It is not a disparate group of individuals who cohabit for a time, although that was the sort of trendy thinking that was imposed on us. Families are entities, not people who live together for a while.
—Is the earth round?

—The earth is still round, believe it or not. The opposition would have changed that if it could. I am very proud to support this legislation. It indicates that the Howard government is committed to Australian families. It delivers on a fundamental plank in our election platform, that we will get back to basics, that we will start to make families important, we will start to re‐recognise that the family is the fundamental unit of our society. The fact that it has survived here as it survived in other parts of the world, despite the trendy onslaught of extreme feminist thinking, is an amazing tribute to the fact that it has got that ability to survive. But we are going to give it some help. We believe it makes good social sense to do so and we believe strongly that it makes good economic sense to do so.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Rocher, Allan, MP

talk.start.para: —The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), in parts of his speech on the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill, advanced admirably the views and thinking of the coalition. But one thing that is noticeable is that he is not a humble man by any means. He is like a lot of his front bench, still gloating over a very convincing win on 2 March.
—Well, you could have been part if it, but you weren't.

—I did win on 2 March, my friend. I won rather handsomely. That is the first time I have gloated about it publicly. I must say that you should have halved your speech, addressed the issues and forgotten about dumping on the opposition, because it added nothing to an otherwise very commendable set of arguments.

speech.para: More and more, successive governments have used taxation law to secure social priorities, as I am sure you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker. Because this bill is another of this all too familiar kind, that is not reason in itself to do other than welcome the proposals before the House. Family tax assistance is to be there for all families who earn sufficient taxable income to be able to get the benefits through the PAYE system or, if they happen to be self‐employed, on lodgment of their returns.

break.para: Lower income families are catered for in the second of these cognate bills, the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill 1996, and they will benefit from the alternative approach of the government, which will take the form of a fortnightly cash payment called the family tax payment, or the FTP. That payment can be expected fortnightly for those whose income is low enough to prevent them qualifying through PAYE or the income tax system.

The coalition is honouring an election promise and is entitled to support for both bills. That it has not backtracked on an undertaking is shaping up as something of an exception rather than the rule, and should be encouraged by acknowledgment. It is especially commendable in this case because the revenue to be forgone must have attracted the attention of and seriously tempted the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in his equally commendable efforts to achieve an underlying budget surplus within three years of the new government coming to office.

In that context, it is well known that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had his way, and that is not a bad thing. That should be viewed in the background of some economic comment which, whilst acknowledging that the family tax package was welcome, was of the view that, given the budgetary situation inherited by the Howard government, it really could not be afforded. So the Prime Minister's priorities were very much in evidence in this particular case.

Indeed, the Prime Minister had the duty and the obligation to honour his undertaking of 18 February last year. The fact that he could not or chose not to take up a few more of the undertakings made about the same time is a matter of regret, but it is also understandable, as I have already indicated, in the budgetary context which was an unconscionable legacy from the Labor government.

To some extent, as has already been pointed out by some opposition speakers, the benefits will be eroded or otherwise offset by other budget measures. There are charges which the beneficiaries of these measures will have to meet, although to some extent they are discretionary and so it is a matter of choice. The effect of these measures will be to redistribute
into after‐tax incomes for qualifying families taxpayer revenue, and to divert or to offset the cost by increasing budget measures which will increase the cost to those same families and to taxpayers more generally.

I have mentioned that the proposal was announced by the Prime Minister on 18 February in the context of an election campaign. The Treasurer confirmed the undertaking in his budget speech not so very long ago. We are told that in a full year the total cost to revenue—if that is the right way of putting it; I am not comfortable with that expression—is in the vicinity of just over $1,000 million in a full year. I think the first full year will be in 1998-99.

The government has, in the explanatory memorandum, tried to deal with compliance costs and, under the heading `Compliance cost impact', it gives us some information. It points out that there will be a cost to taxpayers because they are required to understand the rules. They will have to do new calculations. Tax paying families who have shared custody of children will have to do pro rata calculations to determine the benefits they can claim for their family.

It is surprising, and I am pleased that it is pointed out in the explanatory memorandum, that many taxpayers are expected to have to make agreements with their spouses. The member for Braddon (Mr Miles) might like to reflect on that. We are going along the line of pre‐marital agreements introduced by the tax act. I think that would be unfortunate. I wonder what the member for McPherson will say about that having regard to some of the things he has said.

para.break:
The answer to this is that there will be some additional material in the
Tax Pack
. Thank God for that! I am afraid to admit that, for someone who until three years ago always prepared his own personal tax return, I have recently had to go to the expense of going to a tax agent for the first time in my tax paying life. I do not know what that says about the
Tax Pack
. More importantly, I think it makes a very interesting statement about the complexity of tax laws and the cost of compliance which we speak so often about in this place and which are finally receiving a little atten tion from governments not only in Australia but around the world—with not much effect to date I might add, but at least they are aware of the arguments.

break.para: It seems to me that because the explanatory memorandum does not attach a cost to the compliance cost impact it is short on the sort of information we would expect. Perhaps it is impossible to put a figure on what it costs the average taxpayer to abide by rules and amendments to the tax laws but it seems strange to me. Perhaps it indicates that the time of wage earning, salary earning taxpayers has no value. If that is the case, I would regret that.

The end result is that we have no cost estimate. It goes to the mind‐set of the people preparing the compliance cost impact and perhaps it is something they could address. One thing is certain: this will be just another reason for many taxpayers being driven into the hands of tax agents. I do not say that in any sense of criticism of tax agents because they are by and large very competent people, but there is a considerable cost to taxpayers involved and the more complicated you make the tax law, the more cost to taxpayers, the greater the cost of tax compliance.

To offset that to some extent the bills being debated cognately are in the simplified format. This will mean that we will have the tax act partly simplified. The greater part of it is yet to be dealt with. I am not sure that the overall result is simplification. Nevertheless, I welcome and support attempts to make the tax laws as simple as humanly possible. That is made all the more difficult, though, when governments use tax laws to secure social outcomes. There must be, and indeed there is, a better way of going about it. But every concession you put into tax law creates an opportunity for some people to minimise their tax and for some to enter into tax avoidance arrangements. I do not think this will be any different. I think there will be people on the margin who will arrange their affairs to receive all or part of the benefits of these measures, which they now would not be entitled to.

But it does raise that question, which re‐emphasises it. It just adds another 100 pages
to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, and to social security legislation, in the case of the second bill. Nevertheless, having said all that, I say again that I support the legislation. It is one of the measures which the government clearly promised prior to the last election and found itself able to keep.

In the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill 1996, which will become the prerogative of the Department of Social Security and its minister to oversee, we have a financial impact statement which confirms the figure I mentioned earlier—in the year 1998‐99, a total reduction in revenue of $1.077 million. This bill has no compliance impact statement. I do not know why that should be so. Perhaps they have incorporated all of the considerations in the second bill. But, as these memoranda stand alone—before some court, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the like they may be read on occasions to establish the parliament's intentions in relation to legislation—it is doubtful whether it is wise to leave any relevant information out of the explanatory memoranda, if that is what has been done, on the basis that the same information will appear in the explanatory memorandum for the first of these cognate bills.
I reiterate that I support the bill. I wish it a fast passage.

speech.speaker: Billson, Bruce, MP

talk.start.para: —The Family (Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 and the accompanying Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 are two of the more important bills that this House will consider and probably two of the most evident examples of the success that a coalition government is making of its first term for a long period. I point to the fact that this side of politics has not been in a position to implement these sorts of worthwhile initiatives for a long period, and I refer to what happened to this country while we were sitting on the opposition benches.

speech.para:
What we are trying to do is correct some of the problems of the Labor government that this country has had to bear for some time. One interesting and I think most creative way of ensuring enhanced levels of equity was the previous government's idea that making more people poor was somehow a good way of
increasing equity in this country. Professor Harding's study—many others have been published and debated at length in this House—revealed that families were far more vulnerable under the previous government and that a far greater proportion of families were ending up in poverty statistics and battling to make ends meet. Labor's idea was to make this country more equitable.

I do not think that is the answer. I am pleased to say that this side of the parliament does not think it is the answer and that during the election campaign the vast majority of Australian people did not think that was the answer. We should have been giving families a better go rather than relegating far too many of them, including hundreds of thousands of children, into the lines of the poverty that the Henderson poverty line identifies. It is probably the saddest reflection on what the Labor government did not do over its last 13 years that so many families have been put in crisis.

During the March election campaign the coalition, through our leader, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), continually said that we wanted to restore the core values that had been lacking from politics over the past few years—honesty and reliability—sticking to a much greater degree to promises that we made during the election campaign in vivid contrast to what our opponents on the other side did.

The Prime Minister announced the coalition's family tax initiative on 18 February. When it was announced there was some scepticism around, particularly in the press. I refer to an article by Tim Colebatch in
The Age
on 19 February. Mr Colebatch said:
John Howard's family tax package costs more than we can afford and yet it is clever, well crafted, packaged and it would help those who need it most.

Brian Toohey in the
Australian Financial Review
of the same date commented that those with a $100,000 mortgage might care to ponder the fact that they would save $250 a year simply by a 0.25 percentage drop in interest rates.

We have seen this government not only delivering on both of those commitments but also going even further. Reductions in interest
rates have saved Dunkley families with an average $100,000 loan around $65 a month. That is cash in the hand of families—the people who need it most. We have also seen the government comprehensively deliver on its family tax initiative. On 20 August, we delivered a family tax initiative which proves that the Prime Minister can deliver on key commitments and that he has stuck to core priorities identified during the election campaign.

After the 20 August budget was delivered it is fair to say that commentators were somewhat less cynical, and I welcome that fact. Michelle Gratton in the
Australian Financial Review
said:
The government has kept its election family tax promise which will provide assistance to nearly 2 million families at a cost of almost $1 billion in a full year.

This paragraph did not appear in the
Herald‐Sun
and did not appear on the back of taxis driving around Frankston and Mornington—perhaps it should have. It was saying that this government, during very difficult economic times that were not of our creation, still managed to put $1 billion back in the hands of people who needed it most—the families, the people who are bringing up young Australians, the future of this country. The government, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are to be congratulated for that.

The actual benefits in the family tax package do add up and are affordable. From 1 January next year, provided the Democrats, the Greens and even some of those on the other side decide to give this the green light both in our House and in the Senate, parents will receive two separate sets of benefits. With the first payment a parent's tax-free threshold for each dependent child under 16 or 17 in full-time secondary schooling will be increased by $1,000 provided their taxable income is no more than $70,000 a year.

The $70,000 a year package is an interesting matter to dwell on for a moment in that it is also targeted to those who need it most. It is not a willy‐nilly promise. It is not a hairychested—a term that has become quite popular here—attempt to be attractive as an alternative government to the vast array of
families; it is a policy measure that gives support to the people that need it most.

For each additional dependent child, the tax free threshold will rise by another $3,000 to a maximum of $79,000 for a family with four dependent children. This benefit works out at $7.70 a fortnight per child or about $800 a year on top of those savings that I have already mentioned relating to interest rates on mortgages.

Under the second part of the family tax initiative, single income families, which can either be one parent staying at home or a sole parent, with at least one child under the age of five are also assisted. The single income families receive a flat $2,500 increase in their tax free threshold up to a maximum income level of $65,000. That is stepped up with each additional child up to a $74,000 income limit. That benefit to families is an extra $19.20 a fortnight, $500 a year. That is serious money in the pockets of people who need it most.

I might dwell on that point for a moment because I consider myself one of the more fortunate young people in this country in that my parents made the decision that one of them would like to stay at home and bring up me and my brother. That was a difficult decision for my family because we certainly would not have given these upper income levels a fright. But that was a decision that was made in our family's interests and very much in mine and my brother's.

What it meant, though, was that, as we were growing up and going through our schooling, it was my family and a number of other very fortunate young people's families who were involved in school activities. The fun we had wrapping up lucky dips for the school fete, the buzz you get when you go and buy zooper doopers or something like that at the canteen and see a handful of parents who are giving up their time and putting their energies into making that school community in the broader neighbourhood a more viable, a more vibrant and a more pleasant place to live, was something quite special.

But it was a decision that was made to forgo a second income in the interests of our family. I will illustrate that by pointing out
that when I was of an age to reach pedals on a bike my mother decided to go out and work part time selling Avon so that we could afford a bike. So there is an indication of how close that financial viability line was in our family because we had one source of income, but how important it was for my parents to be supportive of us as we grew up, as we took on the world and as we had to deal with so many other influences that impacted on so many young people's lives then. There are even more impacts that families and young people have to deal with today.

That was something quite special. It was my introduction to community service, almost. It was the ethos that you roll up your sleeves, you get involved for the greater good of the community that you are a part of. I guess that is perhaps where I got my inspiration from to become more involved in serving the community and being a part of the community and thinking more widely about what contribution I can make to my neighbourhood, to my suburb, to my city, to the electorate of Dunkley and, hopefully, to this nation.

Adele Horin in the
Sydney Morning Herald
summed up the importance of this initiative very well in the 21 August comments that she had in the
Sydney Morning Herald
:

The family tax package will deliver real benefits to some of Australia's most disadvantaged families with pre‐school children, including sole parents and unemployed couples. For the poorest families with children under five, it is the best thing to have happened since Labor's family package in the 1980s.

I might dwell on something that Labor did just for a moment. In 1993, Paul Keating offered child‐care policies to the electorate that mainly benefited two‐income families. It was interesting in that he could put his hand up as being most responsible for creating the need for two‐income families, and then he followed that up by facilitating the two‐income families working in the workplace, generating the income needed to deal with the problems that he and his government created. That initiative probably lost votes amongst those people who had forgone one source of income to be a part of the home life and to help rear the children.

break.para: I guess what you are seeing today is that this government has carried forward some of the positive elements of that child‐care policy, actually targeted it more effectively, and countered what I think are quite uncomplimentary remarks that are coming from the other side that community long day child‐care centres somehow cannot cut the mustard like those in the private sector. How offensive is that, when people on the other side say, `Look, you have done these awful things to community based long day care centres because you have taken the subsidy away,' when those subsidies account for about a $4 a week cost differential, and then people over there say, `This is disgraceful, you are ruining these child‐care centres.'

I remind honourable members that people who work in the community, who work even in the Public Service, and who are involved in these community long day child‐care centres do not live in a different world from people who are in the private sector. They are just as able, just as capable and often faced with some of the more difficult challenges faced by those in the private sector. I am quite confident that they will be able to cope very admirably with this change, which is designed to put private centres on an equal footing with those community centres.

On that question of child care, the government has also made funds available for those centres that just would not be viable because of their location or because of the nature of their community. There is another important initiative to say yes, child care is important for those two-income families but we have actually done something for those people that have one parent at home. We have actually done something for all families in this country and targeted that support in a very effective way.

In fact, this legislation before the House represents part of what could be called a kids' quadrella. We have delivered for kids on four key fronts. This is the centrepiece of it, the family tax initiative. We have the health initiatives with the immunisation programs and improving the complementary nature of the public and private health system, so that
if they need some health care, the health care is there.

We have boosted funding to school education and we have supported parents making choices about their education, just as this family tax initiative supports the choices that parents have to make about how to organise their households. We have also improved the post‐education years, the opportunities that are available to young people. They do not have to go down the path of higher education, even though in my state we still have the equivalent of a full house crowd of the MCG as the number of places in HECS funded universities and then some, if that is your choice. But if you are not academically minded, this government has facilitated your making a choice to go down a different career path. So this is very much a budget about those choices.

The other issue that is worth dwelling on for a moment is a claim prior to the election that the sums of this measure just do not add up. Well, haven't we proven that incorrect. Not only have we secured the funding by making sure that this government is not relying on the bankcard to fund these sorts of initiatives; we have also taken pressure off interest rates and, as I mentioned earlier, delivered to those people of Dunkley, purchasing their homes, a great savings in their mortgage costs. That is a very admirable way to go. We have done these things for one simple reason: because our children are very important. They are the future of this nation, and we must never lose sight of that.

One reason why I am particularly supportive of this bill is that it is putting spending power back in the hands of people who need it most. I very much welcome this family tax initiative, because what we have done is to give families a choice that they can exercise. We have not said to them that we favour one type of family structure or another. What we have done is to facilitate that choice. We have made a decision that the Labor Party just could not quite come at, that is families are best placed to decide how families should be organised.

So we have this quadrella for kids. We have support across the board for families. We have kept some of the worthwhile initiatives
that the former government introduced in the child‐care area. We have taken pressure off interest rates. This is fantastic news for the 32,000 children in Dunkley and their families. They have a chance to be able to cope with the costs and they have a chance to be able to prepare themselves for a better future. Above all, they have the chance of a very secure future, a brighter future because we have a coalition government that understands that families are best placed to manage families, that the choices that families make are made because they take account of their own circumstances. We have put money back in the pockets of those people to facilitate those changes. All of us who believe that families are the most worthwhile institution in our community are beholden to support this bill.

We are not actually talking about a measure that favours any particular part of this country. Perhaps those in the inner suburbs in Melbourne where we have fewer kids than Dunkley might think this is something that favours the suburbs, the heartland of people looking for brighter futures out in the electorate of Dunkley. But what has been shown once again is another measure by a government interested in the long term, interested in the future of this country. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

interject.speaker: ACTING SPEAKER

talk.start.para:
—Order! Yesterday the member for Hotham, the member for O'Connor and the member for Moore in questions to me raised the issue of allocation of questions to Independent members. There are currently 54 non-government members. With the present target of 20 questions per question time, this means 10 questions to non-government members each question time. A non-government member could expect one question in six sitting days or once each 54 questions. I understand that in the previous parliament where there were more non-government members, 67 or 68, there were
also fewer questions each sitting day, generally around 14, which meant that an Independent member could receive one question per nine sitting days.

interject.para: To date, there have been 322 questions to the non-government members on 33 sitting days. Two of the Independent members have each asked five questions, and could expect another, as there have been almost six questions per non-government member. The opposition members defer to their leaders. The Leader of the Opposition has asked 85 questions, while the Deputy Leader has asked 44. In respect of the matter raised by the member for O'Connor, I advise the House that the Whips offices are provided with daily and weekly summaries of the number of questions asked.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, No. 45 is addressed to the Treasurer. My question concerns his statement to the House yesterday that the issuing of redeemable preference shares in Telstra `holds no attraction' to the government. Why didn't the Treasurer, before making that statement, give Senator Harradine the courtesy of a private communication, as both the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Communications said publicly would happen? Was it because of poor organisation or congenital bad manners or because the government might still accept the redeemable preference shares option in some form?

—If we are talking about congenital problems, I would have thought the Deputy Leader of the Opposition displays one every time he asks a question. It is called the inability to get a short sentence out. Yesterday I stated the position of the government on various proposals in relation to Telstra. I was asked a question. I informed the questioner and the House what the position was. Senators and others are putting forward other proposals to the government all the time. Their proposals will be treated with all due seriousness and discussions will be entertained with them, but I thought I stated quite plainly yesterday what the position of the
government would be in relation to one such proposal which was raised with me.

—My question is also addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of the future direction of prices surveillance activities by the government? Will the prices surveillance by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission continue where it is deemed necessary in the future? In particular, what is the government doing in regard to country petrol prices in response to the recommendations of the report by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission on petroleum products?

answer.speaker: Costello, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for her question and for her interest in pricing matters. I inform the House that today I have announced major changes to prices surveillance. The government has accepted a recommendation from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to remove price declarations in relation to beer and cigarettes. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission made such a recommendation on the basis of its finding that these industries were competitive and, indeed, that there was substantial price discounting going on.

answer.para: After receiving that recommendation I sought assurances from the companies concerned that, if the price declarations were removed, they would hold prices to lower than the inflation rate over the next 12 months. Such assurances were given to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and, accordingly, the declarations were revoked today.

I have also announced changes in relation to declarations for steel and BHP and changes in relation to glassware and ACI. In addition, the government has received a report on the declaration in relation to petrol. The report of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has recommended that the declaration be removed next year and that it be removed in the context of other changes in relation to franchising. Let me make it clear, Mr Acting Speaker, that the government will be announcing a coordinated response. Other
ministers and I are preparing a government response at the moment, but as a first step and in recognition of that report I have today written to the automobile associations and asked them in cooperation and in conjunction with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, as recommended by that commission, to engage in price monitoring. The Australian Automobile Association has already identified 100 hot spots where country petrol prices appear excessive which could benefit from transparency in the arrangements.

We welcome moves which are already occurring to allow wider access to oil company terminals. This is the government policy. It was announced before the election. We will be encouraging moves to allow wider access because we believe it will contribute to lowering petrol prices. We also make it clear—because there seems to be quite a deal of interest by the opposition—that we do not recognise the situation which the previous government did that access should be controlled by the Transport Workers Union.

talk.start.para: —Well, it is not. It is controlled by the oil companies.

—It is controlled by the Transport Workers Union under what was called the Laidley agreement: so named because there was a person called Leon Laidley who was denied access by the TWU—the Transport Workers Union. As a response, section 45E was introduced to prevent it. The Labor Party repealed section 45E because when it comes to access, when it comes to freedom of movement, if the ACTU says, `No,' the Labor Party says, `All right.' If the ACTU says, `We don't want access,' the Labor Party says, `We will agree.' You have got a Labor Party that cravenly took its orders from the ACTU in relation to this matter. I am very interested to hear the concern now being expressed about open access. Open access is something that this government supported before the election. It is something that is occurring and that we welcome. This government will make sure that it takes the steps that are required to make sure that every competitive factor is brought to bear to make sure that country petrol prices are kept down.
—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Hon. Maurice Williamson, New Zealand Minister for Transport. On behalf of the House, I extend to him a very warm welcome.

question.speaker: Evans, Gareth, MP

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Does he recall his answer to me in question time last week on the Telstra redeemable preference shares issue? He said:

question.para: The response will be given to Senator Harradine, and I believe that is the courteous way to do it.

As the minister with overall responsibility for asset sales, what steps did he take to give effect to that undertaking of courtesy? What is his response to the Treasurer's breach of that commitment? Has the government concluded its consideration of this issue?

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has made it clear that the government will not be increasing its liabilities. The Treasurer has also made it very clear that the government will manage existing liabilities in the most cost‐effective way. But I am impressed that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition today talks about liabilities and brings up matters relating to raising revenue through debt. What we have had is a 13‐year Labor bankcard binge—13 years of bankcard binge! You have brought the liabilities on this government—

—I take a point of order on relevance. Is it relevant to include that in an answer specifically related to the sale of Telstra when he knows very well that the percentage of GDP in public spending is lower than we had when we came into office 13 years ago.
—There is no point of order. The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

—No wonder the Leader of the Opposition gets upset when we talk about debt. When the Leader of the Opposition was Minister for Finance he presided over the biggest area of growth in government—debt
servicing! Ten million dollars, 7.5 per cent of outlays—all under your particular portfolio management. Is it any wonder the people of Australia were sick and tired of the debt drip that they were hooked on under the management of Labor? As I have said, the Treasurer has made it very clear that we will manage our existing liabilities—inherited from Labor—in the most cost‐effective way.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the minister seen reports of suggestions that a cap should be placed on the amount of damages that the courts can award arising from illegal industrial action? Is such a proposal fair?

answer.speaker: Reith, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —I have seen reports emanating in the last 24 hours from the opposition. I must say I was rather surprised by the proposition, because they are suggesting that there be a limit when people are successful before the courts on the damages that they may be awarded. I suppose I am particularly surprised because the reality is that that is not the law today: that was a proposition that was not acceptable to the previous government. I make that statement in the context of another statement by the shadow minister when he said that, in the management of industrial relations policy, the opposition would not regress from where they were on 2 March.

answer.para: But the reality is that in some key aspects of industrial relations policy they are regressing: not beyond 1993 or 2 March 1996, but into the 1970s and 1980s. Not only are they proposing this absurd proposition; they are backing off on award simplification that the former Prime Minister supported, they are backing off on the junior wage rates exemptions they themselves provided because they wanted to protect jobs; and they are backing off on their position about the benefits of a more flexible labour market for the creation of jobs which the Leader of the Opposition himself espoused back in 1994.

When you have boycott action of the sort that you have got from the MUA—leading to a statement by a member of the Indonesian business community that it is economic suicide for Australia to have to have such
bans imposed by unions—what do we get from the weak Leader of the Opposition? Absolute silence. The reality is that behind this regression in policy the unions are pulling the strings on Labor's industrial relations policy. They are not only picking up some of the key aspects; they are pushing them well back from where they were on 2 March.

Unions are running the election policy. In Lindsay, they are not only running the Leader of the Opposition's policy but also running the election for him. We find today that there are 18 paid union officials of the CEPU running your campaign for you. You might remember the CEPU: they are experts at running campaigns. In fact, you could not look to a more reliable crowd than the CEPU.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker: I draw your attention to standing order 145 concerning relevance. The question asked of the minister concerned proposals for a cap on the amount of damages arising from industrial action. He has strayed from the question and I ask you to draw him back to it.
—That was part of the question. The minister will continue.

—So here you have the ACTU running the ALP's industrial relations policy. We have the ACTU and the CEPU now running the Lindsay by‐election for them. They are the same union that ran part of the state campaign in New South Wales which gave you the broken promises on the tolls and on the Nepean Hospital. The ultimate result of that is that we will have an ex‐Keating minister back in this chamber, if Labor is successful. And who is he going to run? He is going to run you, a weak leader.

—My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. Has the Acting Prime Minister received a copy of a secret report prepared by one of his coalition colleagues which states that the 500 per cent increase in the reef tax poses the greatest danger ever to Queensland's tourism industry and will effectively bring about the destruction of the marine reef tour operators on the Great Barrier Reef and a consequent massive
loss of jobs? Will he support his Queensland coalition colleagues—the members for Leichhardt, Capricornia, Hinkler, Dawson and Herbert—in overturning this appalling decision, rammed through by the Prime Minister and Treasurer?

—I have little to add to the answer I gave yesterday in respect of this matter, other than to point out to the House that I have also seen a copy of a news poll which found that, on the matter of jobs and unemployment, the coalition was doing better than the ALP in the eyes of the people. It is a pretty solid poll result just six months after coming into government. For that matter, on the environment—and the Great Barrier Reef is a critical part of Australia's environment and needs very careful policy settings—what was the finding with regard to who is doing best and who will do best on the environment? The coalition was five per cent ahead of the ALP. While I am at it, I was much attracted to the finding on family issues where the poll revealed the coalition is well ahead.
—On a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker: it is hard to see the relevance in relation to the reef tax but, while he is at it, perhaps he might like to mention health and industrial relations.
—No point of order.
—We know the Leader of the Opposition faces a terrifying shadow cabinet meeting tomorrow when it will be a case of whether Beazley or Melham wins on the matter of Hindmarsh Bridge.
—Melham! Melham!
—Order! Members on my right.

—The budget decision stands. The actual implementation may well be the subject of secret and non-secret reports. I am not in the habit of revealing what goes on in government deliberations, other than to say that, in respect of its implementation, these are matters which are before my colleague the Minister for the Environment and Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Robert Hill.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Is the minister aware of growing support for the government's aged care reform package? Will the reforms match the testing system for hostels introduced by the previous Labor government?

answer.speaker: Moylan, Judi, MP

talk.start.para:
—I thank the honourable member for that question. In fact, a former Labor minister, Mr Gary Johns, made a very balanced and intelligent critique of our government's nursing homes initiative in today's
Australian
. I have the article here with me.
—Tell us what's in it!
—Read it!
—Order! Members on my right.

—Mr Johns is in good company because the consumer groups, the industry groups and the relevant unions all support this government's policy on aged care reform. The article must have knocked the wind clean out of the sails of the shadow minister because I notice she is not on the benches today. In this letter to the editor, the former minister, Mr Johns, supported the government's aged care policy. He said:

answer.para: The fact is that the system already applies to hostels, so why not extend it to nursing homes?

This is precisely what this government, in consultation with industry and consumer groups, has agreed to do. The unification of the nursing home and hostel system is exactly what the residents and their families have been asking for for over a decade. I quote further from Mr Johns's letter to the editor in the
Australian
:
It is entirely fair that those who use those facilities should make a contribution.
I think the welfare state can stand a bit of user‐pays, because the great levelling hand of the system can impose inequities as well as abolish them.
If the burden of the current generation of taxpayers is not to climb too high, then those with assets to pay, at a time when there is little risk that they will need them, should do so.

That is exactly what we are asking the people in the community to do. We are asking the people in the community, if they can afford to make a contribution to their own care, to do so while, at the same time, protecting full pensioners and those in the community who are financially disadvantaged. Another gem from Mr Johns says:

My generation will inherit the largest stock of capital ever in the nation's history, and generally we earn better than our parents. It seems fair, then, to use some of that inheritance to keep up a good quality of care for those who need it.

Mr Johns has obviously analysed in depth this government's aged care reform package. He knows good policy when he sees it and, more importantly, he is prepared to publicly support its introduction in the interests of aged care reform in this country. Labor knows it will result in significant improvements in the quality of life for older Australians. Labor knows it is fair and that it is equitable.

This government has listened to the people. By contrast, the shadow minister, the member for Jagajaga, who is not here today has not listened. She is out there scaremongering. That is what she is doing. She was the consultant to the former government because Labor sat on its hands and did nothing to address the capital crisis in nursing homes. She is not listening now. She is conducting a cynical scare campaign against the interests of older Australians.

talk.start.para: —Who is `she'?

—I have already referred to the member for Jagajaga, the shadow minister. Evidence of their lack of commitment is right here in black and white. In Labor's policy document eight paragraphs set out how they were going to fix the crisis in aged care—a system that is falling down in this country. Eight paragraphs is the best they could give in their policy document on how they were going to fix the aged care system. This is evidence of their lack of commitment.

answer.para: The Treasurer was absolutely right on Tuesday when he said that the opposition were opportunistic, incoherent, divided and, more particularly, irrelevant—they are irrelevant in a policy sense, totally irrelevant. Mr Johns also went on to state:

break.para: The taxpayer has already paid for the enormous amount of care and attention that the elderly receive. They pay through Medicare, the public hospitals, home and community care, Meals On Wheels, carers' pensions, and so on.

This is your own former minister whom I am quoting from. Again, Mr Johns's comments accurately reflect the priorities of this government. We have retained Medicare in its entirety. We have provided a six per cent growth in home and community care. We have increased the community aged care packages by 59 per cent. We have provided $36.2 million for the national respite for carers action plan, and we have addressed the capital crisis in nursing homes.

This government will not resile from its commitments to the frail and elderly in our community. We have inherited a nursing home system that is in crisis, that is falling down. The Labor government ignored that. We accept the responsibility to fix the problems and we will.

talk.start.para: —Don't go too far away, Minister. My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Seeing as the minister is so enamoured with Mr Johns's comments, does the minister agree with Mr Johns that the coalition's imposition of an average $26,000 entry contribution to nursing homes is `the nearest thing we will get to those death duties . . . and it was a Coalition Government that did it'?
—That just shows that the Labor Party had a hidden agenda. It was their hidden agenda for death taxes.

question.block.title: Single Aviation Market Between Australia and New Zealand

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Can the minister advise the House as to what measures the government has taken to overcome the blot on Australian and New Zealand relations caused by the former government's arbitrary withdrawal from a single aviation market arrangement between those two countries?

answer.speaker: Sharp, John, MP

talk.start.para:
—I thank the honourable member for North Sydney for his question. I
am very pleased to be able to inform the House that earlier today Minister Williamson, the Minister for Transport from New Zealand, and I signed a very historic and landmark agreement for a single aviation market between Australia and New Zealand. This agreement for a single aviation market that we have signed today enhances our closer economic relations between Australia and New Zealand. CER has done so much to enhance the economic growth of both countries.

answer.para: What the single aviation market does is enables airlines in this country to operate domestic services in New Zealand and vice versa. This is an important micro-economic reform—the winners of which will be the consumers of airline services in Australia and New Zealand. It will do that by creating a more competitive environment for airline services to operate in. It will also provide consumers with more choice and, ultimately, that will result in lower prices as a consequence of the completion of this agreement.

What it also does, as the honourable member for North Sydney intimated in the question, is repairs the relationship that was so badly damaged by the previous Labor government. At a quarter to midnight in 1994, just a few days before the single aviation market was due to be implemented, the previous government axed that agreement at the last moment, having had two years of negotiation, two years of goodwill—negotiation between two countries that have traditionally had the friendliest and most cooperative of relationships.

The former government undertook to give an agreement to establish a single aviation market between Australia and New Zealand. A few days before that was due to be implemented, what did they do? Despite all of the goodwill, despite all of the cooperation between those two countries, a few days before implementation the former government axed it without warning. In a most discourteous fashion the former government faxed a message to the New Zealand Minister of Transport and without further explanation axed that agreement.

That did damage to the relationship between Australia and New Zealand. This government,
within a matter of months of being re-elected to office, has been able to repair that damage and today is the living evidence of the repair of that damage. It is a fascinating thing for members of this House to consider the fact that the minister responsible in that former Labor government for doing more harm to Australia's relations with New Zealand was none other than the member for Kingsford‐Smith, who is too ashamed to be here in the House today to face up to the Minister for Transport of New Zealand, who is here in the gallery today.

The member for Kingsford‐Smith is ashamed of it because he knows his own actions were disgraceful. Not only that, but it is also interesting for the members of this House to consider who, after this enormous diplomatic disaster was created by the member for Kingsford‐Smith, this Labor opposition appointed as their foreign affairs spokesman—none other than the member for Kingsford‐Smith, the man who did more damage to our good relationship with New Zealand than anybody else in the history of this country.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order that goes to relevance: there is only so much crawling and showing off he needs to do in this place. It is not relevant to raise the issue of the opposition. He is dealing with contemporary government policy and that is what he ought to stick with.
—Resume your seat.

—The Leader of the Opposition is just embarrassed that it took six months of a coalition government to do what they could not do in 13 years. Today is a landmark day, a day when we restore our relationship with New Zealand and a day when the consumers of aviation services in both countries get an enormous win.

—My question is again directed to the Acting Prime Minister. Are you aware that, in the Mackay
Daily Mercury
of 29 August 1996, the member for Dawson said in reference to the 500 per cent increase in the reef tax that:

break.para: . . . neither myself, any backbenchers, or even the Tourism Minister, knew about this tax until it was announced.

Does he recall denying all knowledge of the reef tax increase on ABC Far North Queensland on 20 August 1996? In the light of strident opposition to this massive tax increase, will the government move to have this decision overturned or will the government betray the Queensland tourism industry and adopt the same dismissive attitude of the Prime Minister, Treasurer and Minister for the Environment?

answer.speaker: Fischer, Tim, MP

talk.start.para: —This was a matter announced as part of the budget outcome on 20 August. I am not going to reveal the deliberations of government in the immediate lead‐up to that budget.

answer.para:
Opposition members interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —I lost five out of the last eight days of July on it, so you cannot accuse me of that. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is a matter which I know has attracted the attention of the member for Hinkler, the member for Leichhardt, the member for Herbert and the member for Dawson. It is an authority which has certain responsibilities which are carefully monitored by the tourism industry and by local federal members. I believe that should be the case in all the circumstances.

answer.para: As I have said before, we are not standing still with regard to the tourism industry in Queensland or regional Queensland. In fact, announced in that same budget was the granting of full rate access for the tourism industry to the export market development grants scheme.

I just wish you big bullies sitting here in this part of the front bench would occasionally give the poor old shadow minister for trade a go. I have been here for four days this week at the dispatch box and you still won't give him a go.

The export market development grants scheme is being continued by the federal government. The export market development grants scheme currently has the tourism industry at a callous, dismissive half rate of entry. We are going to increase that to a full
rate and we are proud of that budget outcome. These are matters, in terms of their implementation, which are the subject of further dialogue with my colleagues the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Robert Hill, and the Minister for Tourism, Minister John Moore.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the New South Wales Labor government decision on the future of the timber industry, due shortly, likely to make draconian or unnecessary cuts in timber resources in New South Wales? Will the federal government take steps to ensure flexibility in the timber policy that will protect the future of timber communities of New South Wales, the communities that the Labor governments always abandon and neglect?

—Mr Acting Speaker, on the point of order: I draw your attention to standing order 144, which states that questions shall not contain hypothetical matter. I put to you that this is a hypothetical question.
—It is not a hypothetical question.

answer.speaker: Anderson, John, MP

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I note that he has a great interest in these matters. In fact, he is here because he understands the importance of these regional issues and jobs in regional Australia. This is in direct contrast to the person whose place he took and those on the other side, of whom there are now so few.

answer.para: The issue raised is an important one. It goes to the heart of a matter for which the New South Wales state government has primary responsibility. The federal government is absolutely committed to proper process, particularly in terms of establishing our objectives—a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. We have clearly indicated to New South Wales, who have undertaken a lot of preliminary work in this matter, that we expect the process to be undertaken with integrity and with minimum compromise in terms of any early or pre-emptive decisions by the New South Wales government.

break.para: The day before yesterday in this place, I made it quite plain that the government will proceed carefully, taking full and proper account of the social and economic consequences that would flow from locking away large tracts of forest. We will not be party to the decimation of rural communities. That is, in essence, the important point in all of this.

We do seek a cooperative approach. We have been patient. We have put up $60 million for the FISAP program. We do want a proper and balanced outcome. Our commitment to the program is clearly evidenced by the $48 million found to progress the RFAs and by the new regulations for woodchip exports, which will provide certainty and stability for this industry so troubled in recent years by what it got from the other side. Those in the industry are telling us that for the first time in years they feel confident about investing and value adding. That means jobs and prosperity for regional and rural Australia, which you deprived them of. It is a good outcome for industry and it is a good outcome for the environment.

On that matter, I would like to comment that there do seem to be some problems on the other side in getting their act together. When we indicated where we would be going in terms of woodchip licensing arrangements, the shadow minister for the environment put out a press statement full of shock, horror stuff which said, in part:
But the reality is the coalition is allowing open slather on our native forests by stealth.

That is not the case. That is not what we are doing. It is very interesting to note that just two days before that the shadow minister for resources and energy wrote in a letter to me that it was pointless and unnecessary for the industry to give me an assurance that no extra tree would be felled if we increased the woodchip volumes because `the trees are going to be felled anyway.' There is no agreement and no capacity to get a policy position together there.

I note also in that regard that there is a certain organisation that they are reluctant to distance themselves from over there. They are reluctant to distance themselves from the CFMEU. The CFMEU is not reluctant to
distance themselves from the opposition. On this matter, Mr Trevor Smith of that union had this to say:

The ALP's response was big on green rhetoric and small on accuracy. Most telling was the lack of consultation with the union on this issue by any of the relevant shadow ministers before public statements were made. If they are this arrogant now, what would they be like if they were returned to government?
The union was also highly critical of the shadow minister for the environment, Carmen Lawrence. It said:
She demonstrated in 1995 that she was prone to highly inaccurate statements concerning forest issues, and was found out by her own cabinet colleagues.

That was Bob Collins flying over there in a light plane so he could take photographs of what was really happening to demonstrate to his colleagues in cabinet that Carmen Lawrence was way off the mark. The union went on to say:
It's a shame Carmen hasn't improved.

talk.start.para: —I would like to ask a question of the Treasurer. Mr Treasurer, in respect of your budget decision regarding the abolition of section 23(pa) of the taxation act, did you realise the retrospective nature of your actions? Did this concern you or do you merely share the Prime Minister's penchant for retrospective taxation?

—That measure is not retrospective to any degree whatsoever. It is a measure that applies to prospecting rights. There are certain prospecting rights that have been exempted from assessability under tax in the past. There was no rationale as to why some should be exempt and some should not, except to say that it was introduced at a time when it was thought that Australia had severe shortages of some of those base metals. That was proved not to be the case. This was a question of rectifying an anomaly and it will apply prospectively.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Has the minister seen press reports concerning evidence before the
board of inquiry into the tragic Blackhawk accident? Can the minister inform the House of the procedures which are set in place to ensure that any findings which impact on safety are immediately acted upon?

answer.speaker: McLachlan, Ian, MP

talk.start.para: —I have seen the reports. We have had many media requests in my office and other offices, including Minister Bishop's office, on the evidence that is coming before the board. I wish to make it absolutely clear—
—Did you attend those?

—It is quite a serious subject, I would have thought. I wish to make it absolutely clear that we will not be making any comment on any evidence that goes before the board while it is examining this tragic accident. When the board has finished its inquiry in December, and no sooner, we will deliberate on it. I would like to say that the remarks made by the opposition spokesman this morning along similar lines were much appreciated. In this whole matter I will say that we have had quite a deal of help from the shadow minister.

answer.para: There is one further matter. During the inquiry some matters of safety come up. If there is any information which comes to light during the course of the inquiry which impacts on safety, the Australian Defence Force will not wait until the final report. The president of the board is to immediately report to the Chief of the General Staff and any implications that come out of that report which might be revealed during the course of the board inquiry will be taken up and remedial action acted upon immediately.

We are also determined that any necessary remedial steps which will be put in place to minimise the risk of our servicemen during their extremely rigorous and risky training, as the Leader of the Opposition said, on the edge, will be put in place if necessary to sustain our counter‐terrorist capability.

talk.start.para:
—My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. Has the Acting Prime Minister's attention been drawn to media comment made on the
11 AM
program on 17 September this year when the member
for Leichhardt said, `Without question the 500 per cent increase in the reef tax would result in job losses and tourists travelling to destinations other than the Great Barrier Reef?' Will he support calls by the member for Leichhardt for this massive tax hike to be revoked?
—I have nothing to add to my previous answers to this question.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware of a newspoll conducted by the
Australian
showing the electorate's overwhelming support for the government's economic management, including unemployment and despite the tough budget?

answer.speaker: Costello, Peter, MP

talk.start.para:
—Strange as it may seem, I have actually seen this poll. My eye just happened to be caught by a headline in the
Australian
today—`Coalition best for economy: newspoll'. It said:

answer.para: The electorate has given the Coalition overwhelming support on economic management—including unemployment—despite the toughest Budget in living memory.
The reason why the electorate has received the budget so well is that the electorate knows that this is a government which is determined to confront Australia's long-term problems.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: I ask that the Acting Prime Minister not be reading papers in the House.
—From my observation, the Acting Prime Minister was glancing at his press clipping, and is in order.

—It is interesting that, as we wind up the first two-week session after the presentation of the budget, the Labor Party's attack on the budget has collapsed. In fact, if one sat through question time over the last two weeks, one would have found it almost impossible to get a question from the shadow Treasurer relating to the macro‐economic outlook. It is impossible to get any statement from the Leader of the Opposition as to an alternative economic program. It is impossible to get any decent critique in relation to the budget measures. All we see is little dribs and drabs and playing personal agendas from this defeated and divided
opposition coming forward on their own little pet projects.
