answer.para: We had the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs defying the Leader of the Opposition on the Hindmarsh bridge. We have the notoriously absent spokeswoman for nursing homes running her own agenda against the Keating policy on nursing homes. We have the Manager of Opposition Business coming in here every day with only one thing on his mind: how can he show his credentials to become shadow Treasurer?

At the end of the day, you do not have to show your credentials. There is no contest; it is the other fellow who is making sure that you are going to get the job. We have the shadow Treasurer standing up every now and again trying to make the Leader of the Opposition look decisive.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of relevance: perhaps he would make his answer a bit more relevant if he said why the industrial relations end of that particular survey gave him particular personal satisfaction.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I take it back—the deputy leader does not make the leader look decisive. We see in relation to all of the economic indicators that the Australian public have said that they endorse the measures that the coalition government has taken. The coalition leads on taxation, interest rates, inflation and the balance of payments. It leads on all of the key indicators that determine the way in which people in Australia live.

answer.para: This is because the people in Australia have recognised a government that was prepared to take on the hard issues. They have recognised a government that was prepared not to stand by and say, `Seventy billion dollars of inherited debt over the last five budgets; we cannot do anything about it,' but to stand up and to take the measures to fix it. This is a government which is going to secure the future for Australia, and this is an opposition which is suffering from RDS—relevance deprivation syndrome—which is self-confessed, self-diagnosed and self-inflicted.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: this is around the world for sixpence, but it would surely be relevant if he was going to do that to explain the $10 billion worth of budget tightening that he opposed as a meretricious player back in the previous parliament.

—What better intervention could demonstrate the irrelevance of the opposition in relation to this. This is a government that has a plan for Australia. This is a government that has a program for Australia. And we will secure that economic future.

—My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. Has the Acting Prime Minister's attention been drawn to the reported comment by the Liberal candidate for Lindsay, Jackie Kelly, in the 17 September issue of the
Penrith Press
that the funding cuts to the University of Western Sydney were `really gains'? Does the Acting Prime Minister endorse the accuracy of Miss Kelly's comment in the light of a report in today's
Sydney Morning Herald
that the cuts, together with the government's refusal to supplement salary increases, will compel the university to slash spending in some faculties by between 10 and 20 per cent over the next two years, leading to the loss of hundreds of jobs and many courses? Does the Acting Prime Minister concur with Miss Kelly's viewpoint, or does he accept that staff representatives from the university are nearer the mark when they say that the cuts would be devastating and a disaster for the university and the region?

answer.speaker: Fischer, Tim, MP

talk.start.para: —The first thing I want to know about Lindsay is why this mob chose to re‐endorse a failed Keating minister as their candidate for the seat of Lindsay. They even talk about quotas and more women coming forward as a result of the great deal stitched up at a Hobart conference by Carmen Lawrence—who, by the way, was the last female candidate they presented at a by-election. Some outcome.

para.break: The truth of the matter is that we have an outstanding candidate representing the coali tion in the federal seat of Lindsay. I wish her well, and all strength to her right arm with regard to a raft of policy issues she very effectively raised from this seat in the House of Representatives, to which she deservedly can expect to return after the by-election vote.

answer.para: I strongly support the detailed decision making of the courageous Minister, Senator Amanda Vanstone, and the way it was carried out. I will give two examples in this regard. The first example is an outstanding provincial university, the University of Central Queensland, headquartered on Rockhampton, which has countless activities at places like Gladstone, Mackay and Emerald. That university received quite a major increase in the higher education budget allocations, as did several others.

I might add that there was scope for some change. I think that members on both sides of the House might agree with me in this regard. The second and final example I will give relates to the magnificent centre of Broome, in the electorate of Kalgoorlie, in Western Australia. There is a very good story to be dealt with as to why vice-chancellors have a little bit to answer for in contributing to the wellbeing and use of taxpayers' dollars with regard to higher education. Some years ago, the James Cook University, in North Queensland—

talk.start.para: —That is north.

—Mr Acting Speaker, my point of order relates to relevance and perhaps to the Acting Prime Minister's geography. It seems to me that Broome is an awful way away from western Sydney, about which he was asked.
—We all know that, thank you.

—I have a great deal of concern for the higher educational opportunities of people in the western suburbs of Sydney. I happen to barrack for the Penrith Panthers, in respect of that particular football code, and the Sydney Swans and they are going to win next Saturday night. Bad luck, Treasurer!

answer.para:
I come back to Broome, and it is relevant to the budget allocation for the western
Sydney university. It mirrors what has gone wrong with higher education allocations. I noted with interest that James Cook University decided to have a presence in Broome. I have no objection to that. What did that trigger? Suddenly the vice-chancellors of Perth decided they had to go to Broome. So what happened? You had the Edith Cowan University go up there, withdraw and then go back there to have a presence in Broome. Then the Notre Dame University, beyond government, I accept, also had to go to Broome. Not satisfied with that, the Curtin University had to have a presence in Broome as well. So it ended up with four universities.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I accept that Broome is to the west of Sydney, but it is not the University of Western Sydney. If he is going to talk about James Cook University, he might point out the cuts that are being imposed on that institution as well.
—The Acting Prime Minister is illustrating his answer.

—I have a great deal of respect for the vice-chancellors of Australian universities, but they have to prove to the nation why the largess and the decision making associated with the allocation of taxpayers' resources was allowed to run free for a period in the 1980s and 1990s. We are doing something about it, and we are proud of it.
—He went all over Australia and got nowhere!
—Order! I would just like to say to the honourable member for Banks that his deposit of goodwill is running out. It is becoming overdrawn.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. Minister, in light of the number of service personnel leaving the defence forces, is the government taking any steps to halt this decline? If so, what effect will it have on service strength?

answer.speaker: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

talk.start.para:
—I thank the member for her question. It is significant to point out that, in
the six months we have been in government, we have taken the actions which the previous government failed to take which would lead to an increase in the morale and a cessation of the growing numbers of those leaving the defence forces. There are half a dozen things which I would like to mention to the House on this occasion which we have already put in place and which are important.

answer.para: The first is our commitment to increase the mortgage loan available from $40,000 to $80,000, which was introduced and passed through this House and is now in the Senate. Secondly, there was a commitment on spouse employment. We said we would create a database. We are going further than that and also looking at a proposal which is operating in Darwin now whereby we use private firms to place spouses of service personnel into employment.

talk.start.para: —Have you got any jobs, though?

—Yes, indeed we have got jobs for them. In the family support program we undertook to increase the amount from $20,000 for specific areas to $50,000. We have already allocated the first round of payments in this current year of $600,000. There will be a second round of $300,000, which will meet the commitment that we made prior to the election.

answer.para:
In the important area of child care, we said that we would go on and, in accordance with our very specific commitment given before the election, we would provide more child-care centres. Accordingly, there will be further centres in Darwin, RAAF Base Pearce, RAAF Base Tindal, HMAS
Albatross
and Enoggera. Part of the Russell redevelopment will have an extra child-care centre. An extension to the existing facility at Amberley will enable the centre to offer occasional child care. Funding is also being provided for a number of family day care schemes to ensure their services are accessible to defence families.

para.break: I now move to the question of members without families. There has been a long-time campaign from members without families to be treated in an even-handed manner with members with families. That relates particu larly to the question of storage and removal allowances, which I have announced and which became effective from 10 September. Together with that went other allowance which members without families had been campaigning for for a long time, which the previous government had made noises about, but had never delivered upon.

answer.para: The remaining point I would like to make relates to pilot retention. There has been a lot of concern about the number of pilots who have left the RAAF. Accordingly, we are looking at a number of measures to increase the retention rate of pilots. We have in the budget an allocation of $17 million for retention schemes, and that includes a bonus payment scheme, but we are also looking at a range of incentives which are attractive to ensure that pilots will remain within the RAAF and not be lost at the rate that was established under the previous government.

I generally want to say that I have found in the area of defence personnel that the former government presided over a decline in morale. It led to the determination and the commitment that John Howard expressed that defence would not be cut in the last budget. We upheld this commitment.

talk.start.para: —It was cut!
—It was not cut. The simple reason we did not make any cuts in the defence budget was that we believed the previous government cut, cut, cut, cut to the point that morale was very low.

answer.para: The bringing about of the six items I have mentioned here is only the beginning because, importantly, there has been a change in philosophy. We do not regard the Defence Force as public servants in uniform. We regard them as a very special force of people who give service to this nation and will always be recognised as such by this government.

talk.start.para:
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Now that the minister, in conjunction with the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, is responsible for health insurance premiums, will he give the House an assurance that he will not
approve any increases in premiums for families, which are caused by the reductions for singles and childless couples that he announced yesterday? Does he agree that increased premiums for families caused by reductions for singles and childless couples would undermine community rating for families?

answer.speaker: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

talk.start.para:
—I am thrilled to get a question because, some 56 questions ago in
Hansard
, we had from the shadow minister that they `are going to pursue this in this debate this afternoon, in question time tomorrow and throughout every day'.
—What date was that?
—That was on Tuesday, 10 September 1996. So I am delighted that the shadow minister has been able to ask me a question.

answer.para: He does raise a valid point though, and that is that I have sought assurances that any new products would, in fact, be independent and not linked to any other products. I have been assured that single parent families have an enormously low take-up of private health insurance; that any new products that come onto the market would be priced to attract them; and the price of those would be quite independent of any other products—and I certainly will not be allowing or approving increases in family products that were the basis of it because that is contrary to the assurances that I have been given.

question.block.title: Pine Rivers High School: Vocational Education

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the minister aware of a proposal in my electorate of Dickson to utilise the facilities of the Pine Rivers State High School to provide an integrated training program for potential apprentices both in student hours and after school hours using flexible after‐hours training for the unemployed? Is the minister able to indicate his support for such a program, particularly given its enthusiastic endorsement from local businesses?

answer.speaker: Kemp, Dr David, MP

talk.start.para:
—I thank the member for Dickson for his question. I am indeed aware of the
exciting programs being planned for the Pine Rivers High School, which I was fortunate enough to visit with the member earlier this month.

answer.para: This school has a great commitment to provide vocational education courses for its students. It has done so for some years and has some 170 students participating in various vocational education programs. But what impressed me most about the visit to the school was the tremendous enthusiasm of the principal and the staff of the school for the vocational education initiatives that the government announced in the budget and, in particular, for the tremendous opportunities that are opening up for schools through the school based apprenticeships and part‐apprenticeships and traineeships which can be located in schools and organised with local small businesses.

The member will be aware, as the staff of the school were aware, that the government has allocated some $187 million in the budget to encourage the development of these programs. As schools around Australia, such as Pine Rivers High, pick up the government's initiatives and run with them, we are going to see an enormous number of opportunities opening up for students who were consistently disadvantaged by the policies of the previous government. That 30 per cent of students who generally do not complete year 12 are going to gain opportunities that they did not receive throughout the entire 13 years of Labor. These were students who were neglected. They are now having programs put in place which will assist them.

I am pleased to be able to inform the member that, to provide a coordinator to bring the school and the local business community together, an enhancement grant of $49,000 is being provided by the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation. I am aware that the school is also talking with the local branch of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs for funding possibly through another program, the OLMA program, to help unemployed people.

para.break: The fact is that we have here an enormous opportunity for these students, and I congratu late the member on the initiative that he has taken in stimulating the schools in his electorate to take advantage of these. I know that this is shared across the government membership. There is a tremendous commitment across the membership of the government benches to work with their local communities, to work with local small businesses, to work with their local schools to bring communities and schools which have been divided for many years together to take advantage of these initiatives.

answer.para: This is certainly a very positive feature of the government's program. It is one which contrasts very markedly with the neglect of the apprenticeship and traineeship system under the previous government.

question.block.title: Proceeds Of Crime: Drug Education Programs

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the decision in the budget to direct recoveries made under the proceeds of crime legislation into general revenue rather than to public health and, in particular, drug education programs, as was the case under the previous government. Does the minister share the opinion of the government that it is spending too much money on drug education; and, if not, why have drug education programs been cut back in this way?

answer.speaker: Williams, Daryl, MP

talk.start.para: —Let us get the facts straight. The present arrangement in relation to the confiscated assets trust fund, which is administered under the Proceeds of Crime Act, is that half of the residue is allocated to drug education and drug strategy measures and that the other half is devoted to law enforcement measures.

answer.para:
What is proposed under the budget is that there will be the retention of the existing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the states for the sharing of proceeds of joint operations; there will be an introduction of international Commonwealth sharing arrangements for joint operations involving international agencies; and there will be a commitment of a fixed sum to drug strategies out of the residue and the balance, which was previously committed to either some drug
strategy or law enforcement, will go into consolidated revenue.
So this will enable the government to devote specific funds to specific purposes and not have funds in a general fund which is not appropriated in any way. It is a more efficient management of money.

talk.start.para: —I have a supplementary question that arises from the minister's answer.

interject.speaker: ACTING SPEAKER

talk.start.para: —Order! Just resume your seat for a moment. It may assist the House if I address what I perceive to be some misconceptions concerning the asking of supplementary questions. One misconception is related to the frequency of supplementary questions being asked. A belief appears to have developed that the chair will allow a supplementary question to be answered on a irregular basis. This became apparent yesterday when five supplementary questions were asked arising from eight initial questions coming from the opposition and the first four supplementary questions were not allowed.

interject.para: The Leader of the Opposition is recorded as indicating that the question of the chair's discretion with regard to the answering of supplementary questions is absolute. I agree with that statement but add that the chair's discretion with the asking of supplementary questions is also absolute.

Another misconception relates to the purpose of supplementary questions. Standing order 151 indicates that they are to elucidate an answer. On this basis, supplementary questions should arise out of a minister's answer. Thus, I would not expect to allow a supplementary question to a question which, in my opinion, was fully answered. Normally, I would not allow a supplementary question to a minister who had referred the first question to another minister, as a referral of this kind does not constitute an answer.

I add that, during the time I have been Acting Speaker, I have allowed 15 supplementary questions to be asked and, of these, six have proceeded to answer. I consider that the honourable member's question has been fully answered and I will not hear the supplementary question.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Can the minister inform the House of the benefits for Australian tourism operators and businesses from the changes to the EMDG scheme announced in the budget recently?

answer.speaker: Moore, John, MP

talk.start.para: —The government has delivered on its election promises to the tourist industry in full measure. In doing this the government has from 1 July 1996 extended to all tourist operators the eligibility for promotional expenditure. The minimum expenditure threshold has been lowered from $30,000 to $20,000. By doing this, single service tourist providers are included in the scheme at 50 per cent. The Labor Party previously maintained that at a 25 per cent rate.

answer.para: The extension of the use of the EMDG scheme is enormously important to tourist operators throughout Australia. In recognition of the small and the medium sized business operators in Australia, which are predominant within the tourist industry, we have enabled individuals to band together so that they are eligible for the $20,000 that the scheme provides. These are very extensive additions and well worthwhile recalling.

While I am at it, can I point to some good news that is occurring in the tourist area. Only yesterday a press release was put out by my office in relation to international visitors to Australia. This showed that some 3.7 million visitors came to Australia in 1995, an increase of 11 per cent over the previous year. The expenditure in Australia by international visitors in 1995 totalled some $6.3 billion, and this did not include airfares or prepaid packages. On top of that, it is worth pointing out that international tourism generates export earnings in Australia of something of the order of $14 billion a year, accounting for nearly 13 per cent of total export earnings.

Australia is very fortunate indeed to have such a vibrant and successful industry. Extending the export market development grant to the tourist industry as a whole will make an enormous difference to their promotional activities.

talk.start.para:
—Mr Acting Speaker, after 80 questions for the week, over 10 supplementaries and 21 questions happily answered by me, I ask that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
.

question.speaker: Beazley, Kim, MP

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, my question goes to the statement that you just made on the handling of supplementary questions. You referred to my remarks in which I said that your discretion over the acceptance of a supplementary question or the rejection of it was absolute. Then you took that a point further—a point further, I would suggest, than Mr Halverson did or than that standing orders provide.

question.para: The logic of the standing orders and the logic of Mr Halverson's position to this point has been that, before he could make a determination that a question had been fully answered by the minister, he would hear the supplementary question and make a judgment at that point.

Could I ask you to refer your consideration of this to Mr Halverson upon his return, because I do believe that your ruling is at variance with the ruling that he brought down on the position he took on handling supplementary questions.

Of course, you have all his powers whilst in the chair, but, generally speaking, the Speaker is the person who makes the definitive rulings in relation to handling matters relating to the standing orders. Mr Halverson should put himself in that position, seeing as it appears that you have tightened his interpretation. He ought to have an opportunity to consider that matter himself.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. While I personally see no inconsistency whatsoever between the ruling I have just given and the rulings and actions of the Speaker, I will certainly be pleased to consult with him on the basis of your question when he returns.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I have a question for you. Could you advise the House—if necessary, on notice—when was the last time that a Speaker elected during the term of a Labor government ever allowed a supplementary question.
—I thank the honourable member for his question. I think the answer is that they never have been, but I will check the records and, if need be, I will advise the House further.

speech.speaker: Martin, Stephen, MP

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the member for Cunningham moving forthwith:
That this House censures the government for its failure to address the problems of the Queensland Tourism industry, and;

(1)
notes the vocal opposition in their own electorates of the members for Leichhardt, Capricornia, Dawson, Herbert and Hinkler to the 500 per cent increase in the reef tax;

(2)
endorses the opposition to the government's massive reef tax increase because:

(a)
the 500 per cent increase poses the greatest danger to the Queensland tourism industry ever;

(b)
the increase in the reef tax will effectively bring about the destruction of the Marine Reef Tour Operators on the Great Barrier Reef;

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Is it not the case that you take questions to yourself first, following on from question time, before this is done?
—No. The honourable member for Cunningham is in order. Resume your seat.
—I will continue:

speech.para:
(c)
the 500 per cent tax increase damages the credibility of both Prime Minister John Howard and the Government because they are breaching an election commitment not to raise taxes;

(d)
the reef tax hike will cost tourism operators in Queensland millions of dollars and cause job losses;

(e)
the Howard Government is using the tax hike as a crutch to reduce or stop funding to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority;

(f)
without question, there will be job reductions, tourists will visit other destinations such as Indonesia, the Solomons, Guam and Hawaii and the impact of this decision on the business community where people in private enterprise are working on very tight margins and on minimum staff needs to be considered;

(3)
condemns the Government for this very bad policy decision which will cause so much damage to the Queensland Tourism Industry and cost jobs; and

(4)
calls on the Government to immediately abandon its plans to impose a 500 per cent increase in the reef tax.

para.tab: That the member be not further heard.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Bevis, Arch, MP

talk.start.para: —This is an important issue for Queensland and Australia and for the tourism industry—

speech.para: That the member be not further heard.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker—
—You haven't got the call. Resume your seat. I call the Leader of the House.

speech.speaker: Reith, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —The reason the government has rejected this proposal is that—

speech.para: That the member be not further heard.

para.tab: That the question be now put.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, over the last few days, there has been a number of questions asked of you in relation to newspapers and newspaper clippings.
—I will be making a statement at the conclusion of question time.

—And generally concerning greater facilities available to members of the Senate compared with those in this House. On 22 August, the right honourable member for New England asked a question of the Speaker concerning greater resources given in the budget to the Senate compared with the House of Representatives, and the Speaker said that he was going to respond in detail. I know the Speaker is overseas at the moment but, as almost a month has elapsed, I was wondering when members on both sides of the House might receive a substantive answer.

—I counsel the honourable member for Fisher to be patient. An answer is being prepared. As the right
honourable gentleman asked it of Speaker Halverson, we are awaiting his return before the answer is given.

—My question relates to the ruling you have given in relation to supplementary questions. Given, Mr Acting Speaker, that you said the purpose of a supplementary question was to seek clarification arising out of an answer, how can you consider a question is fully answered until you have heard what the clarification is being sought?

—I thank the honourable for his question, but I say to him that, having heard the question and having heard the answer, it was my decision and my opinion that the question was fully answered. I stand by that decision.

—Just a further point: if in fact the member was rising to seek clarification arising out of the answer, how could you consider it fully answered unless you have heard what it is he is seeking to be clarified?

—I refer the honourable member to the
Hansard
of today. He will see that I did not say `clarification'; I said `elucidation'.

—Mr Acting Speaker, have you considered the paper that was sent to your office today in relation to the interpretation and application of standing order 151 relating to supplementary questions? Given the disruption that has occurred to the flow of questions arising out of supplementary questions, will you consult with Mr Speaker with a view to reconsidering the rulings that have been made?
—I have seen the pieces of paper the honourable member alludes to. I have given instructions for an answer to be provided to you suggesting that I would refer it to the Procedure Committee.

—I do not want to belabour this point but, given you have undertaken to the Leader of the Opposition to further reflect on this with Speaker Halverson, could I ask
you to reflect on the point I have just made—whether it relates to a clarification or an elucidation?
—I thank the honourable member for his question.

question.speaker: Georgiou, Petro, MP

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, is there any obligation on Commonwealth government agencies to ensure that statements made in their annual reports are correct? Is there a normal procedure for authorities to correct any errors which might be made in their reports to this parliament?

question.para: Specifically, I refer you to the National Crime Authority's annual report 1994-95, which states in matter 10 that in Victoria income tax assessments involving the target group of companies were amended by approximately $26 million. Fosters Brewing Co., the company of which the amended assessments were reportedly raised, has denied the accuracy of the NCA's assertion.

Since section 61(6) of the National Crime Authority Act requires the minister to table the report in the parliament and since the report was tabled in the House on 30 November 1995, can you please determine and advise the House whether the NCA's advice to the parliament that in matter 10 in Victoria income tax assessments involving the target group of companies were amended by approximately $26 million was correct? If it was inaccurate, has any attempt been made to rectify the error?

talk.start.para: —I will take on notice the question raised by the honourable member for Kooyong so far as elements of the question come within the administrative responsibility of the Speaker.

—On indulgence, Mr Acting Speaker, the member for Kooyong has drawn to my attention the matter to which he has just referred. I have asked for advice from my department and the NCA. I will provide what advice I can. In doing that, I think I have to bear in mind, and of course any answer you give would also have to reflect, the obligations on people who have access to information in relation to the tax affairs of
citizens under the tax act and under the National Crime Authority Act.

—As the Attorney-General was rising to his feet he may not have heard the second part of my answer to the question. I will repeat it: I am taking on notice the question so far as elements of the question come within the administrative responsibility of the Speaker. That will be as far as our consideration goes.

—Mr Acting Speaker, my question to you goes to standing order 107. I note that you had circulated in the chamber this afternoon your choice of the matter of public importance, standing in the name of our colleague the honourable member for Parramatta. You would be aware that I also had submitted to you a matter of public importance in respect of the reef tax. Given that we have on this side been endeavouring to debate it through suspension of standing orders yesterday and today and we have in fact tried to move a censure of the government this afternoon, can I just ask you the reasons where you considered in your opinion that that particular matter was most urgent and important in accordance with standing order 107?

answer.speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

talk.start.para: —Successive speakers in this parliament have never given their reasons—

answer.para:
Mr Leo McLeay interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —The only reason that is pertinent is: `in the opinion of the Speaker is most urgent and important'. It was my judgment that this one was the most urgent and important.
—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: there was an offensive remark made in respect of your decision by the member for—
—You can't even remember who it was.

—No-one knows who you are. But the member sitting on the front bench referred to your decision as being at the direction of other members of the House. That is clearly unparliamentary and a reflection on
the chair. He should be required to withdraw it.
—He is pointing at me, Mr Acting Speaker, and I can assure you that I made no such comment.
—Unless we can identify the person, we can hardly—

—I will take the matter further. I heard the words quite clearly from the front bench on the other side that the decision you had made was at the direction of the government. The person who made it should have what it takes to withdraw it.
—On the point raised by the Leader of the House: this is just the same sort of broad brush smear the Leader of the House goes on with, trying to cover up what he has already done here today.

—There is no point of order. I did hear the comment. I was not watching, so I didn't actually see who said it but, if I were to give a judgment on it, it sounded for all the world like the member for Watson.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I ask you about your ruling on supplementary questions. It is my understanding that, under standing orders in relation to questions and answers, you are required to ascertain whether they conform to standing orders or, alternatively, rule one way or another if it is brought to your attention. It appears to me that, in extending the ruling by Speaker Halverson that he would allow himself to hear supplementary questions before ruling them in or out, you are now advising the House that you are going to judge each question—
—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: this is simply an attempt to debate a ruling you have already given and he should be required to sit down.
—I would suggest to the honourable member that I have already given several undertakings to the House to refer my ruling to Speaker Halverson. I hope that satisfies you.
—Can I raise a further matter? The element of concern is that—

break.para:
Mr Reith interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, I am trying to raise a legitimate question with you.

—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: this is part of a deliberate campaign by the opposition to prevent a matter of public importance being debated this afternoon. You have made that decision. The opposition parties are offended at the fact that the government every now and then wants to have an MPI. This is the explanation for the conduct of the opposition—
—On a point of order: this is a speech—
—And the explanation for the conduct now of this man who is now out of his seat and should be up the back.

—I accept the point of order of the Leader of the House. I have given an undertaking that the ruling I have given will be considered by Speaker Halverson. I repeat with some degree of certainty that there is nothing inconsistent between my ruling and his, but I am quite prepared to do the right thing and let that happen.

question.speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

talk.start.para: —Yesterday and on Tuesday I was asked questions in the House concerning the provision of a newspaper clipping service to members and the distribution of newspapers. The answers to the questions of the honourable members for Fisher, Chifley and Melbourne are as follows.

question.para: In regard to the provision of a newspaper clipping service, the portfolio budget statements of the Department of the House of Representatives make it clear that the department's funding situation is extremely tight, with little scope to absorb any additional expenditure requirements. I have, however, asked that the department examine the scope for providing this service within the existing funding allocation for members' services. The examination will include the scope for use of the existing Senate arrangements which, I am advised, cost in the vicinity of $40,000 for the press clipping contract and in-house printing.

break.para: The suggestion by the honourable member for Melbourne that the redirection of papers from electorate offices to Parliament House during sitting weeks be explored with the Department of Administrative Services will be followed up. The parliamentary departments fund the provision of services to members in Parliament House, whilst the Department of Administrative Services funds the provision of services to members in their electorates. Any positive outcomes will be reported to the House.

speech.speaker: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Proceed.

—In question time today the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) quoted from a letter I had sent to him and misrepresented me in attempting to demonstrate that there was some difference between the position of the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) and myself. He gave a specific quote, but did not use the full quote. In my letter to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy I said:

speech.para: I repeat my overriding view that it is vital to the long-term future of this industry that the federal government maintain maximum pressure for investment in Australia. Any increase in ceiling signals a weakening of this resolve and could set back such investment.
The minister used this precise quote. He said that in my letter I had said:
No extra tree will be felled if you increased the woodchip volumes. The trees are going to be felled anyway.
What he chose to leave out was the few words in front, where I said:
It is disingenuous for the industry to give you an assurance that no extra tree will be felled if you increased the woodchip volumes.
I did expect this letter to be quoted back at me and I did expect it to be misrepresented in the way that it was.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Proceed.

—Yesterday in the House the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), at page 2460 of
Hansard
, and Senator Murray during Senate question time today ascribed to me incorrectly comments regarding the government's 150 per cent research and development tax concession changes. Both the member for Hotham and Senator Murray made their misrepresentation of me based on an article in the
West Australian
of 28 August 1996. No such comments that they ascribed to me were delivered by me. Indeed, the words they seek to rely on in that
West Australian
article do not appear in direct quotes. The article quotes me extensively as supporting the government's decision. There is a statement by the reporter which the member for Hotham and Senator Murray have then used as my direct quotes. Those comments were not made by me.

talker.name: Dr KEMP
talker.role: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation)

talk.start.para: —I desire to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Proceed.

—An article in the
Sydney Morning Herald
today had a headline which completely misrepresented an answer of mine in question time yesterday. My answer was that the Labor Party was responsible for the unemployment tragedy that Australia now faces. As I said yesterday, they tried to use their programs to constantly redefine the long-term unemployed as the short‐term unemployed. That deceit is now being exposed.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—Grievously so.
—Please proceed.

—Mr Acting Speaker, when the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) was taking a point of order on me, on which you ruled in his favour, he asserted that my question to you as Acting Speaker was part of an organised campaign by the opposition to disrupt the government's MPI. That is untrue. I certainly resent the inference that I would use a question to you for such purposes.
—Can I say, Mr Acting Speaker, that Roger has never been in any campaign I have ever run.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The member for Watson not only rises constantly in this place to make points of order which are spurious—actually, which are not points of order but are statements—but now he is speaking out of his place. You should discipline him and remove him from this place.

speech.speaker: Reith, Peter, MP

talk.start.para:
—Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the
Votes and Proceedings
and
Hansard
.

speech.para:
The schedule read as follows
—
Primary Industry Councils Act—Australian Pig Industry Council—Report for 1995‐96.
The Australian government's international human rights policy and activities for period 1 January 1994 to 31 December 1995—Submission by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, September 1996.

debate.sub1.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

break.para: That the Australian government's International Human Rights Policy and activities 1994‐95‐Submission by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, be referred to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

interject.speaker: REITH

talk.start.para: —I present papers on the following subjects, being petitions which are not in accordance with the standing and sessional orders of the House:

interject.para: Opposition to Holsworthy as Sydney's second international airport—from the member for Brand—47 petitioners.
Opposition to the proposed airport at Holsworthy—from the member for Brand—203 petitioners.
Support for continuing operational subsidy to non profit children's services —from the member for Brand—65 petitioners.
Objection to any reduction in federal government funding to children's services—from the member for Brand—6 petitioners.
Opposition to the proposed removal of operational assistance from family day care and recommendation for consultation on any changes to child care funding—from the member for Brand—12 petitioners.
Request for maintenance of the family day care scheme in its present form—from the member for Brand—38 petitioners.
Request to the federal government not to cut funding to children's services—from the member for Brand—54 petitioners.
Request for maintenance of the current system of children's services funding—from the member for Brand—44 petitioners.
Request to reconsider the cuts to operational funding of the family day care scheme—from the member for Brand—533 petitioners.
Opposition to cuts to community based child care services—from the member for Brand—695 petitioners.
Changes to operational subsidy and child care assistance—from the member for Brand—106 petitioners.
Opposition to proposed cuts to child care services—from the member for Brand—31 petitioners.
Support for a total international ban on landmines—from the member for Brand—49 petitioners.
Support for gun control—from the member for Brand—32 petitioners.
Support for gun reform—from the member for Brand—53 petitioners.
Support for gun control—from the member for Brand—46 petitioners.
Support for banning of possession of automatic and semi‐automatic guns in Australia—from the member for Brand—37 petitioners.
Support for gun control—from the member for Brand—73 petitioners.
Support for control of ownership of assault firearms and the escalation of violence in our nation—from the member for Brand—30 petitioners.
Request for stringent laws for the ownership and use of firearms—from the member for Brand—2410 petitioners.
Support for triennial funding and services of the ABC—from the member for Cowper—52 petitioners.
Request for consideration of the ramifications of the Industrial Relations bill—from the member for Flinders—18 petitioners.
Support for gun control—from the member for Aston—414 petitioners.

interject.speaker: ACTING SPEAKER

talk.start.para: —I have received letters from the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) and the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by standing order 107, I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important; that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Parramatta, namely:

interject.para: The urgent need for the government to take measures to alleviate the substantial damage being suffered by the Australian economy as a result of irresponsible industrial action by trade unions.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.emphasis: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I call the honourable member for Parramatta.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I move that the member be not further heard.
—He hasn't started speaking yet.
—That is out of order. I call the honourable member for Parramatta.

interject.speaker: McLEAY

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, I move:

interject.para: That the member be not further heard.

talk.start.para: —You cannot do that once he is going. I call the honourable member for Parramatta.

speech.speaker: Cameron, Ross, MP

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, I rise to raise this matter as a result of reports received which deeply disturb the government—that our Prime Minister (Mr Howard), while in Japan, has been called upon by the Japanese government and by the industry of Japan to give an account—
—The honourable member will resume his seat. I would like to resolve what is before me before I accept any point of order. The motion is in order.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para:
—As I said, I rise on a matter of national importance after reports that our Prime Minister in Japan has been called upon by the Japanese government and by senior figures in Japanese industry to give some kind of assurance that Australia will be able to deliver on its export commitments, on contractual commitments undertaken by Australian companies to deliver resources to Japan. The Prime Minister has been called upon to give that assurance after repeated failures of Australians to be able to
deliver on those commitments as a result of industrial action and as a result of increasing pressure from some of our competitors, such as Canada, who are giving promises of a capacity to deliver on a much more secure basis.

speech.para: The wording of this matter of public importance has been done quite deliberately. I want to make it clear that we on this side of the House have no beef with the vast bulk of the working people of Australia. These are the people who long ago jettisoned the rhetoric of class hatred, which so frequently spews forth from the other side of this chamber. These are the people who want to get on with the job, who want to make Australia more productive and who are embracing workplace and enterprise agreements with relish. These are the people whom this government, more so than any other group in this chamber, represents.

If there is any doubt about that whatsoever, I would urge members on the other side of the House simply to open their eyes. Do not take my word for it. If you want to know who represents the working people of Australia, ask who sits in the seats of Hughes, of Robertson, of Lowe, of Eden‐Monaro, of Paterson, of Richmond, of Macarthur and of Gilmore? I can tell you that we did not get here on the votes of the Melbourne Club. You should ask who represents McMillan, Bendigo and Chisholm. We represent those hundreds of thousands of working Australians who have haemorrhaged out of the trade union movement and have come flooding over to this side of the House. They see us as being more representative of their hopes, of their interests and of their attitudes.

If we go to the seeds of the present discontent, the seeds of the industrial problems in the resources sector of this country, we need go no further than that venerable figure of the trade union movement: Bill Kelty. This was the great leader who, at the height of our difficulties in resolving a complex dispute at Weipa, wrote to the purchasers of Australian resources and told them not to purchase from Australian supplier CRA.

That kind of bastardry is entirely un-Australian. It is reflective of the mind‐set which runs right throughout the leadership of
the ACTU. He followed up that great act of leadership in the lead‐up to the election when groups like the Business Council of Australia indicated they were prepared to play by the rules. They said, `We're prepared to work with whomever the Australian people elect, not Bill Kelty.'
(Time expired)
That Mr Ross Cameron be granted an extension of time.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I remind the House that Bill Kelty wrote that letter as a director of the Reserve Bank of Australia—the Reserve Bank. With our national economy grappling with the problem of the current account deficit, here you have one of the directors of the Reserve Bank writing to our trade customers, advising them not to trade with Australia.

speech.para: He followed up this brilliant act of leadership on 21 February by saying to 2,000 trade unionists, in the presence of then Prime Minister Keating that, if the incoming Howard government dares question the totalitarian hegemony of the trade union movement over working Australians, he will declare `all‐out industrial war'. He said that it `will make Weipa look like a sonata'. He said, `We are talking about the full orchestra—music, clashes, the whole nine yards, a 30 per cent wages explosion.'

para.break: Why does it surprise us that, almost six months to the day when 25,000 of his emissaries gathered outside this parliament, 1,000 of them broke away in front of this great parlia ment—the great institution that it represents—and proceeded to do $300,000 worth of damage to the parliament?

speech.para: It would be bad enough if this were an aberration. It would be bad enough if this were a departure from the strategy. The thing we have to recognise is that this was a natural and logical outcome of the statement made by Kelty on 21 February.

So then at that moment, whilst scenes of violence and vandalism are going out across the world on CNN, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has his first real test of leadership. He steps up to the podium as people's lives are seriously being threatened. Real leadership is the capacity to take on your own constituency on a matter of principle and that was the challenge that the Leader of the Opposition was faced with at that moment.

So what did he do? What words of statesmanship came forth from his lips? What moderation proceeded to calm the rioting crowd? `This government hates workers'—that is the contribution of the Leader of the Opposition. `This government hates women in the work force'—thanks very much, smash, bang, crash, vandalism. `This government hates Aborigines'—so then the violence takes place and the whole thing is out of control. Labor ever since has been in this schizophrenic dance backwards and forwards trying to work out what its relationship is with the perpetrators of this violence.

So what did the CFMEU do? We all remember seeing `CFMEU' emblazoned across their caps on the front page of the
Sydney Morning Herald
. What did the CFMEU do? A week later, the ACTU elects Stan Sharkey to Vice President of the ACTU. It rewards the very perpetrators of the violence.
Not only that, we get a great window, an insight, into the culture of the leadership of the ACTU from evidence given before the Industrial Relations Commission on 6 September.
QLD union official was told to harass and frighten employers, disrupt workplaces and arrange a "bashing" to boost flagging union membership.
This is ACTU leadership culture—leadership training in the ACTU.

break.para: Tony Eggleston, a former organiser with the furniture division of the CFMEU, said he was told by the union's national secretary, Lou Kyriacou, to start a campaign of harassment against employers in the furniture industry. He claimed Mr Kyriacou told him, `I want you to go out there, stand over people, harass them and get the membership right up.' This is not my statement; this is a former employee of the CFMEU.

I first came across the CFMEU in the electorate of Parramatta when I went to the area consultative committees and said, `Tell me the problems that you have had getting young people in Parramatta into jobs.' They said, `One of the biggest problems we face is the unions.' They said, `We got those initiating the M2 motorway project'—a $600 million project in the north of Parramatta—`to agree to employ 60 young Australians in the construction industry. With the Olympics coming up, we needed more construction workers.' They were right about to sign the deal when they got a call from none other than Andrew Ferguson. Andrew rolls in and explained to Abigroup Obayashi, the proponents, that if they dare employ these 60 young Australians the CFMEU will bring the project to its knees. This is the commitment of the ACTU to new employment in this country.
Then we get the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) strolling around here and beating his chest on behalf of the unemployed. This is your commitment to the unemployed. It is a disgrace.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: could I just draw your attention to the standing order that requires the member to address his remarks through the chair.
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

—I would be happy to do that, Mr Deputy Speaker. The ACTU is like a group of guys on a lifeboat. As the others are swimming, holding on to the gunwales and trying to get in, they rush around with the oars, smashing them down to make sure that they cannot get in. It is like,
once you get into the jobs club, `Up goes the drawbridge and you guys can bugger off.' That is the ACTU version of jobs creation.

break.para: The former government knitted that culture into the fabric of the whole government, the whole psychology of the place. It is like you knitted an institutional bias against new employment into the previous government. It is no wonder that the working people of Australia abandoned you in droves.

In the few seconds remaining to me, can I suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that, having so completely soiled the nest, having so completely demonstrated his lack of leadership at a key moment, now is the time for him to take on his own constituency on a matter of principle. Now is the time for him to demonstrate that he has some real concern for the future productivity of this country.

Now is the time for him to disown the ACTU and the extreme elements within the trade union leadership. Again, we are not talking about the hundreds of thousands of Australians who want to get on with the job. We are not talking about all those who have completely repudiated all of this institutionalised hatred, this rhetoric of the Kremlin in the 1950s which pours forth from the left of the ALP. They want to get on with the job and we are here to help them.

So we call on the Leader of the Opposition to repeal the unfair dismissal law, that great drawbridge keeping out any new jobs. We call on him to join us in the passage of the workplace relations bill. We call on him to repudiate the thuggery and violence so prevalent in the ACTU.

Instead of communicating on CNN to the rest of the world the violence and the incapacity of Australia to resolve disputes, we call on him to affirm the culture which this government is leading, which this government is championing, of a new, productive, cooperative Australian workplace.
That the business of the day be called on.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Evans, Richard, MP

talk.start.para: —I present the second report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

speech.para: Report—by leave—agreed to.

proctext.para:
Bill presented by
Mr Prosser
, and read a first time.

speech.speaker: Prosser, Geoff, MP

talker.name: Mr PROSSER
talker.role: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill amends four bounty acts to achieve savings announced by the government in the 1996‐97 budget. The savings are to be achieved by the termination of the computers bounty with effect from 1 July 1997 and the books, machine tools and robots and ships bounties with effect from 20 August 1996.

para.break: The government is abolishing these bounty schemes as they have run their course and are no longer considered to be an appropriate or cost effective means of industry assistance. Recent Industry Commission reports have recommended that each of the bounty schemes be allowed to lapse on their scheduled statutory termination dates. The govern ment has decided to terminate the schemes ahead of their scheduled dates—nine months early for the ships and machine tools and robots bounties, 15 months for the books bounty and 3½ years for the computers bounty—because of the overriding objective to eliminate the budget deficit.

speech.para: As the bounties are being paid at declining rates of support, in line with the reduction of general tariff levels, their impact on industry development objectives is declining in importance. The declining rates of assistance also mean that an ever increasing percentage of the total cost to the Commonwealth of each of these bounties is represented by administration and compliance costs.
I will now turn to considerations in respect of each of the affected bounties which the government took into account in making the decision to bring them to an early end.

The decision to abolish the computers bounty was made because, in the government's view, there are more important factors than the bounty in determining the continuing profitability of Australia's information technology and telecommunications industries.
(Quorum formed)

These factors include the fundamentals of Australia's broad economic environment, the sophistication of the Australian market place and the enormous opportunities for trade in information technology and telecommunications products and services within our region. Therefore, considering the government's need to address the budget deficit problem, it is not possible to maintain the computers bounty.

Moreover, I should note that following the budget announcement concerning the cessation of the computers bounty, the government has honoured its commitment to convene an Information Industries Taskforce. The taskforce, the membership of which has largely been drawn from industry, has been asked to provide advice on any alternative measures that might be pursued to ensure that the information industries are able to take advantage of emerging opportunities. In particular, in the light of the termination of the computers bounty from 30 June 1997, the taskforce has been asked to consider whether, and in what form, the information technology
and telecommunications industries might require industry assistance from that date.

Bounty assistance for the production of books has been in place since 1969 with the current scheme operating since 1987. The bounty was introduced to offset duties on manufacturing inputs and to enable printing companies to remain internationally competitive. The rate of bounty has declined from 20 per cent in 1987 to its current level of 7.2 per cent and is due to phase to 4.5 per cent on 1 January 1997.

The Industry Commission is currently reviewing assistance for book production. In its draft report, released prior to the budget, the commission recommended abolition of the books bounty when the current scheme expires on 31 December 1997. It noted that industry has improved efficiency despite reducing levels of assistance and this would be expected to continue.

The machine tools and robots bounty scheme, which has been in place since 1 July 1985, was also the subject of a recent Industry Commission inquiry. The commission found that the scheme could not be considered a success as it had not effectively promoted production of metal working machines nor the development of machinery for working advanced materials. It also found that the scheme had not been a significant stimulus to the export of machine tools and robotics, nor had it been effective in encouraging Australian industry to invest in advanced technology machinery. The commission recommended that the scheme be allowed to lapse on 30 June 1997.

The government's decision to terminate the books and machine tools and robots bounties from 20 August 1996 merely speeds up the process recommended by the Industry Commission and yields additional savings to help balance the budget.

To minimise disruption to industry, the bill includes transitional arrangements for these two bounties. The amendments will allow bounty to be paid on bountiable books and equipment already in production on budget night, or the subject of certain contracts entered into before budget night, provided that production is completed by 20 February 1997.

break.para: The Australian shipbuilding industry has established itself as a world leader in the construction of small to medium lightweight vessels. The innovative use of technology and advanced materials by the Australian shipbuilders has meant a growing market for fast ferries, which are in operation in many countries providing new services as well as replacing the more traditional ferries. The economies of travel time savings have provided the stimulus for ferry operators to buy Australian built fast ferries. The Australian industry's share of the world fast ferry market has ranged from 25 per cent to 30 per cent in recent years.

The success of the shipbuilding industry was reported on by the Bureau of Industry Economics, BIE, in its March 1995 report reviewing the ships bounty. One of the recommendations of that report was that it was now time to consider the termination of direct bounty assistance as the industry was now at a stage where it could compete in the world economy without the need for such assistance. The government has therefore decided, as a budget measure, to discontinue this bounty. However, it has also recognised that there was a need for transitional arrangements which would reduce the impact of the termination on shipbuilders.

To this end the current amendments allow for vessels under construction on budget night and for those under pre‐budget night contracts but yet to be commenced, to receive bounty as long as those vessels are completed by 30 June 1997, when the bounty is currently due to terminate. Customs will be monitoring the needs of shipbuilders during the transition phase to ensure that the transition from an assisted to a fully competitive environment is achieved in an orderly manner.

The amendments in the bill are expected to result in savings of $8.5 million in 1996‐97 and $14.8 million in 1997‐98 in respect of the books, machine tools and robots and ships bounties and $20 million in 1997‐98, $44.7 million in 1998‐99, $46.4 million in 1999‐2000 and $31.2 million thereafter in respect of the computers bounty. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

proctext.para:
Bill presented by
Mr Fahey
, and read a first time.

speech.speaker: Fahey, John, MP

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The bill will put in place the necessary framework to give effect to the government's decision to sell Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd, and its subsidiaries. CFM is a wholly Commonwealth owned public company that provides investment services in the public and private sectors. Its major clients are the Boards of Trustees of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation scheme. However, it acts as a wholesale funds manager for a number of other public and private sector funds and is involved in retail funds management for individual investors via its superannuation and general investment retail products.

CFM's functions are not part of government's core activities and for this reason and to ensure the longer term future of CFM and the best returns on the funds it has under management the government has decided to sell the company.

CFM was created in 1991 by the transformation of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. SFIT had been established in 1976 as a statutory authority with trustee responsibility for the management and investment of the CSS fund which contained the contributions of CSS members and the income earned from the investment of those contributions.

When the new PSS scheme was established in 1990, full responsibility for that scheme and the investment of PSS fund moneys was given to the joint employer‐employee PSS board. At the same time, the CSS board was established, with responsibilities for the invalidity retirement process and setting the
interest rates to be allocated to contributions. In 1991, the CSS board was given responsibility for management of the CSS fund.

The transfer of SFIT's trustee function and responsibility for the investment of the CSS fund to the CSS board, was accompanied by SFIT's transformation to CFM with the role of general funds manager. To assist its establishment as a funds manager, CFM was provided with legislative monopolies over the management of the CSS and PSS funds until 30 June 1995. Since then, the CSS and PSS boards have been free to determine their own investment management arrangements.

During the period of its monopoly, CFM worked with the CSS and PSS boards to develop investment management arrangements to apply to the CSS and PSS funds after 30 June 1995. The new arrangements involve CFM's subsidiary, Total Risk Management Pty Ltd (TRM), in providing advice to the boards about the overall investment strategies for the funds. The strategies involve management of substantial `passive' cores of the funds. This is being undertaken by CFM. The balance of the CSS and PSS funds has been progressively allocated by the CSS and PSS boards to a number of specialist `active' funds managers who have been selected on the advice of TRM.

Although CFM has developed additional business and attracted funds from other clients, the substantial CSS and PSS funds under management still represented some 75 per cent of the total funds under CFM's direct management as at 30 June 1996. The ending of the monopolies over the CSS and PSS funds has renewed pressures on CFM to improve its competitiveness in attracting additional clients and additional funds under management. This has come at a time when competition in the funds management industry itself has been increasing.

While the volume of funds in the market is growing, so too is the number of fund managers. In addition to traditional funds managers, there is competition from small `boutique' managers offering specialised services and from overseas managers who are establishing operations in Australia. Existing life insurance
companies and banks are also seeing funds management as a source of new business.

Moreover, the growing numbers of competitors provide opportunities for CFM. Many of those competitors are facing similar pressures and it is expected that some would be interested in joining forces via a purchase of CFM. It is expected that CFM's expertise and experience will be of benefit to potential purchasers and in turn that CFM would benefit from the wider opportunities available for further—

interject.speaker: ALBANESE

talk.start.para: —The minister obviously deserves a better audience than this, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I draw your attention to the state of the House.

interject.para:
The bells having been rung
—

talk.start.para: —Order! A quorum not being present, the sitting will be resumed at 5.20 p.m.

para.emphasis: Sitting suspended from 5.15 p.m. to 5.20 p.m.
The House having been counted and a quorum being present—

talk.start.para: —As I was saying, it is expected that CFM's expertise and experience will be of benefit to potential purchasers and in turn that CFM would benefit from the wider opportunities available for further development of its business.

speech.para: The government's decision to sell CFM is consistent with the recommendations of the National Commission of Audit (NCOA) which considered that government business activities whose objectives are to provide goods and services on a commercial basis should only be retained in public ownership if there is a clear public interest case to do so. Against the background of a growing number and variety of funds managers, and the investment strategies of the CSS and PSS boards, there is clearly no public interest case to retain CFM in public ownership.

In reaching its decision, the government consulted with the board of CFM which has fully supported this initiative. The sale process is also being undertaken in close consultation with CFM and CFM's major clients, particularly the CSS and PSS boards of
trustees. The sale of CFM should provide it with the opportunity to further improve its commercial performance and this should benefit its clients, including the boards of the various superannuation schemes and their members.

The CFM Sale Bill provides the necessary framework to give effect to the decision to sell CFM. The bill provides for a flexible disposal strategy. It allows for the sale of the shares in CFM and the separate sale of the shares in CFM subsidiaries on the same or different days. It enables the establishment, under ministerial direction, of subsidiaries of CFM and the transfer of subsidiaries to Commonwealth ownership to allow their separate sale.

Part 2 of the bill provides for the transfer of CFM subsidiaries to the Commonwealth. In particular, it enables the transfer of CFM's existing subsidiary, TRM, to Commonwealth ownership to facilitate sale of that company separately from the sale of CFM, if sale in that form eventuates from the tender process now under way. That approach was recommended in the scoping study prepared by the business advisers appointed by my department.

That part of the bill also includes provision for the transfer of CFM staff, by ministerial declaration, to a CFM subsidiary which has been transferred under this bill. This is because at present all the staff employed in CFM's operations, including those of the subsidiary TRM, are employed by CFM. The bill provides for continuity of employment terms and conditions and accrued entitlements for CFM staff who are transferred to TRM or any other CFM subsidiary that may be created. Provision is also made for the application of certain parts of the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Act, and certain other legislation to transferred CFM subsidiaries.

para.break: Part 3 of the bill provides for the declaration of the sale day for CFM and any transferred bodies by the minister. Importantly, the bill provides in part 3 for the preservation or other recognition of entitlements of CFM staff. It preserves accrued long service leave and superannuation entitlements and ensures that the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensa tion Act continues to apply in relation to injury or loss incurred before sale day.

speech.para: The bill provides for certain other rights, such as mobility rights under the Public Service Act 1922, to cease when CFM or a transferred body is sold. In these respects the bill reflects the past practice of government in protecting accrued rights of employees in asset sale situations. The bill also provides in part 3 for the cancellation of CFM's franking credits, as the government's clear advice has been that there would be no benefit to the sale process in having those credits pass to any purchaser.

Part 4 of the bill further provides for the transfer, by ministerial declaration, of specified assets, liabilities, rights and obligations of CFM or a transferred body to specified transferees on specified days. The ability to transfer these matters in this way will allow for the sale or transfer of matters that do not constitute CFM subsidiaries and for which it would not be appropriate to establish a subsidiary. This includes the transfer of assets and liabilities to transferred bodies to enable them to be sold as separate commercial entities.

The bill amends the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited Act 1990 to remove the constraints on the sale of CFM included in section 47 of that act and provides for the removal of similar constraints from CFM's memorandum and articles of association. The bill applies relevant provisions of that act to CFM subsidiaries that are transferred to Commonwealth ownership while they are in Commonwealth ownership and provides that they will cease to apply to CFM and the transferred bodies when they are sold. The bill also makes consequential amendments to a number of other Commonwealth acts.

This bill will provide a framework for the sale of CFM in the most flexible and expeditious way in response to commercial interest that is expressed in the sale process. It will also protect the interests of CFM employees and enable the effective disposition of assets, liabilities, rights and obligations, including for the benefit of CFM's clients. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

debate.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1996

proctext.para:
Bill presented by
Mr Reith
, for
Dr Kemp
, and read a first time.

speech.speaker: Reith, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The bill provides for this government's program of assistance to the states and territories for government and non‐government schools for the 1997‐2000 quadrennium. It succeeds the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992, which authorised funding for the 1993 to 1996 funding period.

The bill fulfils the government's commitments to promote excellence and achievement through the provision of quality education and prepare our young people for an active and productive life both in the work force and as participating citizens in the community and global economy. The bill fosters a partnership approach with states and territories which recognises both the constitutional responsibility of states and territories for education and the Commonwealth's role in guiding national directions and priorities.

The main theme of the bill is the importance of choice in providing for improved educational outcomes for Australian students. The bill further supports the devolution of decision making about education to parents and communities to ensure that education is responsive to student needs. The bill will provide choice for better options for the future.

This bill provides for significant reform in the emphasis, availability and administration of the Commonwealth's schools programs. To support these changes, the bill will appropriate in excess of $14 billion for the coming quadrennium under a rationalised set of programs which this government believes best
meets the needs and aspirations of those in school level education.

The major part of this funding will continue to be directed to the general recurrent and capital grants programs. The government has, however, decided to replace a complex array of more than 40 school related programs of targeted assistance by a streamlined set of five programs; namely, literacy; languages; and special learning needs, which are included in the bill before us; and two other programs school to work; and quality outcomes, the funding for which is included in other legislation.

A strong determination to secure the foundations of effective learning is behind the government's policy of ensuring that all students are provided with literacy and numeracy skills. Illiteracy is the worst form of poverty and a blight on society. The government's literacy program of more than $150 million annually is one of the government's most important equity programs. The literacy program subsumes the general support element of the English as a second language program and the disadvantaged schools program. It will also replace the early literacy program which was due to end in 1996.

Funding is to be provided under the literacy program for a new national literacy and numeracy strategy directed at improving the literacy and numeracy skills of school leavers. The bill will appropriate some $45 million for this purpose for the next three years. Many young people, especially those who are educationally disadvantaged, leave school without the literacy and numeracy skills essential for further study or sustained employment.

Two factors will ensure the strategy's relevance to the problems being faced by young people. First, it will draw upon the results of the national schools English literacy survey which are scheduled to be released early next year. Secondly, it will identify best classroom practice.

All of this will underpin progress towards Australia's first national literacy goal—that every child leaving primary school should be able to read, write, spell and communicate at an appropriate level. Progress towards this
goal will be measured by national literacy benchmarks at year three and year five which the Commonwealth government will develop in conjunction with state and territory governments.

The languages program, which is the second in the group of priority initiatives, and for which more than $100 million is included in the bill, provides funding for the national Asian languages and studies in Australian schools strategy and for the teaching of community and priority languages.
Debate interrupted.
