interject.speaker: ACTING SPEAKER

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 5.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interject.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I require the question to be put forthwith without debate.
—The question is that the House do now adjourn. Those of that opinion say aye. To the contrary no.
—No.
—No.
—I think the noes have it.
—We want a division.
—You can't.
—We've got two people. We are calling for a division.
—Sit down, Leo. Do your tie up and sit down.

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker: there were sufficient people on the opposition side calling for a vote on this issue. There would be numerous voices if you wish to listen again, or if you had listened then.
—The situation is that you have to dispute the call to call for a division and you initially did not. There are no second bites at the cherry.
—Mr Acting Speaker—
—Resume your seat. The Leader of the House.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker—
—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order—
—The Leader of the House will resume his seat.

—My point of order is that there were a number of people on the opposition side that disputed the vote and called for a division. If you cannot have a division on a disputed vote here now, I do not know what you can do.
—On the point of order: you have ruled on the matter and that is the end of the matter.
—I have ruled on the matter.
—This is nothing but a campaign of disruption by the opposition for which you ought to be ashamed of yourself.
—Mr Acting Speaker, on a further point of order—
—This is the Labor Party in action. This is just the way you people behave.
—The honourable member for Watson on a point of order.
—Mr Acting Speaker, you—
—You've got to sit down. Sit down, Leo.

—He's called me. He actually runs the show, not you. The chair is in charge, not you. I know you would like to pretend that you are in charge, but the chair is. The chair is seeking some advice at present and I am happy to wait while the chair gets that advice. Mr Acting Speaker, my point is that members on the opposition side disputed the call and members on the opposition side called for a division. There are three of my colleagues here, as well as I, who are calling for a division.

—The honourable member for Watson will resume his seat. There is no point of order. The standing orders are quite clear. I said, `The noes have it.' You said, `The noes have it.' Then you realised you had made a mistake and you tried to change it.
—My colleague the member for—
—That is it. The matter is resolved. Resume your seat.

debate.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1996

proctext.para: Debate resumed.

speech.speaker: Reith, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —While the languages program is directed at the teaching of a wide range of languages—

speech.para: That the member be not further heard.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —While the languages program is directed at the teaching of a wide range of languages other than English, it gives particular emphasis to Asian languages and cultural studies. Clearly, it is important to the development of Australia's trade relations for businesses in this country to have leaders and staff who are proficient in Asian languages and who have an understanding of Asian cultures.

speech.para:
The special learning needs program, which is the third priority initiative, includes funding for three tightly targeted areas addressing the needs of clearly identified clients. These areas are: special education for students with disabilities; provision of intensive English language instruction for newly arrived migrants; and provision of supplementary
educational services for students in country areas.

The bill contains some $636 million over four years for the special learning needs program. The program will have as its objective the full participation in schooling of students with specific educational needs and the subsequent realisation of their maximum potential in the work force.

Returning to the theme of choice, the broadbanding effected by this bill, which has brought together a number of related programs, will give schools a degree of flexibility in determining their priorities which they have never had before. Schools will be able to respond to the changing needs of students and direct their resources to achieving the best possible learning outcomes for their students.

In addition to the literacy, languages and special needs programs, which are directed at particular needs in the school community, the bill also provides in excess of $11 billion for general recurrent grants and some $1.2 billion for capital grants, including an additional $30 million for non‐government schools capital grants.

The fourth priority initiative, which I mentioned earlier, and for which funds will be included in other legislation, is the school to work program. This program is intended to make the transition from school to work a natural and successful process for all students.

The final initiative, which will be covered by the appropriation bills, is the quality outcomes program. This initiative unites a number of programs directed at teacher development—the civics and citizenship program and the projects of national significance program. The unified program will provide a sharper focus on the achievement of quality outcomes in schooling while giving recognition to the fact that teachers play a key role in the academic and social development of children. It is vital that teachers have access to quality and regular professional development opportunities to enhance their expertise and professionalism, and the programs contained in the bill will allow for that to occur.

break.para: Emphasising the theme of choice, this bill legislates a new and more equitable policy for non-government schools seeking Commonwealth funding. This policy replaces the attempts of the previous government to impose a bureaucratic, unfair and inequitable burden on non‐government schools seeking Commonwealth funding. The application process under the previous government's new schools policy was bound in red tape, as was the process for reviewing the funding category of those schools already in receipt of funding.

Furthermore, the Labor government's new schools policy confined non-government schools approved for funding since May 1988 to a maximum funding level of category 6. This arbitrary restriction has jeopardised the existence of many deserving schools worthy of a higher level of support from governments. It also restricted parental choice in non-government schooling for their children, especially for low income families.

This government's policy for newly commencing schools will make a school's entitlement to Commonwealth funding primarily dependent upon state or territory government recognition. There will, of course, be a requirement that schools be run by an incorporated body, be non‐profit making and enter into an agreement with the Commonwealth. Non‐government school funding will, however, be both simple and equitable. This is a most important measure.

The government believes that parents should have the choice between schools in both the government and non‐government sectors and between schools in each sector. The government has no preconceived ideas about the size of either sector. It is important that Australia has a strong government school sector and a strong non‐government school sector.

The cost to the Commonwealth of a student attending a non‐government school is more than the cost of a student attending a government school. Conversely, the cost to a state or territory of a student attending a government school is more than the cost of a student attending a non‐government school.

This, coupled with the fact that the proportion of students in non‐government schools
has increased from 24.4 per cent in 1983 to 29 per cent in 1995, has meant that states and territories have had the potential to cost shift and save on the education of students in government schools. Against this background, the government has decided to preserve for the Commonwealth 50 per cent of net recurrent savings to a state or territory from students shifting from the government to the non‐government sector.

Grants to the states and territories for government schools will reflect the choices of parents between government and non‐government schools. This decision is to be effective from January 1997 and operate at least for the 1997‐2000 quadrennial program for schools.

Many of the provisions of the bill are familiar, as they also appeared in the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992. Those provisions have been placed in a more rational structure. This is a reflection of the grouping of some of the previous programs into the five priority initiatives I referred to earlier. It also reflects efforts to reduce the amount of repetition prevalent in the previous act.

For the first time, the bill contains provisions to ensure comprehensive reporting on the application of financial assistance provided to schools. This will be achieved through a strengthened national report on schooling in Australia with a range of core data showing what our students are learning and where the greatest needs lie. This information will be a key factor in the Commonwealth's future policy responses in the area of schooling.

This bill provides the bulk of a five per cent increase in total Commonwealth funding for schools. In financial year terms, this means an increase from $3.3 billion in 1995‐96 to $3.4 billion in 1996‐97. This demonstrates the government's commitment to ensuring that Australia's young people gain the best possible education opportunities to make the most of their future.

As I said, the minister unfortunately was unable to be here, but I do want to add my congratulations to the minister on the work that he has done to be able to present this bill, which so well reflects an important change in policy towards education. On that basis, and
on behalf of the minister, it is my pleasure to commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

question.block.title: Proceeds of Crime: Drug Education Programs

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Speaker, I seek the indulgence of the chair to add to an answer.
—The minister may proceed.

—I want to correct a statement I made in answer to a question without notice during question time today. I indicated, as was my opinion then, that there would be a commitment of a fixed sum to drug strategies out of the residue of the confiscated assets trust fund. This is, in fact, not correct. The commitment of a fixed sum will be out of the consolidated revenue fund. The funding of drug strategies will now be by way of appropriation from consolidated revenue, which in turn will receive the residue from the fund in any given year. This will enable funding of drug strategies in a planned and predictable way.

proctext.para: That the House do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

talk.start.para: —Earlier this week the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) introduced a private member's motion into this House which really laid bare all the phobias and prejudices of the Howard government in its attitude to the union movement of this country. It gave vent to the enduring hatred and contempt that the coalition parties have always had for the working men and women of this country and the unions that represent them in the industrial marketplace.

speech.para:
I attended the demonstration that took place on 19 August outside Parliament House, as did many workers from Geelong, in the
electorate of Corio. I want to place on the public record here today some facts about the protest. It was called in Canberra by the union movement to bring to the full attention of the Australian people—
(Quorum formed)

interject.speaker: ACTING SPEAKER

talk.start.para: —Before I call the honourable member for Corio, I draw his attention to standing order 71, which states:

interject.para:
71.
No Member may allude to any debate or proceedings of the same session . . .
Your opening remarks did allude to an earlier debate of this session. Please continue, but without making those allusions.

talk.start.para: —The protest was called in Canberra by the union movement to bring the full attention of the Australian people to the adverse effects of the Howard government's workplace relations bill, the effect that it will have on the wages and working conditions of workers in this country. It was more than just a demonstration against the punitive anti‐union provisions of the bill.

speech.para: It became a broadly based demonstration by church, welfare and environment groups as well as workers against the massive cuts to the public services that were proposed in the first Howard budget. It was a protest against the cuts in the budget which we now know single out the unemployed, the aged, the disadvantaged, the young students and the indigenous Australians for adverse treatment.

From the length and breadth of Australia, ordinary men and women came in their thousands to peacefully protest against the workplace relations bill and cuts in services to workers and their families. For every one of them who made it to Canberra on that day to protest, there were tens of thousands of working men and women back in their homes and workplaces who supported them in the protest.

In no way can the actions of a violent minority be allowed to detract from the fact that the rally was responsibly organised and that the overwhelming majority of those assembled conducted themselves with dignity and within the bounds of a legitimate, peaceful protest. To infer otherwise would be a perversion of the truth.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Lindsay, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —I would like to finish this long week with some words about some difficulties that I have certainly had in my electorate from the members opposite who basically have not been truthful in their media reporting of certain events.

—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: I say to you that the honourable member for Herbert is reflecting on members on this side and, in particular, I know he is reflecting on me, given that he took a personal explanation yesterday in respect of a media release that I put out. I would ask him to withdraw any reflection.
—I did not hear the member's remarks, but if it is offensive to the honourable member for Cunningham I ask you to withdraw.
—I did not mention anybody's name. In fact, I am going to refer to Mr Laurie Brereton.
—You will not refer to him as Mr Laurie Brereton. You will refer to him as the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I take a point of order again. The honourable member did say in his opening remarks that particular members on this side put out particular press releases which made certain points about him, which quite clearly reflects on the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith. If he does go this way, I would ask him to be very careful or we will ask for a withdrawal.
—I thank the honourable member.

—Only a short amount of time is left to me.
(Quorum formed)
I can but wish the House a very pleasant weekend in the time remaining to me. Mr Acting Speaker, I thank you for your wise guidance through the week. You have been a superb Acting Speaker this week.

speech.para: In the 15 seconds left to me, I will just say that the information in this press release is disgraceful. It will come out next week. Have a good weekend everybody.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 6 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

proctext.para:
Mr Reith
to move:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the following arrangements applying in relation to the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 unless the House otherwise orders:

(2)
at the conclusion of the proceedings on the Bill in the House on Monday, 28 October 1996, the Bill being referred to the Main Committee for the remainder of the second reading stage up to but not including the putting of any questions at the conclusion of the debate;

(3)
in speaking to the motion for the second reading of the Bill in the Main Committee each Member speaking for a period not exceeding 10 minutes;

(4)
during consideration of the Bill in the Main Committee the quorum of the Committee being three Members comprising the occupant of the Chair and two other Members, and

(5)
the Main Committee continuing debate on the Bill regardless of any unresolved questions.

para.tab:
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)
took the chair at 10.10 a.m.

proctext.para:
Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by
Mr Costello
:
That the bill be now read a second time.

upon which
Mr Gareth Evans
moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:

(1)
the Budget betrays the Australian promise of working towards a more fair, just, inclusive and united society;

(2)
the Budget is both mindless and heartless, and its prescriptions are not what the Australian economy needs at present;

(3)
the Budget will have a savagely contractionary impact on economic growth and make impossible the job creation necessary to reduce Australia's still unacceptably high level of unemployment;

(4)
with stronger economic growth the Budget could be restored to underlying balance over the life of this Parliament through a much more moderate program of fiscal consolidation;

(5)
the spending cuts and tax increases contained in the Budget are, on the evidence of the Government's own Budget Papers, not necessary to reduce the Commonwealth Government's debt‐to‐GDP ratio and will not produce a significant improvement in the current account deficit;

(6)
the Budget not only offers no hope to the unemployed but actively harms their prospects of finding a job by cutting labour market programs and privatising the previously publicly provided employment service function of the CES;

(7)
the Budget will have unfair and unjust consequences for the struggling and disadvantaged in our midst—the poor, the old, the sick, indigenous Australians and newly‐arrived migrants;

(8)
the many spending cuts concerned with education and training, research and development, trade development (including breaches of promise with respect to EMDG, ITES and IAMP), production bounties, and other business support, will be counter‐productive in their longer term consequences;

(9)
there is deception involved in the family tax package contained in the Budget, whereby what the Prime Minister appears to be putting into one pocket is for most middle Australian families being taken right out of the other by the Treasurer in higher education fees, Austudy changes, higher nursing home charges, higher fees and charges;

(10)
there are many breaches of Coalition election promises contained in this Budget, which amount to over $17 billion over four years, and which will cause hardship, insecurity, and dismay for millions of Australians;

(11)
the Budget involves a massive betrayal of regional Australia through the abolition of the $150 million regional development program, large cuts to road funding, the closure of regional Government offices such as Medicare and CES offices, and the cuts to the ABC and university funding;

(12)
the mean‐spirited decision to introduce large, up‐front entry fees and massively increased daily fees for nursing homes, and increase user‐charges will harm elderly Australians;

(13)
the abolition of Childcare Operational Subsidies will impact heavily upon community based child care centres;

(14)
the reduction of $800 million over four years in public hospital funding will cause longer waiting lists for the sick and reduce the quality of hospital and medical assistance for millions of people;

(15)
the Budget involves a breaking of the Government's so called `core' commitment to maintain Medicare in its entirety through cuts to rebates for numerous items under Medicare;

(16)
the cruel decision to abolish the Commonwealth Dental Health Program will cause serious problems for the less well off;

(17)
harsh and promise‐breaking decisions will force Australian families to pay substantially more for the cost of their prescription medicines;

(18)
the massive funding cuts to education, the increased HECS charges and AUSTUDY changes will penalise the less well‐off;

(19)
the Budget's comprehensive and ideological assault on the public sector will cost 10,500 jobs in 1996‐97 alone;

(20)
the Government has failed to honour its election commitment to maintain the environment budget and to provide an additional $84 million in the 1996‐97 Budget, instead cutting by 13 per cent the environmental budget and forward estimates;

(21)
the reckless decision to reduce funding for the National Highway by $622 million over four years, breaches a clear Coalition election commitment at the 1996 election, and with other decisions will reduce the level of public infrastructure investment, especially in regional Australia;

(22)
the decision to impose a 500 per cent increase in the taxation arrangements for visits to the Great Barrier Reef will discourage tourism and cost jobs in Queensland;

(23)
the Government has failed to honour its promise to not cut Australia's foreign aid beyond the election commitment to abolish the DIFF program, and in doing so will allow the estimated ODA/GDP ratio for Australia in 1996‐97 to fall to 0.29 per cent;

(24)
the Government has failed to honour its election promise that Defence expenditure would not be cut, whilst cutting $165 million from the 1995 Defence Budget estimates for 1996‐97, and reducing Defence expenditure as a percentage of GDP to its lowest level since 1939;

(25)
the mean‐spirited and discriminatory approach to migrants and ethnic communities will harm outworkers, hurt newly‐arrived migrants and refugees, cut humanitarian aid and penalise asylum seekers;

(26)
the substantial cuts to ATSIC and to indigenous‐related Commonwealth programs represent a massive setback to the process of reconciliation in Australia;

(27)
the savage cuts to the ABC, of $209 million over four years, are in complete breach of the Coalition's solemn election promise to maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC;

(28)
the Budget has failed to honour the promise to maintain levels of arts funding and spend an additional $60 million over three years; and

(29)
the Government's plan to substantially increase Commonwealth court and tribunal fees, coupled with deep cuts to legal aid, will result in a severe curtailment of access to justice by many Australians".

speech.speaker: Brough, Mal, MP

talk.start.para: —Since 20 August, when we had the budget handed down—the first coalition budget in more than 13 years—we have heard from both sides and we have heard a lot of rhetoric. What I want to do this morning is to put the case on exactly what Labor achieved in its 13 years, so that the Australian people can look at some of the rhetoric which has been flowing, and will continue to flow in the next fortnight of sittings, and make a judgment as to the credibility of some of the statements that have been made.

speech.para:
Mr Keating promised not to increase the overall tax burden but to honour the l‐a‐w tax pledge of the 1993 election campaign. He committed his government to a total of $14 billion
in tax cuts but Australians were subjected to $13.4 billion in new taxes. When the 1993‐94 budget was brought down, some of the highlights were: an increase in wholesale sales tax by two per cent, from 20 to 22 per cent, obviously impacting directly upon many Australian families and many of the goods that they purchase; an increase in petrol tax of 7c and 5c on leaded and unleaded petrol respectively, another major impost on average Australian families; an increase in the excise on tobacco of 15 per cent; the taxation as normal income of lump sum payments for unused annual leave and long service leave; the imposition of FBT on salary package benefits such as membership of social clubs; a tightening of the safety net for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme—and haven't we heard a lot about that in this session of the parliament; restricted access to Medicare benefits for optometry services; a reduction in the growth of defence spending; and the pushing of the pension age for women to 65 over a 20‐year period.

The 1993‐94 budget changed Austudy and changed HECS repayments to commence earlier and at higher rates. Yet Labor complains when we make similar changes to HECS in a responsible budget. Labor realigned HECS with income tax arrangements, so payments reflected the proportion of the year for which those with HECS obligations earned above the repayment threshold. That was in 1994‐95. It increased departure tax to $27 and increased recovery costs of aviation safety standards.

In 1995‐96 Labor increased the Medicare levy. It increased the tax on motor vehicles by six per cent, taking it to 22 per cent; increased company tax by three per cent, to 36 per cent; increased the tobacco tax once again by 10 per cent; increased PAYE tax payments; and increased thresholds for the pharmaceutical benefit schemes. The l‐a‐w tax cuts were never delivered.

talk.start.para: —The l‐i‐e.

—Yes, the l‐i‐e tax cuts. I thank the member for Fisher. The point that I make here is that, whether we are talking about HECS, pharmaceuticals or aged care, whatever we are talking about, the 1993‐94, 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 Keating budgets attacked many of these areas. Labor increased taxes, it increased the burden, and yet the opposition stands up in this parliament and derides this government for the position that it takes. The big difference is this: I would have had no problem with the raising of taxes that Labor undertook if it had been going to result in some improvement to the Australian overall economy. But it did not do that. The previous government simply spent more money. When you spend more money, at the end of the day you do not improve Australia's fiscal position, you do not improve the outlook for the generations to come.

speech.para: Under Labor, family household debt rose to over $200 million, or the equivalent of nearly 70 per cent of household disposable income. The current account deficit increased to $2.6 billion in May 1995 and foreign debt rose from $23 billion to $185 billion over the term of the former Labor government.

talk.start.para: —How much?

—It rose from $23 billion in 1983 to in excess of $185 billion net debt in the term of the former Labor government. Australia's economic sovereignty was put at risk, with net foreign debt liabilities as a proportion of GDP at the third worst in the industrial world, ranking 45th out of 49 countries in terms of external debt to exports.

speech.para:
Under Labor we saw the worst economic downturn in 60 years. Home mortgage rates hit 17 per cent and business loans hit 20 per cent. Yet the opposition talks about fiscal
management, it talks about constraint and it complains when we try to bring down what has been seen not only by the financial markets but by Australians in general as a responsible budget.

Under the Labor regime we saw 1.9 million Australians living in poverty. The level of income per person under Labor fell from 10th place in the world to 22nd in a period of 10 years. We are supposed to be the lucky country. Twenty‐four per cent of all families had no family member employed and more than 600,000 children under 14 lived where no‐one had a job.

That very clearly spells out the rubbish that we have heard in this place in the last few weeks. The difference is that yes, this government is making cuts, that yes, this government is taking a more responsible attitude towards the debt that was imposed upon it by the previous government, but we are going to benefit from it. We are benefiting from it already.

Let us look at what has happened since this government came to power. We have had two reductions in home mortgage interest rates of approximately 0.5 per cent which have impacted on families. The people who are benefiting are the people out there who are trying to keep a roof over their heads. Housing is becoming more affordable.

talk.start.para: —Was that before the budget or after it?
—The member opposite asks, `Was that before or after the budget?' It was before the budget because you could already see the fiscal position that was being set up.
—It will help the families in Longman.

—It will help not only the families in Longman; it will help families right throughout Australia. We have also seen a reduction of one per cent in Australia's long-term rates. But, most importantly, the risk factor that Australia pays, the premium we pay for having had such a disgraceful economic management record over the last 13 years, has been reduced since this government has been in power because of the budget measures that were brought down on 20 August by the Treasurer, Mr Costello.

speech.para: We now have a premium of a 1.2 per cent risk factor as opposed to a 2.2 per cent risk factor that we were paying. This effectively means cheaper money for Australian businesses and Australian families. It means that we are no longer going to be connected, because of our foreign debt, by an umbilical cord to overseas companies.

I would also like to speak about the other legacy of this mismanagement and that is how we sold off the Australian farm. I welcomed the Prime Minister's initiative last week with the supermarket to Asia but the reality of the situation is we now own only 20 per cent of our food production in this nation, a nation which has a great record for having one of the most efficient farming sectors in the world.

In 1989 there was $52.9 billion of foreign ownership in Australia. Foreign investment is not a bad thing, but in 1989 it was $52.9 billion. In 1996, some seven years later, that figure has now reached $190.1 billion of foreign ownership. What have we lost in that time? We have lost an enormous number of national icons and they are things which mean a lot to Australian families. We say, `Let's buy Australian', but when people turn up to the shops and the kids want a packet of lollies they go and get a packet of Lifesavers. What better Australian icon could you have?

talk.start.para: —The Iced Vo‐Vos are gone!

—The Iced Vo‐Vos have gone, Tim Tams have gone, and Lifesavers have gone. If you go to the beach the Speedos have gone as well. If an Australian goes to the pub to have an Australian beer he cannot choose Tooheys, he cannot choose XXXX, and he cannot have a Swan because they are all owned by New Zealand. When he pulls on his Stubbies in a morning, or his King Gees, he is not pulling on Australian brand names any more because these companies are owned by the USA.

speech.para: Of course, like myself, a good Australian worker likes to have a Bundaberg rum. There is no point in having that if you are going to support Australian owned products because it is owned by the UK. We all remember when we used to have the Sidchrome super test cricket team and we would have the commentators speaking long and hard about who was going to make it. The Sidchrome super test team really should be a USA team these days because it is no longer an Australian company; it is owned by the USA.

The Fairfax media group is partially owned by Canada, as is the TEN network. Yates Seeds is also foreign owned. As for Qantas, you cannot fly in and out of the country without putting money into foreign ownership. The Brashs retail group is another. You cannot buy anything Australian owned these days. Solahart is another. What about Aeroplane Jelly? There was nothing more Australian than Aeroplane Jelly and now it has gone too.

Of course, for people in the bush, the Liberal Party is a party that recognises regional and rural Australia. The Liberal Party does represent the bush. We have more members in the bush than any other party. In fact, the Labor Party has only two members in this parliament representing regional Australia. The bottom line is that when bush people go out there to protect themselves on the wild, open plains of Australia and they put on the Akubra hat and their Drizabones, hey, they are supporting overseas industries as well. That is the legacy of our Labor opposition. As the headline said on Saturday, 13 July, in the
Sydney Morning Herald
, we are fiddling while the farm is being sold off to foreigners. Only 20 per cent of our food assets are now remaining in Australian ownership.

I would like to read a quote from that particular article in the
Sydney Morning Herald
. It says:
Fundamentally, the problem is Australians can't, or won't, save and governments don't do much to help them save.

Well, this budget that was brought down on 20 August shows exactly what savings can be achieved. It is bringing the budget into balance in three years. I might add, that is exactly what the shadow Treasurer, Mr Gareth Evans, has said should happen. He said three years is a responsible way of going about it. Certainly, there has been hardship but Australians have accepted that this needs to happen. You could say that the Liberal Party and the National Party have brought down a responsible and a caring budget for the future.

Before concluding I would like to make one other point regarding the budget and it concerns something which is going to impact very directly on the people of Longman. I am referring to the change from Medicare offices to local agencies. Opposition members like to tell half the story. They are very good at that; they do not seem to be able to tell the full story. Eighty offices are going to be closed. You would say that that is an appalling thing to happen but the reality of the situation is that the closing of 80 Medicare offices means that we are going to be able to open 400 Medicare agencies in regional areas and in outer suburbs such as in Narangba in my electorate.

break.para: In those areas young families have only one car and the breadwinner usually uses that car. Therefore, they cannot access many of the facilities that other people enjoy in central city areas. They will be able now to have a Medicare agency in their region. The people on Bribie Island where we have very much an elderly population, about 15,000 people, are going to be able to access a Medicare agency now. I also hope that we are going to be able to have them in places such as Laidley and Esk. They are only 100 kilometres from the Brisbane GPO but the bottom line is that they may as well be at the back of Bourke for the amount of service that they received under the previous Labor government.

This is a wise use of money. It is revenue neutral but it provides a service to where the people are, and that is what we should be trying to achieve. That is what this government is about. We are not just about fiscal responsibility; we are about using Australian taxpayers' money in the most responsible manner in order to get the results that are needed on the ground for Australians in the bush, in the cities, and right across this great nation.

I am very proud to be representing the people of Longman. We do not have a wealthy electorate. In fact, the average family income is $28,000. That $28,000 is the total income that comes into the family.

talk.start.para: —It is one of the poorest electorates in the country.

—It is. It is in the bottom third of electorates in the entire country as far as average income is concerned. These people want jobs, they want to work and they do not want to mortgage their future. They do not want to put in jeopardy the future of their children. This budget goes a long way to achieving their goals and our goals.

speech.speaker: Price, Roger, MP

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to speak in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996‐97. I have said before that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Liberal Party and the National Party are to be congratulated. They had a resounding win at the last election.
—That is the good news!

—Certainly, that is the good news and that is beyond dispute. The Prime Minister's statement that he would be governing for all Australians was one thing that perhaps allayed some of the fears that many Australians may have had about voting against the previous government.

speech.para: Because this is the budget debate we really do need to say a few things about what is going to happen as a result of the new direction of the new government. Firstly, it is true that this government has set some targets. It has set targets for inflation at around two per cent. In fact, it has exchanged letters between the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the new governor of the Reserve Bank to ensure that the governor is fully aware of what the government desires in relation to inflation. I have to say that having a low inflationary outcome is a good thing and it really would be supported by members on this side of the chamber.

talk.start.para: —Why would you vote for Labor?

—I think you have to understand that there is a difference between the Howard government and the previous government in relation to inflation. We also said that we thought it was a very high priority to have employment increasing. We were very optimistic and desirous of having a very strong growth rate. It is interesting that the government is prepared to set targets for inflation and set targets about getting into a surplus as far as the budget is concerned—and we would support the general thrust of that. We do not agree with what they
are doing; we do not agree when you hack and slash programs and say you are going to put that to getting the budget into surplus. We think getting the budget into surplus is a good thing. But when half of the money is going to pay for your election promises we say that that is electoral deceit and you will eventually get marked down for that.

speech.para: But I want to return to inflation, because you pay a price when you abandon an employment target. You pay a price—and the price is that if you crunch down on inflation, as this government wants to, you are going to see unemployment increase. The budget papers talk about unemployment rising through the year to 8.5 per cent. You would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that figure has already been exceeded. While the growth target in the budget is 3.5 per cent, I really regret to say that I do not think it is going to be met. Already, people are talking about nine per cent through to the year 2000—and even higher. I think you can guarantee one thing about this budget: the growth target will not be met and the unemployment target will be exceeded. That is a tragedy for ordinary Australians, because even if you are in a job you will know people who do not have one or know the despair of not being able to find a job.

On the Labor side, we always felt you needed to put people first, that the best form of economy is a strong economy and sustained growth. I would like to see growth even greater than we were able to achieve under the most difficult circumstances. I just want to put that on the record. And I ask the people of Lindsay, for example, who will have an opportunity to vote, to note that the government will put a target on inflation, a target on growth, but they will not put a target on how they expect unemployment to fall—because they know they cannot achieve it.

We went to the last election—people such as the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Ted Grace) and our new colleague the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield)—proud of the fact that, as a government, we were setting a target up there. We were saying we believed that as Australia, the society we know and love, goes into the new millennium we had to pick the lowest possible level of unemployment. We said, `At every election we have said we would create a certain number of jobs—and we have exceeded that.' When people on the then government side, on the Labor side, set the figure of five per cent unemployment by the year 2000, firstly we were proud of it and, secondly, we knew that on our track record we would meet that target.

But on the government side today they will not tell the people of Australia what they believe. They do not even believe that they should have a target. In other words, compared to inflation, compared to the budget position—whether it is in surplus or deficit—unemployment is not a sufficiently important statistic for the government to pin its name and reputation on. The second reason for that is that they know all their policies are not going to add up to decreasing unemployment but to increasing it. In this respect, they have sadly deceived the people of Australia. I hope that in the by‐election in Lindsay we will get an opportunity to revisit this with the people, because they are good people in Lindsay, my neighbouring seat. They are hard working, industrious, family oriented and, let me say, very concerned about unemployment. Let's see how concerned they are.

When you have been in government, as the honourable member for Fowler and I have, you always reflect on the worst budget and you think, `My god, how might this have been a little different?' Without specifying the budget, I can certainly nominate one that would meet that category. This is a budget full of hidden nasties, and the great irony is that this is the
government that came to office saying, `Look, we are going to introduce a charter of budget honesty.'

talk.start.para: —We will.

—`We will', says the member for Fisher, but he has not done it yet. In the lock‐up, what was the reaction of all the journalists? Not that this is a budget reflecting a charter of budget honesty, but, `Look how deep, how deceptive, this government has been in burying all the many nasties in it.' No honesty, no openness, no transparency, but guile, deceit and deliberately not living up to the commitments they made to the people of Australia. One day they will be brought to account, let me say. We all get brought to account one day. But in a budget speech of so many nasties it is always difficult to identify the thing that upsets you the most, the thing that you find most objectionable.

speech.para: I think what they are doing about unemployment is really objectionable, and I know it affects a lot of my constituents. Unemployment has been consistently a concern of many of my constituents. But I am going to nominate the thing that I find most abhorrent. Perhaps the member for Fisher is not like me, but I say in my electorate the thing that gives me most pleasure is actually going to school kids, meeting with them and answering questions and speaking to them—

talk.start.para: —I do that too.

—Good. And going to speak to the elderly, the senior citizens. I am very proud to be Australian; I am very proud of our country. The children are going to be our future and they are to be nurtured and treated and valued and encouraged. But our senior citizens are the people that have already made their contribution, doing so before my generation. They have done something to develop and make Australia the country it is. It is not that they are not intrinsically nice people; they are. They are lovely and courteous; they give me great support. But they have made a contribution to Australia which I am always happy to acknowledge in terms of what they are leaving me and others. That is why I find what the government is doing about nursing homes so outrageous.
—You did the same thing with hostels.

—I will come to that, and I will send your constituents a copy of the speech. What they are doing is insisting on a pre‐payment, a down payment on death, by senior citizens in their new nursing home arrangements. The member for Fisher says, `Oh, that is what you did with hostels.'
—Didn't you?

—But what a lie. You see, with hostel accommodation people have a choice. They are not medically assessed for getting into a hostel, as the member for Fisher well knows. It is a matter of choice whether you live in your home, live in your flat, live with your folks or go into hostel accommodation. With nursing homes there is a medical assessment—an ACAT team. You have to be medically qualified to get into a nursing home. There is no choice in your medical condition; it is a function of the condition that you are in.

speech.para:
Mr Slipper interjecting
—

talk.start.para:
—You are obviously in favour of a down payment on death for senior citizens. That is the first lie that has been propounded that I want to nail. There is no choice for people who go into nursing homes. You are saying that this is the same as our action on hostels. Let me say this about nursing homes: once a person is medically assessed, whether it is a
millionaire, the people you like to represent—buy your way into anything—or whether it is a pauper; whether you are living in a housing department flat in my electorate or your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, once you are medically assessed you are into that nursing home bed on a first come, first served basis.

speech.para: The government is going to raise $130 million out of this down payment on death by senior citizens. The minister says, `It is not up to us. Nursing homes are going to make the assessment about whether they are going to charge $26,000'—and I believe it is going to be closer to $50,000. The minister says that it is not up to the government; it is up to the nursing homes. It may be the case that some of the religious nursing homes are going to take a very compassionate view of it. Under the funding for hostels, they have to set aside a certain percentage for people who cannot pay an up‐front fee. But this is not the case with this new nursing home imposition. It is going to be left to the people who run it.

Can we say to this government, which is obsessed with bottom lines, profits and private enterprise, that the wealthy Australians who are so well connected to it and who own and operate private nursing homes are suddenly going to say, `If it is a choice between collecting $26,000 or $30,000'—or whatever the figure that the minister cannot provide is, which we know is at least $26,000—`or not we don't want your money, madam. We are going to freely elect to drop our bottom line. We are not really operating under the profit motive, even though we may be listed or incorporated as a company. We are going to choose some poor person who cannot afford it'? The honourable member for Fisher knows that that is absolute rubbish.

The government is doing a number of things to poor, elderly, frail, vulnerable Australians. Firstly, it is saying that if they cannot afford the $26,000 they cannot get into a nursing home, even though they are in a housing commission flat and are medically assessed as requiring a nursing home bed. So their quality of life is going to suffer. When you are medically assessed as requiring nursing home accommodation, you require it. So your quality of life, your medical condition, is going to suffer. This is the destiny for poor, elderly, frail Australians. This is the government's vision of the future.

What if they are living at home? What if a family has been concerned enough to have their mother, father or grandparent living at home with them and the elderly person is assessed as requiring nursing home accommodation? What happens in the situation where the family cannot afford the up‐front payment on death? What will happen is that there will be an increasing incidence of parents being bashed by their children. That is what is going to happen.

I know a lot of senior citizens who are on a pension and are living in their homes. The government says, `No‐one is going to be forced to sell their home.' I will give you an example. This is a true story. There is a couple in my electorate and the husband required heart surgery. They were referred to a cardiologist. They owned some acreage, but were pensioners. They are lovely people. The cardiologist said to them, `Why do you need to live in your home? Why don't you sell this home and land and pay for the operation?' That is the double jeopardy you are going to be putting people in.

What happens where there is a surviving spouse? I will give you another instance, just quoted to me recently, where a wife had been desperate to keep her husband at home. He really needed to go to a nursing home, but she battled to keep him at home. She has had a complete mental breakdown. She is now away from the home being treated. This is the rosy future that the government is painting for elderly, frail Australians, whom it does not value at all.

break.para: Getting back to the pensioner in the house receiving a pension: what happens when one of them requires nursing home treatment? What happens when one spouse is convinced that the only way they can get them into the nursing home is by paying the up‐front fee? I am afraid to say, pensioners do these things. If they sell the house, probably they will not have their pension affected by the assets test, but they will be deemed on proceeds of the sale of gains. Where does that person live in the meantime?

Perhaps, there is an argument that we need to inject $130 million into nursing homes. That is, in a sense, a different argument. But not one cent of this $130 million is going to provide one extra nursing home bed. Not one. You are going to increase the profits of private nursing home owners and operators. I do not say that about the religious and community ones. You are going to increase their bottom line as a dirty election deal.

I think what you are doing about nursing homes is absolutely shameful. To suggest, as has been suggested, that it is the same as you are doing for hostels is nothing more than a deliberate, dirty untruth.

talk.start.para: —Do you not deny that a lot of people had to go into hostels for medical reasons?
—Are you talking about dementia? What proportion of the aged are you saying are demented?
—Order!

—People are medically assessed by health care professionals as requiring nursing home treatment. I cannot volunteer to go into a nursing home. My mother cannot volunteer to go into a nursing home. My father, I regret to say, or thankfully, is already in a nursing home. But people cannot volunteer their grandparents or their mothers to go in. They have to be medically assessed.

break.para: I know that the honourable member for Fisher is thick, but I wish he would cotton on to this point. I think that probably, once he fully understands the policy, having got out amongst his senior citizens for whom he has interjected and for whom he has so much admiration, he is going to be embarrassed and, I hope, humiliated. I hope he will be motivated to want to change. I think that this is horrific—absolutely bloody horrific.

talk.start.para: —This government supports senior citizens.

—Supports them! By instituting a new up‐front down payment on death that does not add one nursing home bed in Australia! Old people do not want to be a burden on their families. Their one desire in life is to see out their remaining years with dignity and not put any financial burdens on anyone. You have put a new financial terror into this nursing home proposition. Much as the honourable member may interject, it only demonstrates, I think, that even he with his thick hide may be a little bit discomforted by these new arrangements. I say to my senior citizens that I value them.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP

talk.start.para: —In saying a few words today, I think that the first thing to do is to get into perspective the background to the budget. Three dreadful decisions have been made in this country. One of them was the abolition and, it must be added, the undermining of the reserve price scheme for wool in this country.

speech.para:
One tenth of this nation's entire export earnings throughout its history has come from wool. In 1988, one‐tenth of this nation's export earnings came from a single commodity, wool. The last thing that any government should have done was to play around with wool, but
government did. The net result of it was that when the economic rationalists took us into the paradise of enlightenment that we are now in the world's wool buyers were able to buy our wool for $3,000 million a year, instead of $6,000 million a year.

On behalf of the world's wool buyers and wool traders, I would like to say thank you to the Australian people for selling a product at around half of its cost of production to us for the last six years. The people that enabled them to do that were the economic rationalists, the people who are the architects of the misery in this country, and they are still riding high in all parts of government.

I will move on. The second decision was to deregulate the banking sector. Let me go to no lesser authority than Trevor Sykes and his book
The Bold Riders
. He designates that, in four short years, there was a loss of $28,000 million. In that book—that brilliant tour de force, giving an understanding of what happened in the 1980s in Australia—Trevor Sykes delineated the cause of the loss of that $28,000 million. That is a lot of money. That is costing this country, to this day, $3,000 million a year.

So there were two decisions which cost this country $6,000 million a year. The third decision—for which we must thank, as with all three of these decisions, our economic rationalist friends—was the deregulation of the oil industry. As one person put it to me yesterday, it is like the invisible suit of clothes in this place. Outsiders with any sense say, `What is going on here? This economic rationalism is madness.'

We deregulated 90 per cent of the oil industry in this country. Having proved how successful it was, now we are going to deregulate the other 10 per cent of it. That will indicate the enlightenment that we have in this place. Since the time we deregulated it, the world's price for oil has dropped clean in half, from $34 a barrel down to about $17 or $18 a barrel. But in Australia the price paid to the oil companies in the same period of time doubled.

People say to me, `That is ridiculous. Where did you get those figures from?' I thought everyone knew that the world price of oil had dropped clean in half. But, of course, they think it is all taxation. When they go and fill up at the bowser they know that the price they pay has far more than doubled but they think that it is all taxation. Whilst a lot of it is taxation, the fact is that the price paid to the oil companies rose from 12½ cents a litre to 22 cents a litre in that same period of time. So, while the world price dropped almost clean in half, the Australian price doubled.

That means that the oil companies are taking from the people of Australia $6,000 million a year that they are not entitled to—they are not entitled to one cent of that—because of the slackness in our antimonopolistic legislation and our lack of determination to enforce that legislation in this country. If you take all the taxes off here, we are looking at something around 36 cents a litre. In the United States, the last time I looked, it was 26 cents a litre. They have adequate antimonopoly legislation which they enforce.

That is the background to this budget. If you doubt the extent of the damage that economic rationalists have done to this country, I will quote you some figures. Let us look at average weekly earnings in this country over the last 13 years, under the great hammer of economic rationalism, Mr Keating. I do not doubt for a moment that he has many enthusiastic supporters on our side of the House, so I am not going to stand here and be hypocritical enough to say that it is not the same on our side of the House. These people just seem to keep going with policies without ever assessing whether they work or not.

break.para: If you get my speeches from the state parliament, you will find that I was a very strong economic rationalist 15 years ago. You will get a lot of speeches along these lines from me. But I kept watching the figures. I had to say to myself, `This policy is not working.' I then had to put my tail between my legs and run, because I was monitoring what was happening out there and what were the results of these decisions. The results of these decisions were absolutely disastrous for this country—the three costing $12,000 million a year.

As for average weekly earnings, let me quote the figures and be very specific. In 1983, 61.6 was the CPI index. In 1995, it was 117.6. There was a rise in the CPI of 56 per cent between 1983 and 1995. Average weekly earnings in the same period rose from $341 to $654 and that gave us a rise in average weekly earnings of 47.9 per cent. So average weekly earnings trailed the cost of living by 8.1 per cent. Every person who was on an income in this country was down 8.1 per cent.

But that was only a small part of the story. Federal, state and local taxes rose from $52,000 million per year to $151,000 million per year in the same period. Since one‐third of all our income goes on taxes, that translates into a reduction of 17.7 per cent in take‐home pay for the average wage‐earner. The average wage‐earner in Australia has suffered a loss in his purchasing power of 26 per cent in the last 13 years under these policies.

We now have the highest juvenile suicide rate in the world. Very sadly for me, my electorate is outside the metropolitan area. The suicide rate outside the metropolitan area is six times higher than that in the metropolitan area. I do not have to tell this House of the sea of human misery that exists outside of this place; yet the policies that have created this sea of human misery are continuing unabated. On both sides of the House, there are people who are still out there advocating and implementing these policies. It is deeply regrettable that these people have, like the Bourbons, forgotten nothing and learnt nothing.

We have, this year, the highest bankruptcy rates in Australian history. The figures for the past three quarters have all been over 4,000. Let me be very specific. In the past three quarters, there were 12,493 bankruptcies. The March quarter, which is the last quarter for which we have got figures, had the worst figures in Australia's history. On present trends, the final quarter almost certainly will go over the 16,780 bankruptcies of three years ago. It is the worst year for Australian business in Australian history. That is what we have come to, after 13 or 14 years of economic rationalism.

Average weekly earnings are down 26 per cent. As far as unemployment goes, add to the other unemployment figures the figures for the part‐time unemployed—because, as we all know, if you work for an hour per week, you are registered as employed, not unemployed—together with the labour market program figures, which the current minister said were over 200,000 but which, on my figures, were most certainly 198,000, and, on top of that, the CDEP figures, which are another 26,000.

When you add the three figures together—for the labour market program people, the people who cannot get a full‐time job, and the people employed part‐time for an hour per week—you come up with a figure, according to Minister Kemp, of 17 per cent. If you would like to go to the past chairman of the Labor economics caucus committee, John Langmore, he says it is 16.5 per cent. Dr John Quiggin, who won the Academy of Science prize in the year before last, quotes the figure as being between 16.5 and 17.5 per cent. I think that we can reasonably assume that the real unemployment rate in this country is 17 per cent.

During the Great Depression, there were only about four years in which unemployment was over 17 per cent. In the United States, it was only over 17 per cent for three years. Whilst we do not have the human pain that was inflicted during the Great Depression—because we have, some might say, adequate unemployment benefits—the human misery that is entailed in not having a job is communicated through the suicide rates in this country. That is where we can find out what it means in this country to have no job and no hope for the future.

Let me compare, for those who laud economic rationalism in this country. The very antithesis of economic rationalism was John McEwen. A lot of people say that he and Menzies got their own way all the time. Most certainly, he was the driving force as far as economics went, and he was roundly criticised for his policies. Let us look at the score card in the last year of John McEwen policies. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will have to bear with me, because I am going to compare these figures with the 1991 figures, and most of these figures are worse now than they were in 1991, of course.

Unemployment in 1972 stood at 1.9 per cent; in 1991, at 10.5 per cent. The balance of payments in 1972 showed a $754 million surplus. The current account was in surplus. In 1991, there was a $16,000 million deficit. In 1972 there were 2,648 bankruptcies and, in 1991, there were 13,091. In 1972, the value of the Australian dollar was such that it took a whopping great $US1.28 to buy an Australian dollar. In 1991, the value of the Australian dollar was $US0.76, or ¥384; and it is now ¥95. In 1972, interest rates stood at 7.7 per cent and, in 1991, at 15.5 per cent. In 1972, taxation was at $8.9 billion and, in 1991, $97.9 billion.

The interest paid on foreign debt in 1972 was $425 million. The interest paid on foreign debt in 1991 was $19,000 million. Which were the successful policies? They say the world has changed. If we take the phrases used by the current economic rationalists and the phrases used by the people attacking Ted Theodore during the Great Depression, I hate to tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, but it is the same phraseology, the same turn of phrase—the same words are even being used.

How do we get out of the hole that we are in at the present moment? Believe me, we are in a depression. The only reason we do not know that is because we now pay adequate social security payments, which we did not pay during the 1930s. How do we get out of that hole? In fairness to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and to the government, it is very hard to keep borrowing money. Three years ago, the interest paid by the federal government was $3,880 million. The interest paid in 1996 was $9,390 million. If the interest bill keeps exploding at that rate, all of our taxation in a 10‐year time frame most certainly will go to paying interest just on the federal government's debt.

We cannot keep borrowing money, but cutting back on government spending in a recession is not what should be done. That is the very last thing that we should do. The message from what happened in the 1930s was that, when the economy is in recession, cutting back on government spending is the most disastrous move that can be made.

So how do we solve this conundrum? To break the cycle, we have to look at adequate anti‐monopoly laws. We must look at giving our commodity producers, be they wool producers or copper producers or whatever, the ability to collectively market their product. Unless they can collectively market their product, then the little sheep cocky outside of Longreach is being pitted against the might of Itoh of Japan, one of the biggest trading houses in the world.

The little sheep cocky outside of Richmond or Julia Creek or Longreach is going to go under, and he is going under at the present moment. The Australian people are going down
as well, because half of our sheep herd—this nation's greatest asset—has already gone. So we must give our commodity producers the right to collectively and aggressively market their product, instead of, as we have been doing in this place, removing that right. That is what we did when we abolished the minimum price scheme in wool. There are many other examples I could use. Three thousand million dollars a year is the benefit in wool alone.

Another example is the tobacco industry. A lot of people think that it is collapsing because people are stopping smoking. It has really got nothing to do with that whatsoever. There were 660 tobacco farmers in Australia and now there are about 260. The reason for that was the removal of the marketing schemes that existed previously.

If we got stuck into the oil companies and took them on—the same as that great and courageous President of the United States, Theodore Roosevelt, did at the start of this century—we would enjoy the same sorts of prices that are enjoyed in the United States. That would save this country $6,000 million. Just with those two commodities—wool and petrol—this country could save $9,000 million a year if we had a bit of backbone and aggression and took the same aggressive policies that were taken in the days of people like John McEwen and Sir Robert Menzies.

To move on, there are some three or, arguably, six major water schemes in Australia which, if we proceed with them, as the Americans did during the Great Depression, will bring into this country $5,000 million a year. I have not got time to go into much detail here. As far as mining goes, if the laws with respect to the Native Title Act are put into place properly and if we stand up to the ridiculous obsession which some people have with the environment and which takes us into absolute lunacy areas, then we will produce for this country great wealth that is not being produced at the present moment. In just six mines in North Queensland and at the top of Western Australia there is $5,000 million worth of production being held up, some of it indefinitely, because of those twin problems that exist in Australia today.

In the prawn farming industry, the greenies are winning to such an extent that prawn farming is actually going down—production is actually going down in this country—because they are succeeding in closing more farms than we can open. So a tiny little country like Thailand, with a coastline about one‐twentieth the size of Queensland's coastline or maybe even less than that, is producing $2.2 thousand million worth of prawns a year, whereas Australia is producing from her prawn farms under $100 million a year. And that figure, in all probability at the present moment, is falling. So there is $2,000 million in prawn farming alone to add to that list. Moreover, in the area of ethanol phosphate and converting a lot of our transportation systems to electricity there is another $2,000 million that this country can make but is not making at the present moment. Those micro‐schemes, specific target areas, are worth $23,000 million a year to the Australian economy.

If we are looking for money, surely primage is the way to go. All the federal government's income before the First World War came from primage, which is simply a charge on every single product coming into this country, an across‐the‐board charge. I cannot quote you the section from GATT, but it is GATT neutral. The income can be bought in that way at 10 per cent and will most certainly give our struggling manufacturing industries—and even, now, some of our food industries—some desperately needed respite against countries where people are forced to work for $2 a day.

We should move into the area of income splitting. You may want to know why we have the highest juvenile suicide rate in the world. In a single‐income family, where a bloke is
working and the wife chooses to stay at home and look after her kids properly, if the husband is on the average Australian income he starts with $34,424. After tax is taken out he is left with $26,182. If there are four people, including his wife and two children, that works out at $6,500 each. That is what they have got to get by on. If it is a double‐income family, where the wife chooses to work, they are on $52,364 a year after tax is taken out. That leaves them on $14,000 a year each. But if it is a DINK family—double income and no kids—as so many Australian families are today, they are on $26,000 each.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you: would you like to be on $6,500 a year each or would you like to be on $26,000 a year each? If you are a DINK you are on $26,000. If you are like me and like so many of the rest of us and your wife chooses to look after your children, and if you are on the average Australian income, you are on $6,500 a year each. That is the reason why women are being forced out into the work force against their will. That is the reason why our young people truly are so unhappy today that they are doing away with themselves.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Filing, Paul, MP

talk.start.para: —The member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) has just delivered a first‐class speech on behalf of his constituents. He would make a good Independent member, as a matter of fact. What I want to say at the beginning of my speech relates to the fact that we are debating the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996‐97, a very important bill, here in the Main Committee, which was set up—as I well know, being a former member of the Procedures Committee at the time—to deal with non‐contentious legislation. Here we are in the Main Committee, out of the main chamber, debating what is, effectively, the most important legislation of the year, and the government considers this to be part and parcel of a responsible working parliamentary democracy. I can say that that was outside the scope of the intent of the formation of the Main Committee, well outside.

speech.para: This was designed to deal with non‐contentious legislation and it was designed to offer members the opportunity of speaking on those non‐contentious bills for which, often, the speaking time had concertinaed because of more pressing government matters on the government legislative calendar. We find ourselves now here in this room debating, in effect in the secondary chamber of the House of Representatives, the most important piece of legislation the government has this year. In my view, this is an abrogation of the responsibility of the government. The government made it clear in the election campaign that it was going to raise the standards of parliamentary debate. It was going to improve the way in which we conducted our affairs. It was going to make the Speaker more independent.

What we have, in effect, is the executive leaning on the House of Representatives and forcing the legislation which is, basically, going to fund a large amount of the government's election promises—and some of the things it did not promise in the election, which I am going to come to—to be debated here, away from the main stage in the main chamber. That is not only a shame; it is a disgrace. I have made that point clear elsewhere and I will continue to do so until the government realises that people in the wider community will not put up with this. Then it will have to change. The government, in essence, is using the power of its numbers to squash the opportunity for members to make their contribution in the main chamber of the House of Representatives.

There are no ministers here, no parliamentary secretaries. Nobody is listening. Nobody is interested. That also, to my way of thinking, demonstrates the contempt that the executive government has for the contributions of individual members. In other words, all these things
that are occurring in the House of Representatives, either here or in the other chamber, are entirely irrelevant to the conduct of government business. The way in which the government is conducting itself is not only no better than the conduct of the previous administration, in many instances it is worse. It is more authoritarian and, in fact, it is more oppressive than the worse excesses of the Keating government—and believe me, they were bad enough.

What is happening now is that the government is doing more than the Keating government did. The Keating government set up the Main Committee. I was an opponent of it in the first instance, because I believed that the Main Committee would relegate aspects of debate from the main chamber into the Main Committee and there would be a secondary debate. Members of the public probably would not even know this chamber exists, and the members of parliament would feel that their contribution was being treated with contempt. What we have, in essence, is exactly what I predicted, coming true now. But that is not under the Keating government: to be fair to the Keating government, for all the other excesses it brought to the Australian parliament, the Keating government never referred other than non‐contentious legislation to this Committee, except in a couple of instances when it was pulled up, quite rightly, by individual members.

I just make this observation: if the government thinks this sort of thing is going to go on unchallenged, it has another think coming. It really has to fulfil the promise it made to the electorate in the election campaign, that it was going to make parliamentary debates, the parliamentary processes, more relevant to the community. It would raise them, to make sure that the government and the parliamentary process was an effective part of our system of governance. We in this place would all know in the bottom of our hearts that much of what we might say and much of what we might do, as far as the government is concerned, is worth nothing, because it chooses purely to ignore it.

We have seen occasions in recent times when the government has chosen to use numbers to crush individual motions. One instance was, in my view, a dreadful occurrence: a member who chose to move two similar divisions was ruled to be obstructionist and the second division was considered to be out of order. That is interesting, compared with the situation where the Labor opposition has moved three divisions on exactly the same thing but they have not had the same ruling applied to them. It is interesting that there seems to be one rule for some and another rule for the others.

The general thrust of the budget, in most areas, is commendable. I know that the member for Kennedy and others share some very strong reservations about the economic rationalist aspects of the government's agenda, and I do too. But there are a number of areas where the government has been forced into accepting greater fiscal accountability and responsibility as its essential duty to the community. After all, we are here, in essence, dealing with the expenditure of taxpayers' money, and we have a very substantial duty to make sure that is done properly, it is accountable and transparent.

In more recent times the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) pointed out that, in the Primary Industries Amendment Bill which was before this place some time ago, there was a $24 million appropriation from the non‐wool assets of wool farmers to what was called Wool Holdings International, which was a body designed to encourage the sale of wool on the futures market. And how much description was there, in the documentary material which accompanied the bill, about what that was going to be used for? There were two lines in the explanatory memorandum. Did that arouse much interest or concern on the part of the
government? Very little at all. It is incredible that $24 million can be appropriated with only two lines of explanatory memorandum. That is incredible. That is $12 million per line. It is a very expensive explanatory memorandum.

But there are a few areas in the budget which I would like to address now and they cause me some concern. I was elected in Moore as the Independent member with, in my view, a role to play to try and ensure, as much as I am able, that the promises that the government made in the election campaign are kept. I have to say that a number of them have not been kept, and there are a number of things in the budget which were not foreshadowed. Some people have found them to their cost.

The government cannot talk on the one hand of providing incentives for development, prosperity and the public good and then place legislative and administrative fiscal disincentives in the way. I am going to address a few areas where I think that the government can provide innovation and improvement. One is a light fuel oil excise rebate, something the member for Kennedy would know about because this also affects, I would imagine, areas of his own electorate. It is a matter of considerable concern to regional Australians, especially those in Western Australia and Queensland. The government made a very good decision, in my view, to leave in place the excise exemption for light fuel oil used in the mining and farming industries. I was one of those that lobbied the government to try and ensure that this took place. But I am concerned that the government has not addressed the anomaly created by the previous government where the rebate was removed for power generation.

Regional and remote Australia are very dependent on distillate based power generation and thus are highly vulnerable to any increases that occur in fuel pricing. Most electricity consumption in regional and remote areas is directly related to mining and primary industry activities. So there is a little bit of a dilemma or an incongruous situation here. The government has imposed an excise on the fuel used by utilities generating electricity for consumption by the mining and primary industry sectors, and yet it provides exemptions for distillate used by the mining companies in those sectors.

The situation is being exacerbated by the previous government increasing the light fuel excise from 6.5c per litre to 33c per litre. In my state, this increased Western Power's regional power division costs by $18 million, to a record $44 million loss. Western Power generates and distributes electricity to 19,000 customers in 29 regional towns from Esperance to Kununurra. Much of Western Power's electricity is subject to contractual arrangements where initial costs could not be passed on to major consumers.

Western Power is subject to the national competition policy—which I am sure the member for Kennedy has some strong views about—which disallows subsidisation to the regional divisions with profits from the metropolitan operation.

talk.start.para: —That was brought out by Mr Hilmer, the head of the power industry in New South Wales—

—I was going to say that the only recourse in the case of Western Australia will be significant price increases in electricity for regional users. Large regional users face an increase of 30c per kilowatt hour from July next year, compared to the total cost now of 12c per kilowatt hour for supply to a metropolitan household. So, there is a substantial disincentive for businesses operating directly or indirectly in support of mining and primary industries, and it has great implications for development and quality of life in regional WA.

break.para: This excise is an inequitable outback tax and it causes an inefficiency in infrastructure decisions and a significant burden to regional WA and to Queensland, I might add, where there are a number of areas where power is generated through diesel fuel. I call on the government to extend the light oil fuel rebate to cover the generation of electricity by utilities.

The other aspect where I have got some substantial concerns is the cuts in low levels of federal funding in the budget for programs which are related to fighting and preventing crime. These budget cuts are damaging to the morale and effectiveness of organisations such as the AFP and the NCA.
