Public order and safety spending is decreasing significantly as a percentage of the total Commonwealth budget, and this is occurring when the risks to the community from crime continue to increase.

The AFP is a principal law enforcement agency through which the Commonwealth pursues its law enforcement interests. This budget reduces funding for 1997 by $19.2 million in running costs, $1.2 million in outlays for plant and equipment, and $1.8 million in appropriations for buildings or works.

The government gave an election commitment to increase funding for fraud investigation by the AFP. This cannot be maintained. This budget means that the AFP will lose staff and resources. The AFP has shown that there is a direct correlation between operational resources and operational performance. Cuts in resources here will mean a cut in narcotics seizures, investigated frauds and proceeds of crime confiscations. The reduction in the AFP's policing effort will affect the entire Australian policing operation. I share the concern of the Police Federation of Australia that this funding reduction puts at risk the whole reform program for the AFP.

I might add that in my home state it is estimated there is $1 billion of illicit drugs entering over the state border per annum. I might also say that in the face of funding cuts in Australian Customs, the NCA, the AFP, and the Western Australian Police Force—in effect, real cuts—we are going to see a significant problem become even more of a concern. In Western Australia we have significantly higher crime rates than the Australian average. As I have described before, Australia is a place where you are far more likely to have your home burgled or to be robbed or assaulted without a weapon than in the United States. This is something a lot of people do not realise. Crime is on the increase. It is a serious problem. And I am appalled that the government has chosen to target the AFP in particular for those significant funding cuts, as well as the NCA.

The Australian Institute of Criminology was established to conduct research, policy analysis and information dissemination on criminal justice issues. It is a valuable resource in our nation's fight against crime. It has meant, in effect, that the state police services have not had to devote resources of their own to similar statistical research. But there is one particular aspect of it that I am sure the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) would be concerned about too. That is that the budget statement relating to the Australian Institute of Criminology has proposed the discontinuance of the AIC's violence against women project.

I would have thought that members of the government would be appalled at that particular prospect. It is something that I hope they will work within their party fora to have overturned. It has a direct application in the fight against violence against women. We know that that is a matter of very serious concern in Australia, not only to women but to all responsible members of the community. Under the circumstances, given that the state police forces have used the Australian Institute of Criminology statistical research for their own particular
workings, I would have thought that that was a matter for grave concern on the part of government members who I know share my concerns about the problems of violent crime against women—and, of course, domestic violence as well.

The dental program is another area where there have been some serious concerns. In effect, the cessation of the dental program is really a decision to underfund the last year of the program by half. We know that dental care delivery is a state responsibility. But the Commonwealth did develop the program to meet the high level of need in the community for this type of support. There is not any great evidence of a reduction in the demand, and I am concerned to a certain extent that the measure is short‐sighted.

In the circumstances, knowing that dental care is an important component of health care, I think we will see an increase of costs in general health delivery as a result, because the interesting thing is that if you do not get your teeth sorted out, often that can lead to other health problems. We know that in a lot of cases, and certainly from the past, dental health care was considered to be one of the most important aspects of personal health care because of the primary fact that we have to use our mouths in order to be able to eat and drink. Therefore, dental health care is of significance and I call on the government to increase state funding that can be directly attributable to dental care because of the circumstances I have just mentioned.

The changes to deeming for pensioners is another area of concern. They say it is a measure to simplify and reduce the intrusive nature of the taxation system. Independent commentators have stated that the effect of this change is that pensioners must ensure that their money must achieve a return of at least five per cent to avoid being disadvantaged. I have stated that I am opposed to any measures taken by the government that will disadvantage pensioners. I am sure many of the members of the government—

para.emphasis: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

talk.start.para: —I call on the government to reverse its decision on the extension of deeming rules for pensioners and to reinstate the previous exemption of the first $2,000 for singles and $4,000 for couples. Given the difficulty in gaining the five per cent return after operating costs in their working accounts that the original exemption was designed to provide for, I will continue to oppose this measure. It is unfair. It is, in my view, an unnecessary burden on pensioners. It is a burden that, in the first instance, was placed on pensioners to bring about some sort of fairness in relation to the likely unearned income that pensioners might be achieving with some of their financial assets. But, in this case, it is purely and simply an extra whammy on pensioners that they do not deserve.

break.para: In the time that I have left, I want to address a couple of points. One is in relation to AQIS. The federal government funding for both the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the Customs Service remains inadequate in relation to the risks our community faces. AQIS must be made efficient and maintained as such. This is not just in terms of its inspection and prophylactic services but also, most importantly, in terms of the quality of advice it gives to the government.

We have the potential to further develop as a major producer of safe, healthy foodstuffs throughout the region. This is at constant risk from imported pests and diseases. Recently, serious weeds such as cleavers and red shank have entered Australia in canola seeds from New Zealand. Other introduced pests include the golden apple snail, which poses a serious risk to
the rice industry, and fire blight, which could seriously affect our apple production and devastate our pear industry.

The potential damage to Australian industry if infected products such as cooked chicken meat or salmon products are allowed to be imported is enormous. With AQIS funding at its present levels, this becomes more highly likely.

The government must have confidence in the advice of AQIS, and AQIS and the government must be accountable for the actions taken under the advice. In this matter, I give notice to the government that I intend, along with the member for Kalgoorlie, to move a private member's bill to make the Commonwealth government of the day more responsible for the losses that are incurred by producers as a result of decisions made under the advice of AQIS.

Finally, I will go back to the point that I made at the beginning in relation to our system of parliamentary democracy. I will make some comments in relation to some changes to the constitution that are absolutely necessary.

I recognise and applaud the fact that the funding appropriated in this bill is directly related to the implementation of one of the most wide‐ranging changes in direction for Australian society. There was a mandate in the election for the government to implement that program and they are in the process of implementing most of it, some of it in areas which were not foreshadowed.

Industrial, social education and employment characteristics will be dramatically altered. The number of government members attests to the very high level of public support for change. But it was not necessarily support for change to a Liberal coalition government. It was a call for a change from the community which had been absolutely sick to its back teeth of 13 years of Labor's inefficient and, in many instances, corrupted government.

This government has announced its intentions to make government fiscally accountable and responsible. I believe that it is time for them to also become legislatively accountable and responsible. In our society we have witnessed a growth industry in political correctness. We have seen relatively small vested interest groups take control of various issues and, eventually, government. This has occurred relatively easily, despite being contrary to the will of the vast majority of the people.

The Westminster system is becoming more cut off from the will and the rights of the people. In essence, the executive virtually operates in an untrammelled fashion vis‐a‐vis the parliament, the House of Representatives and the Senate. We have the situation where, in many instances, the rights and interests of constituents of the members of the House of Representatives are unable to be fulfilled purely and simply because they do not fit in with the program or the will of the executive.

We must allow the Australian people as a whole the right and responsibility to introduce or amend legislation by the power of their votes. I am referring to what are generally known as citizen initiated referenda. I believe the absence of a mechanism for citizen initiated referenda reduces the quality of our parliamentary democracy and also reduces the accountability of our judicial system to those it is meant to serve. I give notice that I will shortly be introducing a bill to provide for an alteration to the constitution to enable the making of laws on the initiative and popular request of electors.

The Westminster system of parliamentary democracy is under a great deal of questioning, scrutiny and threat. We have a system that has evolved over a long period of time. Because
of this imbalance between the power of the executive and the power of the parliament, we are seeing, in essence, an executive dictatorship in this country, not what was originally envisaged—parliamentary democracy. The system needs to be changed. It needs to be changed to be more accountable to the people. It must be more accountable to the people through the processes of the parliament and, of course, through the diligence and efforts of the individual members representing their constituents.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: West, Andrea, MP

talk.start.para: —The medium‐ to long‐term prospects for Australian families, business, industry and youth are heading in the right direction, after an abysmal betrayal of their future by the previous Labor government. I rise to speak on this Appropriation Bill (No.1). Debt and deficit were all we were passing on to our future generations after 13 years of fiscal irresponsibility. The Australian community were led down the yellow brick road by a pied piper who cajoled everyone into believing his tune was the only beat to move to.

speech.para: The Australian taxpaying public were in for a big surprise when the Treasury books were opened to reveal what we all know now: not just the devastating $7 billion deficit that we found initially upon gaining government, but a disastrous final figure of $10 billion. We did not create the problem, but we will fix it. This is the whole purpose of the measures taken by Treasury to restore the economy to surplus. This will not happen without the measures outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the budget documents for 1996‐97.

The legacy of previous Labor budgets, of their failure to cut government spending and their reliance on high interest rates, undermined Australian families and businesses. Under Labor, home mortgage rates hit 17 per cent. Interest rates went up nearly three per cent between August and December 1994. Family household debt rose to over $200 million. The current account deficit reached nearly $2.7 billion in May 1995, the worst figure ever since the statistics began to be collected. Under Labor, nearly one million Australians were out of work. Under Labor, Working Nation, the greatest failure, cost the Australian taxpayer $3.5 billion. What a waste on labour market programs.

Previous budgets increased wholesale sales taxes by two per cent, from 20 to 22 per cent; increased petrol tax; increased excise on tobacco by 15 per cent; reduced the growth of defence spending; changed HECS so repayments commenced earlier and at higher rates; realigned HECS with income tax arrangements so repayments reflected the proportion of the year in which those with HECS obligations earned above the repayment threshold; increased the Medicare levy by 0.1 per cent, to 1.5 per cent; increased tax on motor vehicles by six per cent, from 15 per cent to 22 per cent; increased company tax from 33 to 36 per cent; increased PAYE tax payments to bi‐monthly for small businesses—and the list goes on.

On 2 March, Australians reassessed their priorities. On 2 March, Australians had had enough. On 20 August, the new government outlined the new direction for fiscal responsibility. For families, business, older Australians and those in genuine need, the 20 August budget met our core commitments. The family tax initiative means that a family with two dependent children, earning less than $70,000 per year and taking out private health insurance, will get a tax break of $51.90 per fortnight. That is $450 a year.
These measures will have a positive effect on the constituents in my electorate of Bowman. In fact, one such family, the Mauds, were quoted in my local paper as saying:
It's terrific. We weren't expecting any family assistance. We didn't think the country could afford it.
They went on to say that, while a $17 a week tax rebate on their health insurance costs did not sound like much, it would certainly help. They said:

break.para: It'll make it a lot more comfortable.

The paper pointed out that the Mauds are typical of the type of family in the Bowman electorate. But in my electorate it is not just families who will reap benefits from this budget. The small business sector have expressed their satisfaction with the measures announced, in particular the move to reduce the deficit which has resulted in a reduction to interest rates.

Business is understandably wary of claims made by politicians, and why would it not be? For 13 years business has suffered from the broken promises and inept administration of the Labor Party. Business, particularly the small to medium business sectors, was the punching bag of the former Labor administration. `We need more money? Let's tax business,' seemed to be the creed of the former Labor government.

One of my small businessmen, who was struggling, has described the impact of the previous government on business as a severe bruising. The bruising that business received was in the form of taxation, duplication, employee related issues, licences and complexity. So it is little wonder business is still wary of governments and politicians.

It is the job of this government to regain the trust and confidence of business, and we have already begun the process. These businesses can rest assured that the deregulation task force set up by the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) is addressing the concerns of small business in putting priorities in a less time consuming way.

As I mentioned earlier, interest rates are on the way down, with the most recent drop bringing the rate on variable loans down from 11.25 per cent to 10.75 per cent. This translates to a total saving of up to $2,500 a year for small business with a variable rate loan. This also represents 40 per cent of all small business loans.

To this effect, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have decided to conduct a forum in my electorate to bring together all the interested parties that are going to deal with the future business in Bowman. It is called a business forum and we are looking at addressing the needs of business. We will bring government members and government advisers together to listen to small business and hopefully promote a strategic plan to address the problems in the area.

The new apprenticeship and traineeship scheme will also assist business with employers being eligible for a commencement payment of $1,250 for each apprentice or trainee, a $1,250 progress payment and a bonus for each one taken on above the previous year's intake. Obviously this measure will not only benefit the small to medium enterprises but also benefit the unemployed. The government will spend $207 million over the next four years on the new apprenticeship scheme. That means real jobs for the unemployed, not the never ending training programs that were designed for one purpose: to keep these unemployed off the unemployed numbers list. The former administration spent over $3.5 million on labour market programs that did not work. In fact, two-thirds of the long-term unemployed are still unemployed after going through a Working Nation program. In direct contrast the coalition government will get these people back to work in jobs that last longer than the length of their course.

We will be encouraging the skillshare organisations to move with us and restructure to cope with the changing needs of the Australian people. On a recent trip to Queensland the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and his entourage of hasbeens and wannabes tried to make political mileage by visiting one of my skillshares. His efforts went largely unrewarded as he was forced to admit that the skillshare he visited would survive. I have commended this skillshare for their ingenuity, their responsibility and their accountability. I endorse their management practices and I have encouraged them to continue.

Further to this, the manager of this skillshare was quoted in the local paper as saying his organisation was putting a positive light on the changes and would adapt to them. This goes to show how out of touch with the electorate the Leader of the Opposition is and why the coalition is in government and he is in opposition.

The Labor Party has obviously learnt nothing from the lessons handed to them by the Australian people on 2 March. At the other end of the spectrum, the government has recognised the significant contribution the elderly have made to the development of this nation and has introduced measures to assist these people enjoy their retirement years. One such couple from my electorate were quoted in the
Courier‐Mail
as saying, `The 1996‐97 federal budget was one of the most encouraging ever for senior citizens.' Bill Clarke, who is the spokesperson for the National Seniors Association, and who is a constituent of mine, went on to say that it was a sensible budget that tries to overcome previous budget shortcomings and Australia's senior citizens have fared extremely well.

The raising of the tax‐free threshold for self‐funded retirees to $11,185 has been well received in my electorate as has the initiative which allows seniors to contribute to a superannuation scheme up to the age of 70. This flies in the face of the scaremongering of the opposition, which is targeting the pensioners of Australia because they are seen as an easy target. The opposition is continuing its attack on the introduction of a voluntary entry contribution fee for nursing homes. I say `voluntary' because that is exactly what it is—a voluntary fee which will be paid by those who can, not as the opposition would have us believe a flat $26,000 fee on all people who enter a nursing home.

I have had a number of calls to my electorate office from pensioners who were worried that they would have to sell their family home should they wish to go into a nursing home. Fortunately, I have been able to ease their anxiety by explaining that the contribution does not apply to those on a full pension, and nursing homes can in no way force someone to pay. These people deserve better than the treatment being handed out by the opposition.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I will turn my attention now to the environment—a subject which is very dear to my heart. My electorate of Bowman includes the magnificent Moreton Bay. The bay is one of the most significant breeding grounds for a large variety of marine animals, and it must be protected at all costs. It is also a great tourist destination.

The government has provided funding to the tune of $1.8 million for research into aquaculture in my electorate. The projects that will be conducted by the Cleveland division of the CSIRO will provide the fishing industry with vital information on fish stocks and the replacement rate of the stock.

At the same time, we need to be looking at the pollution of the bay. The government's proposed coasts and clean seas initiative is aimed at doing just this—keeping the bay clean. However, this will not be achieved without the partial sale of Telstra, which would allow the government to implement the most impressive and important piece of environmental legislation ever proposed—the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the Treasurer and all ministers for their combined efforts in restructuring the fiscal directions of this country. I believe we are on the road to recovery, with very responsible and accountable strategies put in place by our very able executive. We look forward to a brighter future once we realise that we all have a part to play in making these policies work.

We were left in a desperate situation that needed addressing, and we will not back away from our commitment to address the economic mismanagement of the past 13 years. I am pleased to lend my strong support to the measures outlined in the budget documents of 1996.

speech.speaker: Morris, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —I have some sympathy for the honourable member for Bowman (Mrs West) because, as I have said to a number of her colleagues previously, they have a lot to learn in this place. Whilst they may genuinely believe the words that are being handed to them by their leadership, they are going to get one hell of a rude shock a little bit further down the path as we go forward.

speech.para: This budget is a budget of betrayal. It betrays the promises made to Australians in the run‐up to the election. I will cover some of those promises a little later. It is a budget of deceit, because it is a budget that is presented in a manner that is designed to conceal the true impact of the budget, not to reveal it. It goes down in history as the first budget that anyone can recall which has been presented in this fashion.

There will be a lot of examination of this budget to be done in time to come. I would refer those who doubt that to
Hansard
of 10 September 1996, at page P3814, where my colleague the former Treasurer and member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) said that the budget outcome, as reported by the now Treasurer (Mr Costello) for the past year, was a deficit of $10.3 billion. He went on to say:
If we took no corrective measures it would be $9.6 billion this year.

Those figures are not the budget outcome at all. The actual budget outcome for 1995‐96 was a deficit of $5.045 million; that is, about half the figure given by the Treasurer. The forecast actual budget outcome for 1996‐97 is not a deficit at all. It is a surplus of $464 million, which is forecast to grow to a surplus of $6,638 million in 1997‐98. But these figures, of course, are not mentioned by the Treasurer in his speech because they would not fit in with his fiscal crisis rhetoric.

I strongly recommend that members look through the speech on this issue delivered by the member for Gellibrand in the main chamber. I recommend particularly that our colleagues opposite do that, because they are hearing for the first time what this is all about, and they will see how they and the Australian public have been deceived. I do not have to say that to the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). He is wiser and more knowledgeable; he knows it deep down; he can count, he can read and he can analyse. But he has to go with the party line at the moment.

This is also a budget of broken promises. As I have said, it has been presented in a form designed to conceal the attacks it has made on major sections of our population. To the best of my knowledge, it is the first budget in Australia that has been based not on principles of sound economic management but on polls and surveys. It is a poll‐driven budget that will harm specific sections of our community. This government has made decisions, based on surveys and polls, where it believes there are no votes to be lost. In fact, there may even be, in the current climate, some votes to be gained.

Those attacks are aimed at people looking for work, and their families. Running through this first Howard‐Costello budget is the same theme as ran through the Fraser‐Howard budgets, budget after budget. I read all of their budget speeches last evening, just checking. They show the same old thing: people are unemployed because they want to be unemployed. The rhetoric that is in this budget is little different from the rhetoric back in the Howard budget speeches and all of the debates back in those periods of the Fraser‐Howard government. A leopard does not change its spots. The Liberal Party has not learnt much, but it has forgotten nothing. It
goes back to the same old thing: people who are unemployed are unemployed because they want to be unemployed.

That is the most shameful approach to be taken in this country if we are talking about pulling this country together. There are people who will always have more difficulty in gaining employment than other people. There will always be people in the queue who have greater skills, better abilities and better training than others.

Looking at the employment policies of this government, I find that what they are about is contained in the budget papers in the scrapping of the CES and the designing of a scheme of contracting out to the private sector the placement of people in jobs. Who will the private sector take? As we know from experience, they will take those who have the best prospects of getting placed. Who do they not take? Who are left on the scrap heap? The people who have greater difficulty. It is not their fault. That is one part of the problem.

The other part of the problem is the economy. Looking at all of this budget and all of the projections, I find that it says—it is a wonderful objective, in their terms—that there will be no growth in employment. I will put it round the other way: there will be no decrease in the unemployment rate. So all of the prospects they are offering, all of the offers they are making and all of these changes are really about finding a way to cost or provide for their election promises, on the one hand, and concealing the fact that they really do not have a policy or a program that is going to reduce unemployment on the other.

Let us move from people who are looking for work to immigrants. That is coming forward in speeches coming from other members of this House. That is another issue the government is dealing with. That can lay fair and square right across their shoulders. It will come back to haunt them later on. This is divisiveness. This is setting Australians against Australians. Like it or not—and you might not like it, on the other side of this committee—ours is a multicultural society. It is a nation drawn from many different cultures that have lived in harmony, worked in harmony and progressed this country. This country has benefited from their presence and their contributions. A number of us in this committee at the moment come from differing backgrounds. What this budget is about and what this government is about is dividing those groups. Let there be no mistake about this.

The other group that comes from the poll surveys is that of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. Let this also rest on the shoulders of government members opposite, both in the committee and in the chamber. You will wear the acrimony for this later. It is clearly in your budget, in the measures you have taken and in the language used prior to and since the election.

The one that really worries me is the attack upon sick, aged Australians. The other attack is upon working women. But in respect of sick, aged Australians, why is it that, out of the blue, a program like the Commonwealth dental health program, for which organisations campaigned literally for years, is abolished? Almost half a million Australians utilised that program in the last financial year. In my own electorate of Shortland, in the Hunter region and in the Central Coast region which my electorate embraces, over 7,000 people used that program last year and benefited from it. Why is it suddenly abolished? Again, it is an attack on the aged. They think, `There is not going be much response there. They will not be a worry. We have got a very, very big margin and we can wear any response that might come from that.'

break.para: But then it goes to the next step—the increase in the pharmaceutical benefits charge with no corresponding increase in the allowance for people with health cards. Why is it? It is the same target. Then the next step is an entry fee to get into a nursing home. So if you have got bad teeth, and you are aged, bad luck. You are going to pay. If you need medicines, you are going to pay. But when you get to the worse stage, when you really need to be in a nursing home, then you pay up or you do not get the treatment. And don't let's have any of this fussing around the edges and saying, `Oh yes, but the nursing home does not have to demand the contribution.' If you are getting the full rate pension, if you are on a base rate pension—

talk.start.para: —You won't get in.
—Of course you won't get in, as the honourable member for Port Adelaide interjects. You will not get in.
—Rubbish! They were your ideas!

—Don't blame us for your actions. You can't run away, my dear colleague; you can't run away from your own actions. These are your actions. Why are you attacking aged Australians like this? But, worse, why are you attacking sick, aged Australians? Why are you doing this? This illustrates the callousness, the ruthlessness of a government that is really out of control. You target a group like this—aged, ill Australians—but then you say, `Oh yes, they could dispose of their property.' The Treasurer (Mr Costello) said, `Well they could sell the property.' Have you thought about what is involved? It means somebody who is ill enough to need to be in a nursing home, who is in that condition and that frame of mind, is going to be told, `You might be ill, you might be sick and you might need to be placed in a nursing home, but you are certainly fit enough to go out and negotiate the sale of your property.' The inhumanity and ruthlessness of that is something I have never seen before—never even contemplated.

break.para: But you can add to that the Medicare offices. They have this wonderful idea of Medicare offices. `We'll close down the Medicare offices that are functioning efficiently'—I have the Belmont Medicare office in my electorate scheduled for closure—`and people will be able to go into selected pharmacies.' Not all pharmacies—these are yet unnamed pharmacies. In the budget documents it says people will be able to go in and lodge a fax.

Have you thought of the retired person who has not yet gone to a nursing home, who needs medication and has been to the doctor? That person goes across to the pharmacist and has to make a claim to Medicare because they have had insurance—and this is the insurance that the government wants them to have. They have to be fit enough to operate a new piece of technology—and if they don't know, learn how to do it—and then get a credit made to their bank account, go down to one of the supermarkets and key in the amount they want to withdraw.

Just think about the impracticality of that and the burden that imposes upon people in that age group. As members, each of us knows that even the receipt of a form with the Commonwealth crest on it often terrifies and confuses people who are retired. They find it so difficult just to even get a letter, let alone face the set‐up involved in this kind of scheme. So, as I said, the way this budget is being put forward it is an attack on sick, aged Australians. It is an attack on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. It is an attack on immigrants. It is an attack on people looking for work. And it is an attack on the families of each of those groups.

When we come to working women and the changes to child care, this is based upon a belief of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that we should turn back to what he sees as the traditional family: father, mother and two children, and one income—and mother is home in the kitchen looking after the children. And, in those circumstances, if they make the cost of child care greater that might discourage people from going to work and might force women back into the kitchen and back into the household. I want to say to him: that is not going to happen. The world has moved on since those days. But the change to child‐care arrangements and the increased charges that will flow from them will impact upon those families. So it is an attack upon them.

During the election campaign, the Howard‐Fischer Liberal and National parties promised fairness and hope to all. But their first budget offers no prospect of increased employment. As I have said, it deliberately attacks sections of our community. Worse still, members of trade unions and their families are reviled almost as demons. That comes through repeatedly in the House; one hears it. The unemployed are to be punished as if they are responsible for the insufficiency of available jobs. No government in history has presented such a litany of broken promises in their first budget as has this government. But then, the Prime Minister is the same man who, as Treasurer, promised a fistful of dollars in tax rebates at the 1977 election, only to withdraw them several weeks after winning the election. That action earned him the everlasting title of `Honest John', a title he retains today.

What we have before us is a pea and thimble budget: it appears to give tax benefits to some, but then takes them back, and adds some charges through other means. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) in his second reading speech detailed the example of a two‐income family with two children under five years of age, the mother earning $22,000 per annum and the father earning $47,000 per annum, with children in community‐based child care for 50 hours per week and no private health insurance.

The result of the budget will be that such a family gets $7.70 per week from the proposed tax cuts, but is $38.55 per week worse off as a result of increased child‐care costs arising from the government's decision to withdraw the operational subsidy, estimated at $21 per week per child. When we look back at the attack on families, this government mouths all the language about families and incorporates the words `families' and `family' wherever it can into its speeches, but the reality of its policies as they are implemented is to attack families and sectionally impact to the detriment of families.

I turn now to regions and the abandonment of the regional development policy and how that will impact upon regional Australia. Anybody who has a knowledge of country Australia and has heard the reactions coming from there will understand how fierce has been the response against that decision of the government. Linked also to that is the cut in road funding, which is a substantial cut in funds from the Federal government and a reduction in its effort, and that is going to impact upon regional Australia.

I want to say something in respect of Newcastle Airport. Newcastle Airport is a project which we put forward and which came out of the federal Labor task force for the Hunter. Funding was provided by the previous government—some $2.75 million—for the civil facilities to be upgraded and transferred across to the control, on lease, of Port Stephens Shire Council and Newcastle City Council. As the one who led that task force and led the whole project, I am very proud that we have done that, because it could not happen under this government. It happened under the Labor government.

That essential piece of infrastructure has now placed Newcastle Airport Ltd in the position where it is the prime construct site for the lead‐in fighter project that is coming up for decision later in the year. And not only that: that airport is now developing as a regional hub airport, with direct services into Brisbane and, hopefully, into Melbourne. That is an example of judicious federal investment in regions providing the link and the base to generate other activity and the growth and diversification of opportunity and employment in a region—the very action that this government has turned its back on.

I turn now to the impact in the regions of the cancellation of the employment project works programs and the reduction in training programs. It is in the regions of Australia that the unemployment rate is several per cent higher than in the metropolitan areas. It is in the regions of Australia that it is always more difficult to find jobs. There is not the spread of industry and there is not the spread of opportunities, so we always do it harder—whether it is in Port Kembla, Wollongong and Illawarra, or in the Latrobe Valley and Geelong, or in the Hunter and other parts of Australia. Those training programs are much abused and ridiculed by members of the government, but those members don't seem to realise that trying to update one's skills—even if it does not place people in employment—does an enormous amount to lift the esteem of the people involved, and to lift the esteem, feelings and attitude of their families.

Try to give them current skills and to increase their opportunity. No‐one is stupid: they know that there are 800,000 people unemployed, but not 800,000 vacancies. If there were, it would be easy. Their opportunity is going to come from a growing economy, but that has to come from the diversification of regional economies—the very issue that this government has turned its back upon.

On the Central Coast and Lake Macquarie, those programs have been supplemented by the work of the skillshare organisations. Toukley skillshare on the Central Coast has played a very, very important role and is sourced out of Wyong but funded by the former Labor government. They have done a tremendous amount of work in helping people who have a lesser chance of getting a job, who are always more difficult to place. It has done a wonderful job in helping those people get skills and some of them to get into work and regain the dignity and independence of having income from employment.

Similarly with Eastlakes skillshare, they have done a very, very good job. The winding down of the skillshare organisation is really a political decision by the government. It is not a decision based upon helping people obtain skills to improve their chances of getting work.

It is all very well for some of those members opposite to say, `But how many of them get placed?'. The reality is they know and we know that there is no `turn the key solution' that suddenly provides hundreds of thousands of employment opportunities for them.

The other matter that comes forward is in respect of tourism. There was a launch at the beginning of this week by David Simmons, the former federal minister for tourism in the Labor government, of a campaign by the Hunter region tourism organisation which is being funded under a program approved by the previous Labor government.

Small business has been gravely deceived by this government and regional Australia has been deceived about the impact of the attack upon the ABC. The ABC is a vital communications service to regional Australia. For those who are in the regions the major way of getting out news to the rest of Australia and to the world of what we do, what we are good at and how we succeed is through the ABC regional news services.

Obviously, if the government has its way they are going to suffer. So will the regional infrastructure through the various programs that will not be provided as would have been provided under our government. In my own case, the Lake Macquarie City Council, which would have received almost $2 million, and received almost $2 million last year, will miss out.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Bradford, John, MP

talk.start.para: —I am sorry I missed the first part of the speech of the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), but certainly I have enjoyed what I have heard since I arrived here in the chamber. I would like to tackle him on every point that he actually raised. In fact, his speech was very similar to every speech that has been made by opposition members in this particular debate. The point is that they are finding it very difficult, in the end, to be critical of a budget which has obviously been broadly accepted and applauded by the vast majority of Australians.

speech.para: I understand the difficulty that opposition members must have. They are, after all, largely irrelevant; they have been sidelined. They were sidelined in an overwhelming fashion by the Australian electorate on 2 March. Like the shadow Treasurer, they are suffering. I am not quite sure what disease it is, but it is something like relevance deprivation syndrome.

I think the member for Shortland's speech here today just indicated the pain that he is experiencing from that, particularly as the member was a member of the Labor government for the whole 13 years. He, as much as anybody, is responsible for the mess that Australia is now in—the mess that we were elected to fix up after 2 March.

talk.start.para: —Tell us what the mess is!

—I am going to. Let me deal with some of the other points that the member for Shortland made first. He talks about unemployment. No member of the Labor party can come into this parliament and talk with any credibility at all about the problem of unemployment—no credibility whatsoever!

speech.para: They, as we remind them day after day, are responsible for the unemployment problem we have today. They presided over a regime that created unemployment, on the former Prime Minister's own admission. They created unemployment and, through their economic policies, the `recession we had to have'. Are they not immortal words from our former leader? The recession we had to have threw hundreds of thousands of Australians on to the scrap heap of unemployment. So I will not come into this chamber or, indeed, the other chamber and be lectured by Labor Party members about the problem of unemployment. They created, and they have left us with, a huge problem.

The member for Shortland attempts to defend the former government's solutions to unemployment. He is obviously an advocate of training programs. He makes the point that people are better off in training and it is good for their self‐esteem. But the point that we have made, and the point that we have proved, is that it was not good for their self‐esteem. There was training program after training program. Half or three‐quarters of them were mickey mouse programs and were not good for people's self‐esteem.

I had people coming into my office, day after day, in those dark days of the last few years, with certificate after certificate for training programs that they had been sent off to, predominantly to keep them off the unemployment list for a short period of time, if they were long‐term unemployed. Then a cruel hoax was visited on them, when they found themselves, at the end of the training program, no longer long‐term unemployed but back on the queue
at the other end, this time as short‐term unemployed. That is why there was no self‐esteem involved in those particular programs at all.

So the answer to the question of the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) is that we are solving the unemployment problem at the end it must be solved. There is only one way to solve unemployment and that is to create jobs. We are about creating jobs.

talk.start.para: —It's so simple!
—It is simple. The member for La Trobe is right. They could never understand that.
—What's your growth target? Tell us what your target is.

—They think in simple terms. They think the solution to unemployment is creating a target. The only thing they can throw back at us these days is, `If you do not have a target, you are not serious about it.'
—Give us a target for growth!

—Even blind Freddy knows, and certainly the average Australian knows, that you have to be serious about getting the economy moving again. The only way you will get the economy moving again is by getting the private sector working again and getting small business working again. That, ultimately, will be the solution to unemployment.
—You're the big end of town, not the small end of town. You're not small business.
—We are, in fact, quite the contrary. The former Labor government lived at the big end of town and they thrived off it.
—John Elliot is not in the ALP, you know.

—Mr Hawke and Mr Keating used to love going to the big end of town, sitting down at board room tables and having big nosh‐ups with the leaders of industry and the big trade union leaders. They used to love that.

speech.para: I am proud to say that I represent, in this place, the small end of town. My electorate is based on small business. The tourism industry is based on small business. That is what I am here representing. I am proud to say that I have no connections personally—and I do not believe the majority of our party has a connection—with the big end of town in the way the former government did. The Labor Party were the ones that chased the big end of town.

talk.start.para: —I've got news for you!
—If former government members want to take us on on that issue, then our position is entirely defensible in respect of that.

speech.para:
The solution to unemployment is not an easy one. We do not pretend it is easy. That is a difference between us and the former government, as well. They used to try and give the impression to people that they had all the solutions: `Here is another program and another bucket of money that we will throw at this particular problem. Here are a few people off the list for a while into a training program or a new work opportunities program.' That was the solution. Well, it turned out not to be.
In fact, quite the reverse happened. The situation actually became worse and, at the end of the day, we ended up owing a lot of money.

If the former government's systems had worked, they might have solved the problem to some extent and the money we spent on it would have been worthwhile. But the great irony
and the great disappointment were that, having thrown those hundreds of millions of dollars into those programs, that did not work. We were left with a deficit of some $8 billion, as a result, that we had to come up with solutions to. So the money was wasted. It was borrowed and we had a debt problem.

talk.start.para: —Third lowest deficit in the world!

—You can twist those statistics as much as you like. We are talking about the situation here in Australia as it applies today. The fact is that you borrowed money hand over fist. You sold off the family jewels. You did whatever you could to throw money into all of these programs, none of which worked.

speech.para: Our small business policies which were criticised by the member for Shortland are aimed at getting the small business sector working. That is not going to be easy. We do not pretend that it is going to be easy, and that is why we are not going to be sucked into setting some sort of target.

The former government was great at setting targets. A former Prime Minister, you remember, said that no child would be living in poverty by 1990. It was one thing after the other. They had this great illusion that somehow targets were the solutions to problems. The fact is that we have acknowledged that unemployment is going to remain high, that there is an awful lot of underemployment in the Australian economy and it is going to remain high in the foreseeable future.

There is a lot of underemployment in the Australian economy that has got to be soaked up. There are a lot of people who gave up looking for jobs under the former government and who are now coming back into the system. They can see some light at the end of the tunnel and, of course, the participation rates are increasing. As participating rates increase, obviously it is going to be hard to get that raw unemployment statistic down for all of those reasons.

Our policies in respect of the small business sector are aimed at creating the right climate for business—and that did not exist before. Our fundamental labour market reforms which this opposition, joined by the Democrats, is committed to opposing in the Senate, and the tax and regulatory reforms are all policies announced in the budget, and they are in the process of being put into place. In fact, a large number have been put into place.

But the problem is a big one and it is going to be very difficult to solve and it is going to take time to solve. In the end we are not under illusions about the solution to unemployment. It has to be the creation of real, full‐time and lasting jobs. The utter tripe that we heard trotted out by the former government so often about the number of jobs they created! They used to come into the parliament and say,`We have created 300,000 jobs this month,' or some other ridiculous figures. When you got down to the fine print—and it was a matter with the former government of getting down to the fine print, getting behind the rhetoric, the exaggeration and the hyperbole—you found that most of these jobs were part‐time jobs, even as little as one hour a week, or transitory jobs. They were six‐month jobs for people who had been brought into one of these great programs and who would end up going out at the other end back onto the unemployed list. The end result was that over all that period of time very few full‐time, lasting jobs were actually created.

So we are getting on with the job of fundamentally reforming the Australian economy. The former government, to its credit, went down that track and did a lot of the right things. But they stopped short, particularly in the area of industrial relations, of making the reforms that were absolutely essential if the Australian economy were to thrive. They took some of the
tough decisions. They recognised that we had to find our way in the real world, that we could not hide behind high tariff barriers, and that we could not regulate a financial system in the world economy as it exists today. They took some of those decisions. But, in the end, they stopped short. We intend to carry the process on to its logical conclusion.

Our industrial relations reforms are obviously an integral part of reaching that conclusion. The member for Shortland, once again, fell into the trap of trotting out the rhetoric that we have heard from opposition speaker after opposition speaker here in his criticism of our nursing home policies.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have a lot of nursing homes in my electorate and, I think, the oldest demographic group in the country. So I am very close to what is happening in that area. I believe that the end result of our reform of nursing homes will be overwhelmingly positive for older people. It is a disappointment to me and to many others that the opposition has perhaps seen a little bit of an opportunity here to criticise an element of that policy. But, in the end, what they have done, and what they set about doing, is to frighten older people into believing that there is something draconian or something inherently unfair about this policy. What they have done is to misrepresent and distort that policy. They have seen just a glimmer of an opportunity to do that, and they have jumped right in.

When I have been putting people in the picture about that policy, I have been able to defend it entirely, because it is defensible. The end line of that policy—the former government would not take the step—is that we will have better quality aged care. What could be more desirable than that? What could be fairer than the underlying principle here, which was always subscribed to by the former government, that people who can afford to pay for this—or anything else, if it comes to that—should be required to do so? That is the essential element of this particular policy. It extends to nursing homes the principle that the former government introduced in respect of hostels. It means that people who can afford to make a relatively small contribution will be asked to do so. There is nothing unreasonable about that.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the unfairness of the opposition's misrepresentation is that they thought, `We will jump in and attempt to frighten as many old people as possible into believing that somehow there will no longer be a nursing home place for them, unless they either have the money or sell the family home.' But neither of those criticisms is true. We have made the point over and over again, although opposition members do not want to hear it, that people will not be required to sell the family home to move into a nursing home and people who cannot afford to pay will simply not have to pay. The principle of that is sound, and it is a principle that the former government always accepted.

This has been one of only a couple of very small windows of opportunity for criticism in this budget, and the opposition has jumped on it in an attempt not to make a small opening in the window, but to throw it wide open and make people think that there is actually something draconian about this policy. I am happy to stand up here, as I have stood up in my own electorate—which, demographically, is this group—and say to those people that our policy means better aged care. Not only that; it will also address the other fundamental problem that we had with the former government, and that was a chronic shortage of nursing home beds.

In my electorate, there are people who cannot get into nursing homes. There are people moving from one respite situation to another, at a very critical stage of their life, who cannot find a permanent nursing home bed. The former government did nothing to address that problem. Everything was wrong with the current system, especially the funding complexities.
We have attempted to reform that area, and I believe that we have been very successful in doing so. So, I take considerable issue with the member for Shortland for attempting to jump on that particular bandwagon. I make the point to him and to the chamber that our nursing home policy has an overwhelmingly positive end to it as far as that particular sector is concerned.

The member for Shortland went a little further down the track in trying to frighten my constituents, the older demographic group, about access to Medicare offices. Once again, he failed, in terms of recognising the fact that access to a Medicare office has been and is a problem. I have got two Medicare offices servicing my electorate, one at the southern end and one at the northern end, and nothing between them. I had constant complaints from people who could not get access to Medicare offices. Our solution to that, which is a practical and sensible solution, is to provide additional facilities where people can have access to Medicare offices. There is no suggestion in that—the member for Shortland tried to say that there was—that this will somehow make it difficult for older people. For a start, most of my aged constituents do not even go to a Medicare office. They do not even need to go. They go to a doctor, where their needs are taken care of, and they are bulk‐billed for that service. We have indicated that that will continue. But for people who do need access to Medicare offices, for all sorts of reasons, we will increase the availability of that service.

Nothing the member for Shortland said and nothing any member of the opposition can say about that can deny that fact. They can try and frighten as many people as they like, particularly older people, into somehow thinking that this is a major backdown on some aspect of health care policy. In fact it is again an improvement in the status quo and I applaud that policy. My electorate welcomes that policy overwhelmingly and fortunately most of the people in my electorate understand what the benefits of that additional access to Medicare facilities represent for them.

The coup de grace, if you like, for the member for Shortland, from my perspective, is that he wants to get into the area of family policy. This a matter that is on the agenda in the main chamber today and it is a debate that I am looking forward to participating in very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. If there is one policy area that I have taken an interest in here, amongst a number of others I suppose, it is certainly the area of family policy. I stand here today in this chamber as I will in the main chamber later, very proud of the commitment of this government, as the budget indicated and underlined, to Australia's families. Australia's families were forgotten by the former government. The former government was diverted into all sorts of appeasement of minority groups and a whole range of activities, but in the end they forgot about the traditional Australian nuclear family which after all is the fundamental unit of our society.

I believe that was a fundamentally important reason why the former government was defeated at the last election. It had simply forgotten the mainstream. It had forgotten the important part that families play. The member for Shortland attempted to criticise the new policy direction that we have now introduced. Underlying that policy—and he was particularly critical of the implications for child care—was our commitment to providing choice for Australian families. Australian families said on 2 March they were sick of the government telling them how to run their lives. Our policies are aimed at giving families choice—choice in child care, choice about whether both parents go out to work—and an end to conscription for mothers who overwhelmingly indicated they would prefer to stay at home and look after their children.

break.para: I dispute everything that the member for Shortland has said about what has been an excellent first Howard government budget.

speech.speaker: Jones, Barry, MP

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in a sense we are all economic rationalists and nobody would seriously urge a return to economic irrationalism. In the 1970s a global economy developed, breaking down traditional trade barriers and the goal of national self‐sufficiency. Economics rose and rose as the dominant intellectual paradigm and driving force in politics and administration.

speech.para:
In the 1970s and 1980s economics became overwhelmingly dominant in government thinking in the West and human activity was measured by its ability to meet `the bottom line.'
It also contributed to a top down political model in which major parties competed with each other to show their toughness in making essentially short-term economic decisions, despite evidence that voters were seriously alienated. This has led to a loss of confidence in the legitimacy of governments, even democratically elected ones—a profoundly worrying phenomenon.

The 1996‐97 Costello budget illustrates, in a crassly triumphalist way, 20 major fallacies, and I appeal to
Hansard
to print my speech in the format as I set it out, including the inverted commas.
The 20 fallacies:

1.
`That economics is a destination not just a vehicle.'

2.
`That economic values are more important than political or social ones.'

3.
`That the urgent must have priority over the important.'

4.
`That precisely quantifiable economic targets can be set.'

5.
`That Treasury has a wonderful track record in forecasting.'

I listened to many maiden speeches by members elected on 2 March with their heavy emphasis on family values and wondered how far they realised those values were undermined, not reinforced, by the dogmas of economic rationalism. The idea that every value has a dollar equivalent is repellent but inescapable, especially in sport, but it applies increasingly in education and health too.

With a gross domestic product of almost $500 billion, the highest OECD growth rate, the third lowest debt to GDP ratio in the OECD and a high degree of social stability, the battle cry of `Woe to the vanquished' and frenzied pursuit of the arbitrary, largely mythical, `black hole' is extraordinarily misplaced. As the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has conceded when overseas, he inherited an economy in very good shape. The rhetoric of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) is quite contrary.

Treasurers, on both sides of politics, can become obsessed with targets expressed in absolute numbers, rather than a range of figures, plus or minus, say, 2 per cent. It then becomes a demonstration of masculinity to be able to reach the magic, if arbitrary, goal. The amount of damage caused, for example, to long‐term activity such as education, research or culture is quite out of proportion to the actual sums saved in short‐term cuts.

It might seem self‐evident that a five per cent cut across the board for, say, CSIRO or the ABC, will lead only to a five per cent reduction in activity. But it does not work like that. Most budget allocations are locked up in salaries and other inescapable outgoings. A five per cent overall cut to an agency will have a devastating impact on discretionary funding—that is, the amounts not actually locked up. Having to meet a five per cent target will often mean
the difference between viability and non‐viability, a point very well made by Dickens's Mr Micawber.

An efficiency dividend might seem appropriate where applied to some areas where the range of activity is finite—for example, processing Medicare accounts or taxation transactions—but mindless when applied, say, to the acquisition of books for the National Library or setting goals for research into radio astronomy. What does it mean: `Last year you measured 1,000 stars; this year cut it down to 970'? A research project can be destroyed with the slash of a Finance bureaucrat's word processor. It may never be restored. Short‐term factors dominate.

The much publicised `$8 billion black hole' is a completely arbitrary figure, relying on the assumption that the Treasury forecasts are infallible. Note that the government insists on setting absolute numbers in the budget, aimed as it is at discrediting the Hawke‐Keating government, but refuses—rightly, I think—to do it in unemployment where it would be the victim if the magic target was not met. Even if the $8 billion figure were correct, it could be covered in a variety of ways: one, cutting expenditure; two, raising revenue by a small adjustment to the tax rate; or three, a judicious mixture of one and two.

The Treasurer's choice is to slash and burn. For example, eliminating the dental program for the aged was harsh to the victims but saved only $400 million to the revenue over a four‐year period. The Treasury does not have a wonderful record in forecasting and has been wrong in predicting growth rates and interest rates. It gave spectacularly bad advice on interest rates during the recession of 1990‐91.

6.
`That Australia is a highly taxed country.' In 1993, of total tax revenue as a percentage of GDP at market prices, of 24 OECD countries Australia ranked second lowest at 28.7 per cent. Only Turkey was lower, at 23.5 per cent. Japan was at 29.1 per cent and the US at 29.7 per cent. The OECD average was 38.7 per cent.

7.
`That Australia has an unduly large public sector.' One might expect that in a huge country with a federal system there would be a very large public sector and some degrees of duplication. In OECD's
National Accounts
1996, in a table setting out current general government revenue as a percentage of GDP, Australia ranked as one of the three lowest: US, 31.7 per cent; Japan, 32.9 per cent; Australia, 33.5 per cent. Canada, with which Australia has much in common—a large country with a federal system—stands at 33.5 per cent.

Government employment as a percentage of total employment is also relatively low: 16.6 per cent. Some nations, curiously, have higher government expenditure but lower employment: Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland. The US figure is 14.5 per cent—far below us—and Japan's is an unusually low 5.9 per cent.

8.
`That foreign debt is largely due to government borrowing.' Deregulation of the financial market after 1983 led to a winding down of controls on private borrowing and has been the largest single factor in increasing foreign debt. Incidentally, Australia has the third lowest public debt in the OECD. Of foreign borrowing—that is, gross debt—the Commonwealth government, plus the Reserve Bank, accounts for 15.3 per cent of the total. State governments are responsible for 17.8 per cent. Borrowing by public enterprises such as Telstra amounts to 6.1 per cent. Private sector borrowings amount to 59 per cent. With net foreign debt, the private sector accounts for 63 per cent.

9.
`That interest rates are "current account deficit driven".' This was stated as an absolute statement of fact by the Prime Minister in question time last week. The Parliamentary Library can find no evidence to support this. Despite variations in overseas ratings by Moody's and
Standard and Poors, all Australian governments have `an immaculate record' in repaying, and this is the major factor for long term investors. Short term interest rates are set by the Reserve Bank.

10.
`That Australia's employment levels fell under Labor.' There was an employment revolution which began under Fraser, continuing under Hawke, Keating, and now Howard—a dual labour market with the paradox of high levels of unemployment and high levels of employment as well. It sounds like a contradiction in terms, but it is absolutely correct. What it means is that many people, for example, unskilled males who traditionally were in the labour force are now no longer in it and a number of people who traditionally were not in the paid labour force, particularly women, are now in it. So the result is that, in terms of the participation rate, we are at an historic high and we have the phenomenon—we are not Robinson Crusoe in this; it is shared with most countries of the OECD—of having high unemployment and high employment at the same time. But, with the dual labour market, it means that different sectors are involved in different ways.

11.
`That cutting government expenditure will free up the economy and lead to job creation.'

12.
`That freeing up small business will generate many more jobs.'

13.
`That productivity can be increased without job loss.' There is absolutely no empirical evidence to support the last three points. This is, as Martin Luther might have said, `justification by faith alone'. Productivity, of course, we see as being an OK word—everyone wants productivity. But productivity simply means the ratio between output and the number of people employed. In other words, if with higher productivity there must be job loss relative to output. That is what it means.

14.
`That there could be no gain without pain.' Wage cutting, and confusing flexibility with instability, will not produce a stronger economy. Countries with higher wage rates than Australia—for example, Sweden, Norway, Finland and Japan—are far more competitive internationally than Australia and have significantly lower unemployment rates than we do. The argument that we could only create jobs if we opened up the el cheapo end of the market is absolutely, totally fallacious. And indeed, to give the government credit, they are not even advancing any evidence. They simply assert it and leave it at that.

15.
`That government enterprises are necessarily less efficient than private.' This is an ideological obsession, quite ill‐founded if we compare the record of Qantas versus Ansett, of the Commonwealth Bank versus Westpac, of Telstra versus British or French Telecom. The costs of telephoning London or Paris from Melbourne are far lower than the return call on a privatised system. Logic suggests that if the privatised system is much more efficient, then telephoning Australia from Britain or France should be a good deal cheaper. In fact, as every consumer will tell you, it is very much dearer. That suggests there is something wrong with the proposition.

16.
`That foreign ownership of Australian corporations will have no adverse domestic effects on employment or social policy.' The tragedy, with which all too many members are thoroughly well aware, is that if a corporate decision is made in Detroit, for example, to cut jobs, of course the people who make the decision have no community responsibility because they do not know the people, they do not know the areas, they do not live there, they do not have the social contact. The argument that a whole number of enterprises can simply go offshore and it will not have any social impact is a dangerous delusion. There are many people in the coalition parties who know better, in terms of their own experience as local members,
but who, because of the way in which the system operates, are not quite in the position to speak out as they should.

17.
`That Australia can only rely on comparative advantage'; that is, David Ricardo's concept of comparative advantage. Our obsession has been that other than raw materials there was no other possible base for our economy. That is, again, a half‐truth. Of course, the contribution of the primary sector, of agriculture and mining, is absolutely profound. But if we say, `That is as far as we need go; nothing more to be said,' that is dangerously short‐sighted.

Australia's greatest single economic weakness has been our conspicuous failure, over many years, to address what I have called the `inventory problem'; that is, the lack of high value added brand name goods and services for which there is international recognition and demand, the area of fastest growth in world trade for three decades. We see ourselves as exporters of high volume, low cost exports, and little more. We have utterly failed to grasp the nature of `competitive advantage'—that it is not just a matter of cost in exports but of value, recognition and reputation.

The Republic of Korea—within the next week or so to join the OECD—understands `competitive advantage'. We do not. They had an economy absolutely in ruins in the mid‐1950s—nothing to build on at all. So, what they decided was not to pursue comparative advantage, because there was no area of comparative advantage for them, but to pursue competitive advantage—to find niche markets and develop quality products. We can all see the extraordinary intervention in the Australian market of the Hyundai motor car and the tremendous proportion of electronic products from Korea.

What are the equivalent products that we are selling Korea? They are all staples—wheat, wool, coal and the basic metals. We export products measured in tonnes; they export to us products measured in grams. There is something wrong with that. I commend to those honourable members who have not already read it—although I know that you are a devotee of it, Mr Deputy Speaker—Michael Porter's great book,
The Competitive Advantage of Nations
, a textbook that everybody in this parliament should read.

18.
`That it is illegitimate for governments to be making choices'—also known as `picking winners'—`in priority areas for innovation.' It is true that there may be some slight modification there.

19.
`That winding down R&D expenditure indicates that Government is giving it a higher priority.' It sounds a bit contradictory, and indeed it is. I remember John Elliott saying to me a few years ago, when I was trying to goad CUB into doing more R&D expenditure, `What sorts of signals are you giving? If you are winding it down in levels of your expenditure and then you are saying to us, "You ought to be spending more," the signal is completely contradictory. If you don't think it is worth putting more money into it, why should we?'

This was a big defeat for the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and a win for the Treasurer. Cutting back R&D tax concessions from 150 to 125 per cent is estimated to save the revenue $2,247 million between 1996 and 2001. The Treasurer announced `a flexible package of $340 million over the next four years to encourage highly innovative research and development'. But this involves a shortfall, overall, of nearly $2 billion. So, is it an advance, or is it a retreat?
The final fallacy—one that I feel very badly about—is No. 20: `That CSIRO did well in the budget.' In his budget speech, the Treasurer said:

break.para: The government will provide an additional $115 million over the next 4 years for CSIRO.

That sounds very generous. In fact, it is totally deceptive. With the impact of extra efficiency dividends, and a requirement to repay asset sales, leaving inflation aside, CSIRO can expect to be $10.3 million worse off by the year 1999‐2000. So, far from having a $115 million increase, they will be $10.3 million worse off, leaving inflation aside.

In other words, what they have said is, `Look, we'll provide the $115 million, but we will take it back from you. It looks good and we are not going to talk about the fact that the efficiency dividend has been cranked up.' I succeeded, in part, in getting the efficiency dividend wound down. I thought it was bad enough under our government. But it has now been re‐imposed, right across the board, at a higher level. If people on the coalition side are not aware of that, they ought to be. They ought to be asking their minister raising it in their party rooms.

This is a miserable, mean‐spirited budget. It also has the politics wrong, because it is remote from the electorate and will be destructive to community values. The community is far more than a `market'. The worst kind of bankruptcy is moral bankruptcy. Telling the truth might be a good start. I commend the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and I hope honourable members will support it.

speech.speaker: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

talk.start.para: —I remember, in my childhood days, performing in a school play. It was the story of the king that had no clothes. It might not be surprising to those present that I was one of the tailors who conned the king into believing that we had made him a beautiful set of clothes at great cost when, of course, he went down the street in public naked. All the people were cheering and commenting on the magnificent clothes, until a very small child said, `Mummy, the king's got no clothes on.'

speech.para: I make that point because today I would like to address the budget and the concept of how it and some of the contributions that have been made could be described as `naked'. In the context of this debate, let me start with a statement of fact, which is that too many politicians measure excellence by expenditure.

That leads me to the speeches of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and the member for Aston (Mr Nugent). The member for Oxley, for instance, called for the closure of ATSIC. The member for Aston, in seeking to rebut the member for Oxley, quoted the acknowledged substandard living conditions of Aboriginal people. Unfortunately, I feel the member for Aston's examples were, in fact, substantial reasons for the disbanding of ATSIC and all the associated bureaucratic structures, such as the Aboriginal legal aid services and the Aboriginal medical services and land councils, that have so obviously failed to address the fundamental problems of the very disadvantaged people in Australia known as our Aboriginal people. While tens of millions of dollars are allocated in this budget to funding white lawyers to lodge land claims, there are many Aboriginal people with glaucoma who can no longer enjoy the beauty of their land. They simply cannot see it.

Personally, I acknowledge the good intentions, on behalf of their constituents, of both members. The MP for Oxley, as the representative of an electorate where many white people are suffering low living standards and unemployment, feels that more attention to their problems is required and resents the special allocation to Aboriginals. The member for Aston concerns himself, quite properly, with the deprivation of the Aboriginal people, and wishes to give them help.

break.para: I wish to give positive and genuine assistance to both groups, and I am convinced that the current method of service delivery to Aboriginal people is a total failure. Not only is it not helping Aboriginals, but it is consuming large sums of money that might go to other disadvantaged people. In fact, in delivering decentralised, conventional, bureaucratic structures for the Aboriginal people, we have created a typical third‐world hierarchy: a small group of very well‐off Aboriginals and a poverty‐stricken majority.

I lack time today to develop this further, but my solution is a complete reversal of Aboriginal funding, from our current top‐down funding system, to a bottoms‐up system. I refer the parliament to my letter published in the
Financial Review
on 30 August. In this process I propose the total removal of all the current Aboriginal bureaucratic structures, including the Council for Reconciliation. In this regard, let me say that, if we want evidence of the efficiency of this institution, let me refer you to the community—not the media—reaction to the member for Oxley's public statement.

If our pursuit is for reconciliation, why do we support in legislation a native title process that, at every stage, throws interest groups into direct confrontation with one another? In any other area of land management, state government administrations stand as the determinant and thus—if I can use the word—the enemy.

At this stage, in my electorate and throughout my state we have Aboriginal in conflict with Aboriginal and Aboriginals in conflict with white people, and nobody is going anywhere. Surely, it is time that we found some clothes that the king might wear.

Passing to the broader effect of the budget, let me say that I support its thrust, which is to stop the process of increasing indebtedness of our nation and the burden that that applies to future generations. Put simply, during the term of the previous Labor government, this parliament, using the children of Australia as security, borrowed $70,000 million and sold and consumed the proceeds of approximately $10 billion worth of public assets such as Qantas, CSL and the Commonwealth Bank.
