Whilst I have had to take these figures out briefly and quickly, it is an interesting fact to note that in 1991‐92, when GDP growth was three per cent, the deficit of the government as a percentage of GDP was 2.6—almost the same. In 1992‐93, the deficit as a percentage of GDP was 3.2—Australia's percentage growth of GDP was 4.2 per cent. The figures for 1993‐94 were 4.3 per cent and four per cent, and I could go on. The next two years we found a somewhat wider gap of just one per cent but, in reality, they were the years when massive asset sales were brought to account to artificially reduce the budget deficit.

Whilst my education in economics as a science was limited to my leaving school examination—at the end of my secondary schooling at Perth Modern School—after that I continued my education in the school of business hard knocks. Based on that experience, I must say that turnover growth—that is, Australia's GDP, which is entirely debt and asset‐sale driven—is not sustainable growth, particularly when in this case the expenditure involved was almost entirely directed to consumption, rather than to capital works. For years, this country has boasted economic growth which was identical to the amount of money that the government borrowed in that year or which it otherwise accumulated by selling off the farm. With that sort of growth, we have a situation that can only take us backwards.

Just briefly, let me look at the budget outlays therefore, by function, to show where the money has gone. In that regard, I want to refer to the massive growth that has occurred, for instance, in the provision of health services under Medicare. In just the life of that proposal,
we have seen a growth in outlays from about $3 billion to $19.4 billion. But worse, in terms of investing in the future, in that same time education outlays grew from $4 billion to $11 billion. So we are pouring money into a philosophical issue that never worried us once—called Medicare—and, in the same breath, we are cutting back on education which, surely, is an investment at government level in the future. It is like a business building a new factory—something that is there forever.

This budget reduces the government's expenditure by many billions of dollars and consequently curtails that accumulated debt. However, it also must have a downward effect on GDP growth which, in the national interest, must be filled by the private sector. The previous speaker, the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), tried to recreate this myth that government debt does not have an effect on interest rates. But when you have a government pulling $10 billion or $15 billion a year out of domestic interest markets, of course it is having an effect. Furthermore, a lot of that paper, when sold, is bought by overseas interests and contributes to the nation's overseas debt.

A number of criteria have to be met or the private sector will not fill this gap which has been created by a reduction in government expenditure. And it is a gap—government has been propping up this economy for 15 years and, as government ceases to do so, somebody else has to fill the gap or, yes, we will have economic decline. I am the first to admit it. But, as I said, the private sector will not fill this gap unless a number of criteria are met. These include the ability for business to hire and fire staff based on the staff's personal performance and the financial circumstances of the business.

No‐one sacks staff out of spite. That is a myth that has to be exploded. This myth has built up that people have to be protected from businessmen who get up in the morning and say, `Who can I sack today?' I have talked to businessmen who have cried when they have had to put off staff—and I mean cried—because they did not know whether they could get such good people back when they recovered the financial circumstances of their business. The reality is that business does not hate its staff. It values it, but it has to have staff who perform. In times of economic downturn they have to have the right to put some of them off, and they cannot do that at this huge redundancy price. Their defence is just not to hire.

The criteria that have to be met in order for the private sector to fill the gap also include the productivity value of such people based on international comparison. Productivity value does not imply lower wages, but does demand higher productivity per worker than occurs in low wage countries that compete with our industries at home and abroad. It was the previous government that took the decision to deregulate the financial market and lower tariffs, and I support that concept. But you cannot ask business to compete in that environment with a regulated labour market. It is just silly.

The new industrial laws that are being proposed by the government are therefore essential. The argument of jobs for jobs' sake is just another king with no clothes. If Telstra employs 20,000 employees it does not need and passes the cost of those employees to industries who must compete with countries around the world, then those industries simply die or never develop. If employing public servants was the answer to unemployment, why not just double the size of the Public Service? We could fix the problem overnight—except that we haven't got the money to pay for it.

Nevertheless, this budget is also topless, to say the least, because it fails to reform the Australian tax system. But the fact that it does not cannot be criticised because the governing
party promised at the last election it would not do so. It is a tragedy, but it was a promise that had to be made at the time. However, if the Australian private sector is to provide the real GDP growth and jobs we require, it is absolutely imperative that this parliament—and I do not say this government or this opposition, I say this parliament—join together to take the lead of the Australian tax system out of the saddlebags of Australian industry.

There is not a politician in this place who does not agree that the Australian tax system is a mess and a huge burden to Australian employers. I pointed out last night to the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), with his huge responsibility to people in the car industry, that $700 to $800 is the cost, as estimated by Australia's Treasury, that feeds into the manufactured cost of every motor car made in Australia, because of the Australian tax system. We blame the workers for their lack of productivity, yet we never blame the Australian tax system, and it is probably the worse of the two. I think that Australian workers have lifted their productivity; the facts are there. But, while we are blaming the workers and denying them jobs, we sit in this place being too smart by half, using the tax system as a political tool when we should be joining together, every one of us, to put down a sensible reform package for each level of government: local, state and federal.

I tell you what: we would create many brownie points with the Australian community if, on an area of such national importance, we got together and demonstrated bipartisanship. I think the last person to do it was a Labor person, Mr Curtin, when he invited Bob Menzies—who foolishly, as I remember, declined—to form a government of national interest to defend Australia during the war. Of course we should get together on these sorts of issues. It is too big for political pettiness. The Australian tax system is the worst. Australia is in a tax time warp, and the rest of the world is passing us by.

Let me return to my written words and say that we should all be collectively ashamed of ourselves if we cannot join together to establish a workable solution for revenue raising in all three levels of government in our country. There is nothing wrong with, at that time, addressing the difficulties for certain groups of people, the poor and the disadvantaged, of any system. But let us get together and say, `This is the best tax system; these are the difficulties it creates; let us address them in that circumstance.'

Another urgent requirement is that interest rates fall by about two per cent, if the private sector is to fill the gap being created by the public sector. Such a fall in interest rates would have two benefits: reducing the direct cost of doing business and investing in the capital assets we need for real growth; and, of course, reducing the value of the Australian dollar. Mr Deputy Speaker, I have approached the opposition representative and I seek leave to have incorporated in
Hansard
two graphs that show both the exports growth and economic growth that occur when the Australian dollar falls in value compared with foreign currencies.
Leave granted.

interject.speaker: DEPUTY SPEAKER

talk.start.para: —Leave is granted, and the graphs will be incorporated as long as they fall within the guidelines of the Speaker.

interject.para:
The graphs read as follows
—

talk.start.para: —In both graphs, the evidence is clear that, at this stage of Australia's economic development, a lower exchange rate is very desirable, particularly when our currently high exchange rate is dictated not by our economic performance but by our high interest rates. Interest rates will fall only when governments stop borrowing money. Inflation need not rise with a lower exchange rate. The international price of the goods that come in means that they will cost more to import at a lower dollar value and, of course, that will improve the opportunity for Australian business to fill the gaps. The simple fact is that there is no such thing as an international price for a product that has been manufactured. The price is what the local market will bear.

break.para: Of course, the performance of local industry has a lot to do with that. You can buy cars in various parts of the world, but they look awfully the same to me; yet they are substantially different in price because of local market conditions. But a lower dollar value is not the reason that we will get inflation. Inflation will rise if the trade union movement seeks to steal from future generations by claiming the benefits of economic growth that would result from lower exchange rates. The joke is that, if they try to force wages up—as they are trying to do now, more for political reasons than anything else—they will force inflation up.

One of the most remarkable things that I have never been able to understand about trade union leaders is that, when they go out and get the workers a pay increase and, as a result of that we have inflation, that inflation means Mrs Jones pays more down at the supermarket; but, of course, the government has taken half the pay rise through taxation before Mrs Jones even gets the money to spend down at the supermarket. In fact, all the evidence shows that there has been a real drop in buying power as a result of some of these pay increases. It is plainly silly and it should not occur.

There is another group of people in the community that should be considered in this regard—children. The debt processes of the last 10 to 15 years and the forcing up of inflation are a charge against the children of this country. It is outrageous that that should even be considered. We must not have people rushing out for extra money the minute we start to get the economic growth we so desperately need to repay the debts of the last decade. I make the point that we can get the growth and we can put a million people back into work. It cannot be done artificially. It cannot be done by fiddling the books. Real jobs will only come with real growth, and governments have to recognise that.

I still have business contacts through my family, and we have seen some of these make‐job schemes. They are heartbreaking. The people arriving to do the jobs know they are not going to stay. They have no interest in learning anything. There was no future in it. So what we are saying is, `Let's make apprenticeships affordable.' An affordable apprenticeship for an employer is one that they will contract and keep. The reality is that, by taking away the cost of the days when the young people are not on the premises and thus creating some productivity for the employer, more employers will be prepared to take on young people.

It is stupid to think, as is currently the law, that young people should be paid the same wages as old people. It is back to this king having no clothes argument. The reality is that when you get to that, the kids do not get a job. They do not get an apprenticeship. It is as simple as that. Business people are not silly and we have not yet passed laws that demand they employ people.

The trade union movement cries crocodile tears over youth unemployment, and yet it is the trade unions that still restrict, through the award system, the ratio of apprentices you can have
to full‐time employees. How dumb is that? If we want to have skilled people so we do not have to import skilled welders from the Philippines—as occurred in my state recently—then we have to do it. I encourage everybody to get together on these issues.

speech.speaker: Causley, Ian, MP

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure to stand up in this House and reply on behalf of the budget presented by the Treasurer (Mr Costello). I believe it was a very responsible budget. It was, by its nature, a tough budget, but it was a budget that had to be tough. Many people around Australia understand that after the profligate years of Keating we had to do something to try and rein back the debt that was occurring in this country.

speech.para: I have heard many speakers on the other side talk about this being an unconscionable budget. They say there have been cuts in areas where people can least afford them and that this is a terrible government that has no compassion. They are ignoring the fact that many of them belonged to the government that ran up this enormous debt; a debt that grew from $30 billion to $180 billion during their term and a series of deficit budgets which could not continue.

The last budget was brought down to bring in a surplus of more than $3 billion, and yet we found that at the end of the day, we had a deficit of more than $5 billion. That is total irresponsibility. Any company or any business that was running its affairs in such a way would be broke tomorrow morning. Australia is no different. We have to run our affairs responsibly.

The members opposite who have been crying about the fact that certain areas have been cut, areas where people who are disadvantaged are not to receive the benefits that they received in the past, forget that if we continue to run deficit budgets such as that, if we continue to run up debt, then the very people they want to help most in the long‐term are the people they will not be able to help.

There are plenty of examples around the world of economies that have got out of control, where people have had to move in and take control of those economies. The very first thing that happens is that welfare is slashed. The people that all governments, all parties, all members of political parties want to help—the disadvantaged members of society—cannot be helped because we do not have the finances, we do not have the wherewithal to do it.

It was put by the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) that deficits have another effect. They certainly have an effect on interest rates. They undoubtedly have an effect on employment. I put to this House that, in fact, the deficit that we have run up over the last years has exported jobs from this country. The fact is that we do not have the savings in Australia for Australians to have shares in their own companies. The fact that these companies, because of the debt that has been run up, are being taken over by foreign companies is something that concerns Australians. The very basis of that is the fact that we have not had control of our finances.

I keep on having people coming to me from my electorate—the electorate of Page, which is on the north coast of New South Wales—and saying, `Don't resile from the job. Keep on with it, because we understand that we have to straighten this country out. We cannot leave a debt to our children and grandchildren and expect them to have to pay for our profligate ways.' I am sure that there are a number of people in Australia who share that view.

I believe that the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) touched on a lot of issues in the community which go deep into this budget and go deep into the areas that budgets are about in Australia, those of funding particular programs about which many Australians are very concerned. I have been concerned that there have been members of this House stand up and try to, in some ways, downplay what the member for Oxley had to say. In some instances,
I believe they have been trying to quieten her and deny her the right to speak in this place and bring forward her views.

In many instances these days, unfortunately, in Australia we are not allowing freedom of speech. We are not allowing these views to be brought forward. If someone dares to say it, they are either `discriminating' or they are `vilifying' and they are howled down. I believe that the member for Oxley has every right to raise, in this parliament, the issues that she raised.

talk.start.para: —Do you agree with her? What parts do you agree with? Do you agree with her on migrants or Aboriginals?

—If you listen carefully, you will hear what I have got to say. If you are prepared to listen, I will tell you. The Labor Party, of course, have failed, because they are the ones who have created these issues. The Labor Party have failed in these areas because, obviously, they have not addressed the problems that the society sees. When people say that there are a minority of people supporting the member for Oxley, I turn them to the poll done by Alan Jones, which showed that 98 per cent of the people in the community had these concerns.

speech.para: I am not saying that the concerns are legitimate. But I have to say this to you: because governments of different persuasions have been pandering to minority groups for some years now, the mainstream of Australia feels left out. They feel that they are being discriminated against. I think that is the issue that the member for Oxley has raised. It is a legitimate issue for this parliament to debate.

If you look at those areas where the mainstream of Australia believe that they are discriminated against, you find we have to address it. We cannot hide it. We cannot slip it under the carpet and say, `Look, it will go away.' It will fester and it will cause problems in this society that we cannot control if we do not address the issues that are involved.

People will say it is discrimination and people will say it is vilification. I do not believe it is necessarily so. I do not say that there is not any discrimination in this country. In fact, I agree that there is. But the fact is that we must address these areas of concern.

It is not just within the mainstream community in Australia. If you talk to the minority groups—if you talk to the rank and file Aboriginal people—they will say to you that money is being squandered and money is not getting to the grassroots where it is needed. The very people who need the support are not getting the money, even though we have spent millions of dollars on it. They are not getting the support that is necessary. It is something we must address. We just cannot push it away and say, `That is discrimination. You should not talk about this.'

I might also say—and it goes back to the discrimination argument and the Asian statements that were made by the member for Oxley—that the real concern in the community is not to do with Asians, but is to do with immigration. They are saying, `Here are our children. They cannot get work in Australia, yet we are bringing people in from overseas.' We are saying that we have to bring people in from overseas because they have skills. Yet our young people do not have skills. I think this government has addressed that in some way in this budget. I think that you can go further, but there is no doubt in my mind that to give assistance to apprenticeships, where you are training people in long‐term skills, is very important.

I have had some concerns for some time now that the apprenticeship system has served its purpose. The old indentured apprenticeship system might have served its purpose. The world
has changed, changed dramatically, and technology has caused that in many ways. Employers can no longer afford to have apprentices under the old system, particularly where they have to go away for quite some time on block release. That is why they are not taking on apprentices, that is why we have not got our young people trained. I think that this budget does something about that, that it gives some incentive to employers to take on apprentices and to see that they are trained. Those areas are very important and we must address them.

The Labor government had a method of just pouring taxpayers' money into this. I do not say that all of their labour market programs were bad. In fact, there were a couple of programs that were pretty good but in many instances, because they were so determined to manipulate the unemployment figures, this money was entirely wasted.

We saw a program on the north coast of New South Wales in the dying days of the Labor government where they threw $21 million at creating 1,750 jobs, which was ostensibly to try to save the two Labor members up there, the then member for Richmond and the then member for Page. But people saw through it. They saw that this was just a waste of their money. This is one of the attitudes that are in society today, that people are sick and tired of governments wasting taxpayers' money.

I believe that this government was elected on some of that emotion. People were saying, `We have had enough of this, we want a change, we want to get away from the systems that we have at the present time.' I believe that the member for Oxley tapped into this emotion. There is no doubt about that. This government, if it does not listen to the concerns of that great bulk of Australians out there, will go the same way as the Keating government because people believe that governments are elected to do something about the concerns that they see in their society.

I want to get more specific about my electorate of Page on the north coast of New South Wales. I was delighted to see in the budget that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) had honoured a promise which probably emanated from the parliament of New South Wales where the coalition government there proposed a Motorway Pacific. It was a grand scheme for a divided highway between Brisbane and Sydney. We have an upgrade of the highway between Melbourne and Sydney, to a great extent completed at this stage, but the other great arterial road link in Australia is between Brisbane and Sydney.

The Pacific Highway was a total mess 10 years ago until the New South Wales government and the Commonwealth government put substantial funds into it and upgraded it. However, it needs to be upgraded substantially if we are going to have a very good economic link between those two cities. I would like to say that this is a great start. We are going to have the sections from Coolongolook to Bulahdelah and from Chinderah to Billinudgel upgraded. However, there is a link in between that we need to continue on.

We should not forget that this is a start on this particular link and we should continue on. There is a link in my electorate which goes from Harwood Island bridge on the Clarence River down nearly to Woolgoolga at what is called Dirty Creek Range. That is a link that needs to be put through as quickly as possible, otherwise you will have to go back to the old meandering highway, up through the valley, and that is just not good enough for a major link.

While I am extremely delighted that the government has found the funds to upgrade these two sections I am saying not to forget that project because I believe it would probably equal the Snowy Mountains scheme in days gone past because it is an extremely important infrastructure program for Australia.

break.para: I understand also that the minister took note of another road which we call the Summerland Way which takes off from Grafton and wanders up to Casino and into Queensland behind the range, up through that area. For some time the Summerland Way has needed upgrading and I understand that the minister is talking to the New South Wales government at the present time—some positive talks, I am told—about getting an upgrading of that particular road.

That area takes some of the heavy traffic away from the Pacific Highway where most of the population is. That route from Grafton through to the Queensland border, past Kyogle, will certainly alleviate some of that heavy traffic in that area and I commend the Minister for Transport and Regional Development for coming forward with those proposals.

Small business was a big part of the government's election promise. I was listening to the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). He was saying, `How are we going to get all these jobs? Are you going to cut wages? Are you going to work at the lower end of the socioeconomic group? How are you going to do it?' I know the member for Lalor has been an eminent academic in his day but obviously he has never been in business, because that is where you generate the jobs. Jobs are generated in business. Unfortunately, I think, at the present time, of the wealth generating area of Australia, only about 11 per cent of Australians are employed in that particular sector. It is an area where we need to grow if we are going to get involved and if we are going to improve this economy. Obviously, small business is a very important part of that.

I can tell you that from my discussions with small business, do not underestimate the effects of the anti‐dismissal laws. People are absolutely terrified of them. Rightly or wrongly, they are absolutely terrified of them. When we have decisions in the courts over someone who was dismissed because they were taking money from the till and the courts let them off and say, `Well, you didn't tell them not to', I think that is a very sad day for Australia. I believe that that is one rule that you should be taught as soon as you can talk—that you should not steal. I believe it is a law that was always taught in our community. For a court to come down with a decision such as that is absolutely abysmal. The small business community has been terrified by it. While this approach in the industrial relations laws is to modify it—it is not taking it away; it is modifying it—to remove the extremes, I think is a very good move in the right direction.

The other area which has tended to be overlooked, particularly by the Labor Party when in government, is the fact that in small business all of the equity is in the business. Everything they own and everything they have worked for over years is in the business. If you are going to tax them in some way that does not allow them to enlarge that business, then you are inhibiting a very, very large sector of the Australian economy. That is what this is doing at the present time. This particular budget measure is saying that, if you want to enlarge your business, if you want to sell a business and go into a larger business, then we are not going to charge you tax on that. We are also going to allow you to retire with some of the assets that you have built up. We are not going to tax that because that is your superannuation, that is what you have worked for. Surely those are incentives that are worth while and would be supported from both sides of the political fence, because they are so important in our economy. I think both sides of politics agree that small business is very important in Australia and it is an area that must be helped.

I noted that some of the opposition did raise the spectre of the ABC. Of course, coming from a rural electorate, I can assure you that I am very conscious of the ABC and some of the
funding cuts that have been put forward. Can I say, though, that I believe the ABC over many years have not addressed inefficiencies, have not addressed their management structure, have not really closely looked at some of their programming. I believe that there are savings to be found. If you look at many of the major companies in Australia over the last 10 years, they have had some soul searching to do themselves. They have looked very closely at the management structures; they have looked very closely at their costs to see whether they could prune them and get profit back, and many of them have. I think the ABC is in the same position.

Can I say to you, though, that I am certainly speaking out loudly on behalf of regional news and regional programs. I think that that is what the ABC was based on in the first place—to get radio out across Australia. I do not think that role has changed, quite frankly; it is a core role. I would be extremely disappointed if management did not see the need to continue that particular core element in the ABC. I would speak out strongly against it if, in fact, that were the case.

In the little time I have left, I would like to touch on the point that I probably came into politics about 12 years ago and that is forestry. I am very concerned at the present time about the fact that the New South Wales Labor government is using the national forest policy as a means to close down small country communities. I do not believe that the policies that were put in place by the federal government, and that includes the previous government, were meant to be used in such a way.

I know that there is a very important need to have comprehensive and adequate reserves of forest types across Australia, but unfortunately we see that extremists take this to a further point which really does undermine industry and production and employment. Unfortunately, we have elements of the New South Wales Labor government at the present time who are trying to use this particular excuse to further their green agenda. I know I have the support of the members of the Labor Party in New South Wales. I hope I have enough support because I have spoken to a few in recent days. I call on them to look very carefully at the spurious arguments that are being advanced in this particular debate.

There is far too much dishonesty in the debate. If we look at the scientific facts, it is not supported by scientific fact but it can have very detrimental effects on small communities. It can have very detrimental effects on the economies of rural areas and very detrimental effects on the economy of Australia. I ask that anyone in this parliament who has influence talk to colleagues in the other states because this is a very important issue.

Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to address this budget. I believe that it is a very responsible budget. I believe it will set the foundations for a very strong economic return in Australia.

proctext.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

question.speaker: Andren, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 29 May 1996:

question.para: (1) Did he claim that the Australian Defence Industries (ADI) plant at Lithgow, NSW, was shabbily treated by the previous Government.
(2) Did he undertake to (a) unleash ADI and (b) ensure that ADI's local capability would not be sacrificed to the expedience of overseas purchases; if so, how.
(3) Will he ensure that ADI Lithgow retains its staffing at existing levels and pursues contracts other than defence business; if so, by what steps.

answer.speaker: Fischer, Tim, MP

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In February 1996 I stated and I quote "Since ADI was corporatised by Labor in 1988 Lithgow ADI has gone from a state‐of‐the‐art facility with about 1100 employees to a business struggling to support 200 workers". It is pointed out that during this period ADI across‐the‐board downsized by 65% as part of restructuring.

(b) In February 1996 I stated and I quote "This is a factory which is still in limbo over a key rifle contract with Thailand, despite Labor's rhetoric about engagement with Asia". It is pointed out that Thailand is still evaluating tenders for a large small arms order including the ADI tender, and I will do all I can to support ADI in a proper way regarding this tender.

(3) These are matters for the management of ADI Limited, but I can assure you that the Government takes trouble to appoint competent directors to the Board of ADI Limited whose responsibility it is to successfully manage plants such as ADI.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 26 June 1996:

break.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims that the proposals to restrict gun ownership may breach the rights of citizens to bear arms guaranteed by the Bill of Rights 1688 (UK).
(2) Has he received advice on the legitimacy of the claims; if so, what was the advice.

answer.speaker: Williams, Daryl, MP

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes. I do not consider it appropriate to provide the substance of a legal opinion in response to a question on notice.

question.speaker: Morris, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 27 June 1996:

question.para: How many staff were employed at each office operated by the Minister's Department or any agency or statutory authority for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility in the electoral divisions of (a) Shortland, (b) Newcastle, (c) Paterson, (d) Charlton and (e) Hunter at (i) 31 March 1996, (ii) 30 June 1996 and (iii) the date of answering this question.

answer.speaker: Williams, Daryl, MP

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: There are no Departmental staff in these electorates. The following portfolio agencies have advised of the following staffing in these electorates:
(a) Nil
(b) Auscript employs one permanent staff member and operates a register of 10 staff who are employed as required on a casual basis. (i) 1 (ii) 1 full time and 4 casual (iii) 1 full time and 5 casual
Australian Federal Police: (i) 6 (ii) 6 (iii) 6
Family Court of Australia: (i) 37 (ii) 38 (iii) 39
(c) Nil
(d) Nil
(e) Nil

answer.to.qon.title: Development Import Finance Facility and Export Markets Development Grants Scheme

question.speaker: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

question.para: Since 1 July 1994 which companies in the electoral division of Wills have: (a) been included in the Development Import Finance Facility scheme and (b) have received Export Market Development Grants Scheme grants.

answer.speaker: Downer, Alexander, MP

talk.start.para: —As the honourable member's question falls within the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio, the following answer is provided on behalf of both ministers.

answer.para: (a) Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF)
No companies based in the electoral division of Wills have, since 1 July 1994, either been issued with Letters of Advice, Letters of Formal Offers or received direct funding under the DIFF scheme.
(b) Export Market Development Grants (EMDG)

The confidentiality provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985 preclude the release of detailed information concerning the affairs of individual grant recipients such as, the electoral division in which companies receiving grants are located. Therefore, the information sought has been provided on an aggregate rather than on an individual basis.
Since 1 July 1994, a total of 36 grants under the EMDG scheme have been received by companies in the electoral division of Wills. The total value of these grants was $1,915,829.

answer.to.qon.title: Emergency Relief Providers: Electoral Division of Wills

question.speaker: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

question.para: Will she provide (a) the total sum and (b) a breakdown of Commonwealth funding allocated to emergency relief providers in the electoral division of Wills including the (i) Coburg Community Information Centre, (ii) Moreland Salvation Army, (iii) Glenroy Salvation Army, (iv) Brunswick Salvation Army and (v) Melbourne City Mission, Hartnett House, Brunswick, since 1 July 1994.

answer.speaker: Moylan, Judi, MP

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) Total Emergency Relief Program funding allocated to agencies in the electoral division of Wills since 1 July 1994 is $371,152.88.

(b) Of the five agencies specified in this Question, two fall within the current electoral division of Wills, the others are in the electorates of Calwell and Melbourne. Funding broken down by agency and financial year is as follows:
Electorate of Wills
Electorate of Calwell

break.para: Electorate of Melbourne
Notes
1. The Melbourne City Mission, Hartnett House, ceased providing Emergency Relief Program funding as of 1 July 1995.

2. The figures represent the first payment which has recently been forwarded to agencies and is roughly five‐twelfths of the original (ie before the $5 million supplement) full‐year estimate. The final level of funding for each agency for 1996/97 will incorporate additional funding from an allocation in the 1996/97 Federal Budget. The final payment will be made in December 1996.
